story:
What Is This?

"In my four years of living in New York, I've only ever swiped right on white guys on Tinder."

I LOVE WHITE MEN is an exploration of one Asian woman's obsession with white men. Through a series of confessions, Reddit posts, email records, historical research, and reflection on her Singaporean upbringing, YY attempts to unpack the complex relationships she's had with the various white men in her life-- and figure out where to go from there.

NEXT UP at Ars Nova ANT Fest 2019, on Thursday June 20th, 7pm. Get ready for a show about white worship, postcolonial baggage, and lots and lots of sex!!!

ANT Fest is Ars Nova’s 12th annual celebration of All New Talent, in which they jam-pack the month of June with at least one (or 2 or 3!) one-night-only performances from artists they are excited to get to know. We are beyond thrilled to be among great artists!

 

Who We Are

Sim Yan Ying (Creator & Performer) is a theatre artist based in New York and Singapore. She creates works that are borne out of her obsessions - which are often messy and ugly - and her preoccupation with ordering this chaos. She draws much of her inspiration from New York City bars, strangers on the streets, and her Facebook newsfeed.

Renee Yeong (Director) is a Singapore-born, New York-based theatre director and sound designer. She most recently assisted Rachel Chavkin on Bess Wohl’s world premiere play Continuity and will be a member of the 2019 Lincoln Centre Director's Lab. She is also an avid Oprah SuperSoul podcast fan and loves hosting dinner parties.

Nicholas Chan (Dramaturg) is a Singapore-born writer that loves tackling spicy issues like social inequality, postcolonialism and racial disparity often through fantastical lenses. Before graduating from NYU, he was the lead writer of a Singapore-based video game company, and now is excited to explore a very different kind of fantasy with ILWM.

Lisa Mordkovich (Producer) is a New York-based producer completing her BA in Performance Studies at NYU Tisch School of the Arts. Recent producing credits include: Tisch New Theatre's Next to Normal at Soho Playhouse and I LOVE WHITE MEN at Dixon Place. She is leaving to continue studying producing in London this summer and wants to start a theatre company in the mountains somewhere because she thinks she is destined to live in the mountains.

Chris Voegels (Lighting Designer) is a lighting designer who has worked on numerous student works at Playwrights Horizons Theater School. Credits include The Content Generation, Where Are You, Annie Aspen's Musical Space Spectacular!, and Rekindle. Chris is excited to finish his last year at NYU in the fall, majoring in - you guessed it - acting!

Tate Rehklau (Projection Designer) is grateful to be the honorary white man of I LOVE WHITE MEN, developing work with a team that welcomes him, listens to him, and openly praises his every action. His primary responsibilities include: posing with YY for pictures, introducing YY to his friends, and going to dinners with her and her family. He would like to thank the team for being so appreciative, like... strangely appreciative.

Alexis Lapp (Publicity Manager) is an NYC based artist, currently studying directing at NYU. She has recently had the joy of assistant directing at St. Ann’s Warehouse annual puppet lab, Labapalooza! under Sharone Halevy. Thanks to Renee and YY for this opportunity & cheers to the changemakers baby!

 

Timeline

January 2018: Development began with core creative team Sim Yan Ying, Renee Yeong, and Nicholas Chan

June 2018: Closed workshop presentation at Playwrights Downtown with collaborators Danica Jensen, Jacqueline Brockel, Beth Golison, Tate Rehklau, and Frances Yackel

January 2019: First public (and sold-out) performance at the Dixon Place Mainstage, with collaborators Lisa Mordkovich, Tate Rehklau, and Ava Novak

June 2019: Second public performance at Ars Nova ANT Fest 2019!

 

Some Backstory...

I LOVE WHITE MEN started with a conversation in KFC in Singapore, when Renee and I were home for winter break. I told her, “I’ve only dated and swiped right on white guys ever since I moved to New York.”

She asked me why. I said I didn’t know. And so I embarked on this project, together with my core collaborators Renee and Nick, as a means to find out why - and it has proven to be messier and more complicated than I thought.

I examined conversations with my family, researched Singapore’s colonial history, read Reddit posts that broke my heart, interviewed white men who shamed me, and consolidated personal stories ranging from my unlikely friendship with a Swedish man when I was seven to my many one night stands in New York. I put all of them together, and still cause and effect eluded me.

As it stands now, I LOVE WHITE MEN is about the tension between “problematic” desires and social expectations. My desire for white men goes against the traditional Asian values that my parents and my country have worked hard to instil in me, and also against the progressive liberal ideals of equality. What do I do when my heart is unable to catch up with my mind? Why do I continue to worship white people despite knowing better? How do I go about undoing the inferiority complex that I have carried with me for decades? Can I?

I LOVE WHITE MEN was also created in response to what we felt was a gap in mainstream knowledge about Asian culture and stories, and specifically for us, Singaporean stories. There are so few stories in our global canon that capture the nuance and complexity of who Singaporeans are as individuals and we hope, as ambitious as it sounds, that I LOVE WHITE MEN can dismantle assumptions, break through stereotypes, and ignite our curiosities about things that feel foreign to us.

 

Why We Need Your Help

1. Our design team will require funding to be able to work their magic. Your donation will help us acquire props and who knows, maybe you’ll be a lucky audience member taking home a souvenir ;) 

2. Rehearsing in New York is expensive! Your money will help us find rehearsal space and acquire items for rehearsal - scripts, tape, rehearsal props, etc

3. We have a small team of seven creating a show for 100+ people, and will be working intensely for 6 weeks to develop this show! It is important to us that everyone gets a stipend as a thank you for their work. Part of your donation will go towards our goal of equitable compensation.

4. We are working to spread the word about I LOVE WHITE MEN - your donation will help us launch a solid and creative marketing campaign including Facebook ads and printed handouts, and reach audiences that are diverse in identity and political views. People whom we can challenge and will challenge us!

*If you're unable to financially contribute, you can help us out by sharing our fundraiser on social media! You can also share our Facebook event, buy tickets online and Like us on our Facebook page!

story:
UPDATES!

We have currently raised over £6,300!!!! Thank you to everyone for their support but we still have some distance to go. Help us reach our final goal!

Why Yellow Cake?

The project began by asking a question in a workshop "What do people think about Nuclear Energy?". We found that people had very strong stances, either completely in favour or avidly against. We then asked "What do you know about Nuclear Energy?" and we found the people knew very little! We then went to the streets to follow this up, with questionnaires and interviews, and again we found that people had very strong opinions but didn't know the facts. 

Thus came the project Yellow Cake. Through our research we have found that many people in the UK have a "fear" of Nuclear Energy, and that Nuclear Energy is a cleaner energy source than coal, oil and gas.

We plan to expose the truths and lies about Nuclear Energy, enlighten our audiences and entertain.

We will represent these fears, we will provide the audience with the tools to question what they are hearing and seeing. Are you afraid? Why are you afraid? What should you be afraid of? 

Yellow Cake is scheduled to have an initial showing in October, at the Bloomsbury Festival, as well as a second showing in Manchester (TBC). 

Why Theatre Company?

In order to understand we must first ask, why? This question has driven the curiosity of Max and Eleanor all their lives in the pursuit of knowledge and understanding. This question was also a key stone to our artistic analysis: Why this play? Why now? It forces us to analyse every step we take and make sure that every one is purposeful and effective. This is why we are here, right now, presenting this to you.

Why Theatre is a new company exploring social and scientific themes. Max and Eleanor studied together at RADA and, during their time there, identified the type of theatre they wanted to make and what they thought was missing from the current theatrical landscape. Encouraged by their passion for science, psychology, philosophy, morality, and the complexity of human relationships, they set up Why Theatre in 2018.

Based between Lancashire and London, Why Theatre Company are focused on bringing content driven plays to audiences across the country. Endeavouring to make new relationships and inspiring people to never stop asking themselves and others: Why? 

VISION and IMPACT

Climate change is a real threat to all of us. We hope that through this play we can give people the information they need in order to make an informed decision on Nuclear Energy and finally put a stop to the use of "clean" coal, "natural" gas and oil.

By combining immersive theatre and science we wish to fill the market gap and create a social impact that will influence all generations to engage with science and art.

We make theatre that is experimental and accessible; that connects with a larger demographic. There are science education shows for children but not many for adults. We want to change this

By working with theatre techniques which are fully embraced and realised in Europe, but are infrequently utilised in the UK, the work we create will be at the forefront of exploration for English theatre.

By putting on progressive and thought-provoking science theatre, we hope that people of all ages will be inspired to rediscover science whether it is in their professional lives or from the comfort of their couches.

Last, but not least, many articles have been written over the past few years about the increase in tribalism in our societies. This is why we want to create work that is brave, that engages with these divisions; work that encourages people to have difficult conversations whether they be about climate change, stem cell research, immigration or gender politics.

Risks & Challenges

Through financial management we have drastically reduced the risk of this project to a very small percentile.

This is a technically ambitious project and will need a high budget to adequately tell this nuclear energy story. With advice from professional producers and technicians, we are able to follow the most cost effective route to help guarantee our success.

We believe that no-one should do their job for free, and so we think it is reasonable to ask that all artists involved with this project get paid at least equity minimum wage. With your help we can ensure this and provide fair living to everyone.

The money we are raising will ensure we are able to make high-quality theatre, where everyone is paid for their hard work. 

What We Need

We have managed to raise the first chunk of what we need (yay!) to cover rehearsal space, lighting and sound hire, theatre hire and will be getting marketing support from the Bloomsbury Festival. 

However, we believe that no one should work for free. The money you give will help us to pay actors for two weeks of rehearsals, and their performances. We will also be bringing on a Technical Director to help with the creation and running of the show. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't support us financially but are keen to get involved, then please talk to your friends and family about this project and spread the word. Talk to your neighbours about nuclear energy. Ask a nuclear worker about their job. 

Science and theatre aren't incompatible; just ask us! Drop us an email at: whytheatrecompany@gmail.com

And don't stop asking yourself, and others... why?

story:
Don’t you miss the experience of theatre live and in person?


And how about if you shared space and time with the characters? What if you could

choose the perspective from which you witness the actions unfold?

Then you need to become a part of the Green Mist revolution.

●  Developed over three years at the Playwright/Directors Workshop at The Actors Studio, Green Mist is a play designed to be performed in a real house where the audience is free to choose their own path through the rooms and the action.

●  In order to be able to make this production come true, The Call Theatre is producing an immersion-infused Equity Staged Reading at Fiona's Bar in Flatbush, Brooklyn on June 13th and 14th.

●  This reading will give us the opportunity to: 1) develop the immersive aspects of the piece; 2) present the work to potential producers and investors interested in the play as a full-scale immersive installation.

●  In order to make this reading an engaging experience, we have a team of talented theatre artists who have been developing the play and will give voice to this experience.

●  Here's where we need your help! We need to raise funds to compensate these fantastic

artists for their time, craft, and commitment to bringing Green Mist to life! Can you help us to fight the mist?

In order to make this immersive reading succeed, we need to raise $2000. This will allow us to compensate everyone involved.

Why should you get involved?

The last 15 months of this pandemic have certainly been a financial challenge for Independent Theatre. However, this period has also been an opportunity to reflect on the diverse stories that need to be told in order to positively impact our society.

Green Mist is not only an entertaining story, but a reflection of how privilege has shaped our society founded on the myth of meritocracy. As we re-emerge into the world after months of lockdown, we see our society with new eyes, empowering us to make change. This story will help audiences become more aware of the systemic disparities in our society and begin the work towards a more just world.

The Call Theatre strives to revolutionize ways of engaging the community through the arts while making theatre and food more accessible to our neighbors. In this project we will be collecting non-perishable food items from the audience, using the food as props in the piece, then donating them to the Flatbush Friendly Fridge (the community fridge).

By supporting this project you are supporting:

●  Art accessibility.

●  The re-emergence of Independent Theatre.

●  The creation of stories that are relevant to our times.

●  Becoming a part of the renaissance of theatre in New York City

Other Ways You Can Help

We would love to have your monetary contribution to our project. However, if you are unable to donate there are other ways to help Green Mist.

●  Spread the word! Share this campaign with anyone you think might want to help.

●  Come see our reading! Live Theater is nothing if not for the beautiful people watching.

Please come and enjoy our story, and tell others about It!

●  Invite people to see the reading at Fiona's Bar! Know anyone who might be interested in

the play, and/or being an investor for the proposed installation?

story:
Who’s Fox? What’s Melted Riot?

Hey, I’m Fox Whitney an artist creating performative experiences that combine theater, dance and visual art. My transgender, queer, multiracial point of view is at the heart of my performance project, Gender Tender. I started Gender Tender in 2012 to feature myself and my first collaborator Will Courtney in performances that centered my conceptual point of view as an artist looking to center nonbinary perspectives. I am lucky to be able to continue to create experiences with the support of an interdisciplinary team of artists also interested in investigating the nature of queer and transgender personal relationships and histories as well as the surreal nature of transformation. Gender Tender engages a team of artists I cast that are willing to train in my methods modeled on the structures of sports teams, sitcoms and riots. 

Featuring myself, Will Courtney, Sara Ann Davidson, Leon Finley, Hexe, Loren Othón, Kristi Krein, Kathryn Hightower, HATLO, Vanessa Dewolf, Emily Batlan, Ariel Burke, Hendri Walujo, Dani Tirrell, Vida Alapour, Christine Abdale, Tonya Lockyer, Minna Lee, Tyra Kopf, Peter Kohring, Wryly McCutchen and Corinne Manning MELTED RIOT is The biggest production I’ve done to date!  We have been in development on this piece since I became Velocity’s 2018 Artist in Residence over a year ago. I am grateful for the support of this program and we are thrilled that this project is presented by Velocity.

We are raising funds for our latest project that is so dear to all of us and I need your help to pay the artists  involved and to cover the cost of materials and technical equipment for the visual art elements and costuming.

You will make our artistic dreams come true. Funds go directly to the artists first to offer them a token of appreciation in exchange for their talents, time and passion. Your contribution supports experimental approaches to how we make art and what it means to make queer art now and we couldn’t do it without you.

What do you need cash for?

Good question. Heres’ a break down of how your gifts will be distributed:

100 dollars each to 10 additional main cast artists=1000

20 each to 12 additional performers joining low commitment = 240

Lighting, speakers and projectors: 500

Costumes: 100

Visual Art Installation Materials:400

Additional Documentation for rehearsals and performances: 300

Dramaturg: 100

Rehearsal Director: 300

 

Total = 2, 840

Any amount we receive will first go to artist stipends and support roles and then be distributed to cover tech and materials. Any funds we raise beyond our goal will be used to increase the stipends that go to artists!

 

THANK YOU, art life is hard out there....

Your gift makes a huge difference in supporting the work that is so important to me. Gender Tender loves being a part of the Seattle dance and performance family and I am so inspired by the love, rigor and support I see flow through my community. We are so thankful for the ways our friends, families and audiences have supported our fundraising efforts in the past. Our previous campaigns...our Indiegogo for that GT classic Sync or Swim at Gay City in 2014 and our Hatchfund for the Renovation at NW New WOrks fest 2017...were successful thanks to YOU!! We appreciate your considering making another donation or making a donation for the first time towards bringing a GT experience into existence :)

MELTED RIOT is a project that is running on love, and the beauty of it (even your dad Fox gets emotional sometimes) is I know the stellar artists and production staff and crew would do this for nothing at all because it is that important to them to see the art they want in the world.

I swear to you, in my weirdo artist way, I’ll keep working to make the world I want come into being until someone makes me stop (LOL ain’t gonna happen). Knowing that people like you support this kind of experimentation and collaboration is what keeps me going even during the roughest patches. Thank you for reading this, if you can’t give, no need to, please share if you’d like and above all else we hope you’ll come to the show!
story_txt:
Who’s Fox? What’s Melted Riot?
Hey, I’m Fox Whitney an artist creating performative experiences that combine theater, dance and visual art. My transgender, queer, multiracial point of view is at the heart of my performance project, Gender Tender. I started Gender Tender in 2012 to feature myself and my first collaborator Will Courtney in performances that centered my conceptual point of view as an artist looking to center nonbinary perspectives. I am lucky to be able to continue to create experiences with the support of an interdisciplinary team of artists also interested in investigating the nature of queer and transgender personal relationships and histories as well as the surreal nature of transformation. Gender Tender engages a team of artists I cast that are willing to train in my methods modeled on the structures of sports teams, sitcoms and riots. 
Featuring myself, Will Courtney, Sara Ann Davidson, Leon Finley, Hexe, Loren Othón, Kristi Krein, Kathryn Hightower, HATLO, Vanessa Dewolf, Emily Batlan, Ariel Burke, Hendri Walujo, Dani Tirrell, Vida Alapour, Christine Abdale, Tonya Lockyer, Minna Lee, Tyra Kopf, Peter Kohring, Wryly McCutchen and Corinne Manning MELTED RIOT is The biggest production I’ve done to date!  We have been in development on this piece since I became Velocity’s 2018 Artist in Residence over a year ago. I am grateful for the support of this program and we are thrilled that this project is presented by Velocity.
We are raising funds for our latest project that is so dear to all of us and I need your help to pay the artists  involved and to cover the cost of materials and technical equipment for the visual art elements and costuming.
You will make our artistic dreams come true. Funds go directly to the artists first to offer them a token of appreciation in exchange for their talents, time and passion. Your contribution supports experimental approaches to how we make art and what it means to make queer art now and we couldn’t do it without you.

What do you need cash for?
Good question. Heres’ a break down of how your gifts will be distributed:
100 dollars each to 10 additional main cast artists=1000
20 each to 12 additional performers joining low commitment = 240
Lighting, speakers and projectors: 500
Costumes: 100
Visual Art Installation Materials:400
Additional Documentation for rehearsals and performances: 300
Dramaturg: 100Rehearsal Director: 300 
Total = 2, 840
Any amount we receive will first go to artist stipends and support roles and then be distributed to cover tech and materials. Any funds we raise beyond our goal will be used to increase the stipends that go to artists!
 

THANK YOU, art life is hard out there....
Your gift makes a huge difference in supporting the work that is so important to me. Gender Tender loves being a part of the Seattle dance and performance family and I am so inspired by the love, rigor and support I see flow through my community. We are so thankful for the ways our friends, families and audiences have supported our fundraising efforts in the past. Our previous campaigns...our Indiegogo for that GT classic Sync or Swim at Gay City in 2014 and our Hatchfund for the Renovation at NW New WOrks fest 2017...were successful thanks to YOU!! We appreciate your considering making another donation or making a donation for the first time towards bringing a GT experience into existence :)
MELTED RIOT is a project that is running on love, and the beauty of it (even your dad Fox gets emotional sometimes) is I know the stellar artists and production staff and crew would do this for nothing at all because it is that important to them to see the art they want in the world.
I swear to you, in my weirdo artist way, I’ll keep working to make the world I want come into being until someone makes me stop (LOL ain’t gonna happen). Knowing that people like you support this kind of experimentation and collaboration is what keeps me going even during the roughest patches. Thank you for reading this, if you can’t give, no need to, please share if you’d like and above all else we hope you’ll come to the show!

story:
I grew up surrounded by mental illness - without turning this into a soapbox or therapy session, I have direct knowledge of not only what it does to relationships and families, but how the world's stigmatization of it, especially towards women, further erodes the potential for treatment and management of it.  

Now, in 2019, with the current dual-front wars on both women and healthcare (including a massive step back in the way we talk about mental health), the script was hauntingly relevant when I had the chance to read it.  

I'm honored to be partnering with Ted Wold and a brilliant cast and crew to bring this play to New York for the first time.

All profits from ticket sales, as well as any money remaining from donations, will be donated to the National Alliance on Mental Illness.

story:
Dive into the mind of Edgar Allan Poe as he desperately searches for his lost love in this tragic dream within a dream. While exploring the ~30,000 sq ft, +20 rooms, 3-floors, and countless tales, you will unravel the mystery of his chaotic descent into madness.

Show Dates: August 13 - 25, 2019

Location: The Cultch in East Vancouver

Anyone paying attention to theatre in the last decade will have noticed the explosion in “immersive” productions," proclaims Forbes. 

Forget about seat selection. In an immersive theatre production, you won't simply watch from a cramped row of the theatre. The action happens all around you, and our "stage" is a 20-room, three-story building, transformed into an entire world full of dark delights and deeds for you to explore.

New York Times describes immersive theatre as "shows that spill out of the usual confines. Shows that envelop you, or otherwise turn you into an agent of your own experience."

Let your whims and desires guide which characters and storylines you wish to follow as you explore the space at your own pace, unearthing meticulously crafted Victorian details and experiencing secret moments unique to the path you chose. 

With 14 storylines happening simultaneously, you'll have your own unique experience that will be different every time you see the show. 

Oh and we almost forgot, you'll wear a mask the entire time and you'll take it home as a souvenir. 

Deep Into Darkness is produced by Third Wheel Productions, an experiential production company based in Vancouver, Canada. We create shows that range from large-scale immersive spectacles to one-on-one encounters that foster personal, meaningful interactions with audiences.

We've assembled an insanely talented team for Deep Into Darkness, including our production designer John R. Taylor who is a Jessie Award winner, as well as Sean William, our sound designer, who was nominated for the Western Canadian Music Awards for his work on the short film Small Fish. Our dramaturg Stephen Atkins is currently writing a book called “Crosspoints: An Embodied Acting System” and teaches this method in South London. Our fight choreographer Nic Harrison has done choreography for Bard on the Beach as well as the Vancouver Opera. And finally, our wonderful costume designer CS Ferguson who is not only an extremely talented designer but also a historian who grew up in Baltimore; where Poe himself died! Crazy and magical if we do say so ourselves.

Our cast members work on many different TV shows and films in Vancouver, including Van Helsing, Snowpiercer, Six, Ice, Sacred Lies, Chilling Adventures of Sabrina, Ghost Wars, Siren, The Detour, Final Destination 5, Robert Kirkman’s Secret History of Comics and so many more.

We're well on our way - our theatre rental and several other essential expenditures are paid for through private investments.

With your help, we'll add the finishing touches on Vancouver's largest immersive theatre project to date. Your support will fund everything to do with building a world: best in class production design, sound design and costumes! 

You'll help us take an entire modern building back in time, to the 19th century, so our audiences can get lost in a dark, abstract world that combines Edgar Allan Poe's life and stories as well as Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream. Our performance will transform The Cultch into a dark Victorian home trapped in a fairy dream world.

We'll purchase the raw materials to bring this world to life and fill entire spaces both big and small, from the floor to the ceiling, including the detailed story elements that you might even find inside desk drawers, cabinets and behind paintings. Story and character lurks wherever audiences can see and touch, just waiting to be discovered.

Funding Breakdown

We’re offering a scintillating selection of to-die-for rewards in exchange for your early support.  

Please note that you may need to double click on the reward square to see the full contents.

Also, you'll be able to choose which night you'd like to attend at the end of this campaign, after you've purchased your tickets through the perk of your choice. 

Some important things to keep in mind, when it comes to rewards:

Join the party! By getting your tickets through our campaign, you're invited to our exclusive premiere party complete with red carpet, cast and crew. That's only offered to people who get their tickets now, so don't miss your chance to toast Vancouver's largest immersive experience at our exciting launch event.

It pays to be fast! Be one of the first to buy your ticket and get it at the reduced rate of $50. Only available to the first 50 pairs of tickets sold.

Not in Vancouver? No prob! Please choose the '2 Tickets for SPCA Volunteers' option. We're partnering with the SPCA in Vancouver, a wonderful organization serving sick, neglected, abused and homeless animals. You can help us thank a volunteer for their work by giving them a ticket to enjoy our show. And, we'll send you a souvenir mask. Win/win! 

We are fortunate enough to be using The Cultch theatre in East Vancouver on Venables street.

Except for a few rooms for offices and storage, the entire Cultch will be transformed into a Victorian world. From the Historic Theatre, to the depths of the basement, audiences will be able to explore 20+ rooms of the Cultch building (~30,000 sq ft!).

The Cultch is in East Vancouver near Commercial Drive. This district of the city is a colourful area full of diverse and artistic people and we hope to add to the already outstanding community that is there during our stay at The Cultch. Deep Into Darkness will be opening right before the iconic Vancouver Fringe festival and offers a perfect complement to Bard on the Beach lovers.

We’d like to acknowledge that The Cultch is on the ancestral, traditional and unceded Aboriginal territories of the Coast Salish Peoples, and in particular, the Musqueam, Squamish and Tsleil Waututh Nations on whose territory we stand.

Tickets on Sale:

Crowdfunding EARLY BIRD deals for tickets; GET THEM NOW WHILE YOU CAN.

Regular priced tickets on sale for the show start May 2019.

August 2019 Show Dates:

  • Tuesday, 13th - Sunday, 19th,

  • Tuesday, 21st - Sunday, 25th

  1. Make a contribution! Any amount helps.
  2. Share the campaign on your social media platforms and/or via email. Tell people why you’re excited about Deep Into Darkness and invite them to be part of the biggest immersive theatre experience in Vancouver!
  3. Follow us on Instagram and Facebook. If you dig this project, you’ll be into the dark stuff we’re posting.
  4. Join our email list, to stay in the loop.

story:
What is Takes Chops Productions?

We pride ourselves in creating opportunities for early-career artists diving into this sea of an industry.  Through development and collaboration we produce published works, new works, and reading workshops.  We understand and encourage artists to develop and explore all facets of the creative process through educational workshops, lectures and mentorships. We are happy to be an artistic sanctuary for these young artists testing their wings.  We dare them to create fiercely, unapologetically, and truthfully.

Board Members

Artistis Director: Flynn Osman

Managing Director: Caroline McQuaig

Director of Development: Tessa Welsch

 

Why For the Love of?

For the Love of (or, the Roller Derby Play) by Gina Femia is a passionate, exhilarating, hilarious and seductive play capped off with an entirely female and non-binary cast!  With its fast paced, raw dialogue this show will take you on a captivating ride.

Synopsis:

When Joy gets on the Brooklyn Scallywags and meets the star, Lizzie Lightning, she and her long term partner Michelle find their lives turned upside down. For The Love Of asks how much you’re willing to sacrifice – or lose – in order to follow your heart.

Creative Team

Playwright: Gina Femia

Director: Flynn Osman

Assistant Stage Manager: Paige Mercy

Lighting Design Mentor: Emma Percy

Lighting Designer: Ariana Finamore

Costume Designer: Jennifer Iris Rivera

Scenic Designer: Nickie Dubick

Dramaturg: Lee Harrison Daniel

Casting Director: Megan Townsend 

Physical Trainer: Nora Walden 

Props Designer: Hannah Germansky

Intimacy Coordinator/Choreographer: Erica Melhorne

 

Production Team

Company Manager: Kelly McGuinness

General Manager: Tessa Welsch

 

Budget Breakdown 

If you choose to give to our campaign, your money will be going towards:

  • The copyrights to produce eight (8) performances
  • Rehearsal space to refine our production
  • Costumes designed by Jennifer Iris Rivera
  • Lighting Equipment for designers Emma Percy and Ariana Finamore to bring their vision to life
  • Sets for our scenic designer Nickie Dubick to build our world
  • Marketing, so as many people as possible can come experience this play we love so much

 

Risks & Challenges

Creating theatre is always a financial risk, but we believe it is a worthwhile one. Theater space, especially in New York City, comes at a price and we cannot cover it alone. We also have big dreams here at TCP and some of the gorgeous costume and set designs we have in mind for this new production are going to require more than what we can source from our own homes. With your funding and our ingenuity and elbow grease, we can make this DIY production look like a Broadway smash. 

Other Ways You Can Help

There are many ways to help us get this project off the ground without a financial contribution! You can support us by sharing this campaign with your friends and on social media and following us on Instagram (@takeschops).

story:
NEW STRETCH GOAL: 3000

WE BELIEVE WE CAN DO THIS!! WE HAVE SUCH AN AMAZING AND SUPPORTIVE COMMUNITY!!

We launched on Feb 3rd and we have surpassed our first goal of 1500! Which is what we needed to get started (audition space, printing, materials for the room, deposit on the theatre).

The entire budget of our production is $6,000 and if we can raise 3000 we can focus less on grant writing and getting sponsors and focus more on creating our show!

“I can no other answer make but thanks/And thanks; and ever thanks.”-William Shakespeare

 

Broken Codes: A New Play by Stephanie Garrison

Danny and Val fight for survival and freedom against the powerful Megaport. This suspenseful, quick-witted, original play Broken Codes, has been developed over the past two years by playwright Stephanie Garrison and producer/director Megan Kosmoski. Set in a near-future New Orleans and coastal Louisiana, this innovative script tackles the existential challenges facing our home through the lens of the sci-fi genre. Coastal land loss, gentrification, and classism intersect in this thrilling spy-drama.

 

When, Where, What?

May 2020. You arrive at the Fortress of Lushington, a black box theatre in New Orleans, LA.

Upon entry, illuminated on the stage you see a lived-in New Orleans neighborhood bar on the coast, warm and dark, built of rich old wood, friendly but with some darker corners for more secretive and plotting conversation. Not long after the show starts you are thrown into the MegaPort, a sterile industrial center off the Louisiana coast. The world unfolds with a projection design that sprawls across the space. You are immersed in the battle for the survival of the New Orleans coastal community. 

(Inspirational Photos)

 

Where Is the Money Going?

Production costs and artist pay. We have a small amount we personally are putting toward the production and are applying for funding, but we really need help from our community to give this script the production it deserves. Every donation helps. 

 

Who Are We?

Stephanie Garrison (playwright/producer) and Megan Kosmoski (director/producer)

We have worked together in the past on Garrison’s play SOLITARY, performed as part of Two for Tennessee in the Tennessee Williams Literary Festival in New Orleans. The play’s very successful run inspired us to produce a local playwrights’ group in New Orleans, composed primarily of people of color, women, and LGBTQIA writers (entering its second year). Kosmoski has also produced many plays, workshops, and festivals, including the Faster Than A Speeding Bullet Play Fest at the Allways Lounge Bar, featuring over 50 artists, in June 2018 (for more on Kosmoski's work: www.MeganKosmoski.com)

 

 

SOLITARY by Stephanie Garrison

Developed with Megan Kosmoski and Second Star Productions in New Orleans, 2016.

(Tablework in rehearsal. We developed the script over a 9 month period . SOLITARY had multiple readings and drafts before getting to production)

(In the rehearsal room, Garrison and Kosmoski worked together to create the world  of the play)

(Mike Spara and Leslie Boles Kraus in SOLITARY presented at Two for Tennessee part of the Tennessee Williams Literary Festival, 2016)

(Mike Spara and Leslie Boles Kraus in SOLITARY presented at Two for Tennessee part of the Tennessee Williams Literary Festival, 2016)

(Mike Spara and Leslie Boles Kraus in SOLITARY presented at Two for Tennessee part of the Tennessee Williams Literary Festival, 2016)

(Full house for SOLITARY presented at Two for Tennessee part of the Tennessee Williams Literary Festival, 2016)

(Garrett Prejean, Megan Kosmoski, Mike Spara, Leslie Boles Kraus, and Stephanie Garrison pre-show, SOLITARY presented at Two for Tennessee part of the Tennessee Williams Literary Festival, 2016)

story:
What is the Picher Project: 

The Picher Project, a new musical, explores abandoned mining town of Picher, Oklahoma through its 100 year history. The town that once was the largest producer of lead and zinc in the world became the EPA’s #1 Superfund site, deeming Picher the most toxic place in America. After native lands were mined out for years, leaving the earth damaged and causing other environmental and health crises to arise, Picher officially dissolved in 2013. Picher, a town that meant the world to its citizens, was founded and destroyed by the mining industry, leaving its population with no way to return home. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are attempting to raise $10,000 to fund the developmental process of our musical. Creating a musical is expensive: rehearsal space, supplies, time, expenses for residencies, performances, and actors all require some sort of funding. Our proposed breakdown is as follows:

40% - Developmental Workshop Process- including Residency, travel expenses, supplies, and space.

20% - Directly into Research and Dramaturgy, conducting further research and interviews

20% - Demos EP - creating a professional Demo EP

10% - Rehearsal Space 

10% - Website development, Branding Development, and Project relationships

The Impact

The Picher Project is more than just a musical, it’s a call to action. The environmental disasters that happened in Picher are not the first and surely won’t be the last. If we do not learn from our mistakes, how can we grow as a society? The Picher Team, after spending several months researching and writing, travelled to Northeast Oklahoma and Picher. Getting to see, firsthand, the true magnitude of what has happened there, and hear the stories of people who called Picher home, gave the project new meaning. While we are creating a musical, we hope to also be pushing our audiences to truly minimize the impact we have on the earth. By using art in conjunction with activism, we hope to continue to grow both our story and mission.

Risks & Challenges

The Picher Project has been working hard for nearly a year in their own free time to write and create this show. After all of that, and funding our own trip to Picher, we are seeking your help in the next steps of our developmental process. This funding will allow us to continue our work and bring the show to life early next year.  We are thrilled to be heading to Maine with a group of actors for a week-long residency to really focus on our script and musical arrangements. We plan to compensate our actors so they can take a week away from the city to work with us. The next step is a demo album, which we plan to fully record in New York. Additionally, on October 23rd, we will have a concert at Feinstein/54 Below. Finally, there will be a full production in New York early next year. Funding is necessary for each step along the way, and we hope you can help us make this all a reality.

Since our trip to Picher, we have received opportunities to bring our project to Maine, New Jersey, and back to Oklahoma to work on, and present our show. If we can keep working to produce the show next year, we eventually hope to bring the show back down to Oklahoma and present it for the community it was written about.

Other Ways You Can Help

We really hope you'll contribute... any amount can go a long way in aiding our process. If you cannot, we understand, but there are other ways to help!

First, we hope you'll share this Indiegogo Campaign on all of your social media platforms. Second, email our campaign to anyone who you know would be interested in our amazing show! 

Visit: https://thepicherproject.wixsite.com/thepicherproject

With so much love,

Quentin Madia, Lauren Pelaia, and Alex Knezevic

story:
The Story

At the risk of stating the obvious, the dance world is a small one. I've been lucky to have sustained relationships with performing artists whom I consider colleagues, mentors and friends. Many of them have crossed paths with each other. This is the roster of artists. You can read below to hear about how I know them.

  • Ellen Bartel (Austin, TX)
  • Erika Batdorf and Kate Digby (Toronto, Canada and Manhattan, Kansas)
  • Clarence Brooks and Michael Foley (Boca Raton and St.Petersburg, Florida/Paris, France)
  • Nina Haft and Company (Oakland, California)
  • Jessica Kondrath (Los Angeles, California)
  • Stephanie Liapis (Philadelphia, Pennsylvania)
  • Prometheus Dance (Boston, Massachusetts)

While a freshman at Bates College in 1994, I had the honor of performing in a piece choreographed by Bates Alum Michael Foley. Over the course of my four years at Bates, Michael came back several times to set work and teach class. Each of his visits to campus was so nourishing to my soul. I admired positive teaching and realize now the massive impact it had on my own style of teaching.

After graduation, I moved to Boston and started taking class with Tommy Neblett and Diane Arvanites at The Dance Complex. In 2001, I joined their company: Prometheus Dance. Dancing with Prometheus was the first time I felt part of a tribe - artists who were athletes, actors, poets - who poured their souls into the rehearsal process and were fierce performers.

In 2003, I was living in Berkeley, California when I started taking class at Shawl-Anderson Dance Center. It was there that I met Nina Haft and was introduced to her artistry and rejuvenating classes. I relish the intelligence and empathy in Nina's work.

In 2004 while visiting Austin, Texas, I attended a performance at Cafe Dance in which Ellen Bartel had a piece of choreography. It was a solo that resonated deeply with me, and I immediately started keeping tabs on her work from afar. This performance will be my third time presenting her work. 



In 2006, after moving to New York City, Kate Digby (who had been an acquaintance in Boston) invited me to audition for her company's residency at The Yard. A longer story would have a very interesting turn of events but suffice it to say that Kate did not select me yet I ended up joining the company a few months later and remained a member of her company for five years. It was during Kate's rehearsal process that I discovered where vulnerability can lead in the creative process. Her insights continue to shape my experiences both on and off the stage.

It was at the residency at The Yard where I met Erika Batdorf - Kate's guest and collaborator - when she worked with Digby Dance. Erika stripped away our dancerly ways and helped each of us discover our rawness, our authenticity...or as I think of it: "performing without acting." Erika is an arresting performer and such a gifted teacher.

As a dancer in NYC, it's a pretty common experience to find a teacher and stalk them. You follow them to wherever they teach, you work around your conflicts and find them. When I first moved to NYC, Stephanie Liapis was that teacher for me. I adore her energy, her movement, her taste in music, her deep plie. When I took her class and when I watched her perform, she reminded me of why I dance.

Similarly, as a dancer in NYC, it's often the case that you find fellow dancers who are doing the same things you are...at the same time...with lots of the same people. Jessica Kondrath and I took class alongside each other, rehearsed in studios adjacent to each other, sat in the audience at the same performances, taught classes at the same time, etc. Having peers in the dance world is crucial for support and professional development, and I have deep respect and appreciation for Jessica.

Finally, in March 2018 I had performances with Sokolow Theatre Dance Ensemble and Clarence Brooks was a Guest Artist. Once we met at rehearsal, we realized just how many mutual acquaintances we had. We traced so many different dance relationships and were amazed that we were just being introduced to one another. Clarence is a treasure - his generosity of spirit is unparalleled and his talent is astounding. Watching him dance is a privilege.

What We Need

The goal is to raise $5000.

  • I will be renting the theater for performances, technical and dress rehearsals and hosting a reception on stage after each performance. Funds will go towards this cost.
  • I would like to offer each performance group a small stipend of $500 to offset their travel and housing costs

What else....

Come to a performance!

  • Tickets are here: https://outoftowners2018.brownpapertickets.com
  • And share this Indiegogo campaign with friends and supporters: https://igg.me/at/outoftowners/x/5958886

story:
Hi! We’re Adin Lenahan and Barbara K Begley, and we’re playwrights, Kate Bush enthusiasts, and board members of the Brooklyn Arts Incubator Undiscovered Countries.

(With our fellow board members Kaela Mei-Shing Garvin and Alton Alburo. We're cute, right?)

For the last five years, Undiscovered Countries has supported new work from queer & marginalized artists through a free bimonthly show of in progress works, a Publishing department supporting writers, illustrators, and comic artists, and our Blast Off interdisciplinary development lab. This project, a collaboration with famed NYC arts presenter The Tank NYC, represents a brand new venture for us - a Double Feature Production of two full length works, both previously developed at Undiscovered Countries! 

We're raising funds to produce two exciting new shows - Adin's solo play Asher Rhys Got Married Too Young, and Barbara's deranged variety show MARYSHELLEYSHOW. Asher Rhys Got Married Too Young is the story of a man trying to hold onto his son while suffering the indignities of his psychic in laws. MARYSHELLEYSHOW is the story of teen genius Mary Shelley, noted sometime lesbian recluse Emily Dickinson, infamous sexy attention hog Lord Byron, and some human/horse hybrid children, as they try to create a family. 

Even though The Tank has generously given us the use of their theater space for free, we still need $3,500 to produce this show.

(Don't worry, Emily, that's in 2017 dollars, not 1817 dollars)

Here's where that money goes

$1,600 goes to pay our team. We are an Equity Showcase production which means that we are legally required by the union to pay performers, and we also believe that making theater is work, and that theater artists deserve to be paid for it.

$300 goes to a set and costume design by Shakhed Hadaya. We have a lot of pieces left over from MARYSHELLEYSHOW's run in Chicago, but Shakhed's got a lot of work ahead of her building the existing set into a fully transformative space where the extremely different worlds of MARYSHELLEYSHOW and Asher Rhys Got Married Too Young can coexist. 

$750 is for rehearsal space! This is what space costs for two full rehearsal processes in New York City (and in fact this is based on the cheapest bookings we can find.) If you are unable to donate monetarily but are able to loan us a 12' by 15' room in your apartment to make art in, give us a call (and see "in kind donations" towards the end of this campaign).

$250 goes to transportation - for getting performers located out of state to New York to do the show, and to get our set to The Tank for the production.

$600 goes to things like crowdfunding fees, marketing costs like printing postcards and programs, and emergencies - if something breaks, if something gets lost, if the New York City Subway all shuts down the day of the show and everyone needs separate cabs to the theater - this is our cushion for acts of God. 

We're so excited to bring these plays to you, and if you come, this is what you'll see! 

ASHER RHYS GOT MARRIED TOO YOUNG is a sort of modern epistolary, written and performed by Adin Lenahan. This multi-generational tale is told in layers: Rott Mellevold goes on a conspiracy theory podcast to refute rumors that his wealthy family are secretly psychic healers; Asher Rhys leaves voicemails for his friend (over a period of 20 years) mostly concerning his psychic in-laws The Mellevolds, his partner Lukas & their son Rott; and Lukas' mother and father have intimate conversations with their son (both before and after his death) in an effort to understand his past and justify their present. But primarily it is the story of Asher, who marries Lukas at 18, is a widower at 28, and spends his thirties trying to hold on to his son Rott. A fable of parenthood, sacrifice, and forgiveness.

MARYSHELLEYSHOW is a variety show presented by dirtbag teenage geniuses  Mary Shelley and Emily Dickinson, as they struggle with friendship, loneliness, the stresses of parenting, the slipperiness of fame and historical importance, and the desire to host one damned party without Lord Byron messing it all up. It has musical performances and dance numbers and poetry readings, and it's acerbic and dirty and absurd with a big pained mushy heart. MARYSHELLEYSHOW played to enthusiastic  houses at local Maine legend The Theater Project and at the Chicago Fringe Festival in 2016, but it has never been produced in New York City.

This is the first full NYC production of either of these shows, and Undiscovered Countries's first time producing two shows in conversation with each other. Help us make these shows a reality, and you'll be helping bring exciting, new queer theater to a new level.

In addition to this towering, glittery cake of theater majesty, by supporting us you'll get some cool perks as our way of thanking you! Check the sidebar for details. 

Any contribution helps - $10 gets us an hour of rehearsal space, $20 gets us a costume, $50 gets us half of a stage, $100 pays for an actor stipend. We would love your support in any way possible, if you can't give to the project we'd love to see you in our audience at The Tank on October 24th and 25th (ticket link coming soon!).  Thanks for your support!

xoxo, Barbara and Adin (and Emily Dickinson and Rott Mellevold)

story:
Who We Are!

This summer we are producing Much Ado About Nothing and all its wit, romance, and mayhem, set in the electric 1970s. Much Ado About Nothing runs from July 29 to August 13 at the Performance Works Outdoor Stage on Granville Island. We are hoping to raise $2,600 to help cover production and program costs. This is where you come in! Help us continue to make this amazing program free for the audience and affordable for the participants.

What Do We Do?

What does it mean to support the Teen Shakespeare Program (TSP) and who does it affect? Every summer, CTYP opens its doors to 16 vibrant, unique and talented teen actors’ ages 13-18 who have a passion for Shakespeare and performance.

Led by Head Instructor Mike Stack, students embark on an intensive pre-professional training process where they build not only skills that will carry them forward in the professional theatre industry, but skills that they will carry with them throughout their lives. The program builds confidence, teamwork and communication skills and fosters a strong sense of community.

“…watching them both with highlighters and pencils marking their scripts so painstakingly is the most beautiful and incredible sight for us. I think it is so important that we give each child something to feel good about themselves for – something to shine at – and drama is what Carousel has given my boys. “ 

                                                                                                     -  Parent of TSP Participants

The program culminates in a two-week run of the production at the Performance Works Outdoor Stage on famed Granville Island where the actors learn about the joys, challenges, and surprises that come along with performing outdoors for a live audience. In 26 years, over 500 youth have come through the program and made Shakespeare a part of their summer.

For the Teen Shakespeare Program, the Bard’s comedies, tragedies and histories are not the stuffy domain of highbrow academics. Whether you are 2 or 92, a professor of English Lit or someone who doesn’t know who Shakespeare is, TSP productions are accessible to all. We are dedicated to providing high quality Shakespeare interpretations that highlight the talent and accomplishments of young people in our community while being free for everyone to enjoy. 

“Starting out in Hamlet, I was nervous even for our first read-through, stumbling over the words and meter. Now, I am confident on stage performing Shakespeare.”

                                                                          -  Laura Reynolds, Former TSP Participant

Bursaries are available to support students with demonstrated financial aid and each year, a merit-based scholarship is awarded to a participant who is going on to pursue a post-secondary education in theatre or anything else! Actors, scientists, and politicians alike represent where Teen Shakespeare alumni find their calling but it is their love of theatre, ignited by TSP, that unites each and every one of them.

2015 recipient of the Teen Shakespeare Program Scholarship Laura Reynolds with Artistic Director Carole Higgins

Number Crunching the Teen Shakespeare Program

Expenses

Set $2,500

Props $500

Costumes $3,500

Lighting, Sound $1,000

Theatre Rental $7,050

Scholarships & Bursaries $2,200

Instruction& Program Management $23,000

Marketing $8,500

Concession $1,500

TOTAL: $49,750

Revenues

Tuition $11,600

Reserved Seating $2,000

Concession $2,500

Grants $30,200

TOTAL: $46,300

DIFFERENCE: $3,450

Help us move from the red to the black!

2014 recipient of the Teen Shakespeare Program Scholarship Sofia Bunting-Newman with parents (foreground), Artistic Director Carole Higgins, Head Instructor Mike Stack and Assistant Instructor Melissa Oei

Fun Facts!

# of participants over 26 years: 520

#of audience members over 25 years: 152,000 +

Scholarships and Bursaries Awarded: $6,000 + in the last ten years

# of rehearsal hours per year: 150 (and this doesn’t include all the work the actors do at home!)

# of volunteer hours: 7,500+

# of hot chocolates poured: 5,000+

# of geese intermissions: 1  ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gl8fGonIgvM )

Inaugural recipient of the Teen Shakespeare Program Scholarship Seamus Fera (centre) with Teaching Artists (L-R) Mike Stack, Carole Higgins and Melissa Oei and the cast of The Teen Shakespeare Program 2013: Hamlet

Risks, Challenges, and FAQ

What happens if we don`t reach our goal? As the old proverb goes, the show must go on. The show is slated to run but your contribution will help CTYP take the program and production to the next level. Your support allows us to provide bursaries and scholarships to current and future students and continue the long tradition of FREE Teen Shakespeare performances for years to come.

Why don’t you just raise the cost of tuition? One of our key values is that the program should be accessible to all youth in Metro Vancouver no matter what their family’s financial circumstances are. We have been so lucky to have had a wide variety of participants from all over the Lower Mainland - from West Van to Coquitlam. Rising production costs and the importance of maintaining a high quality experience for participants and audiences necessitated a small increase in tuition in 2014, and we don’t want to raise the tuition any more. In the coming years we want to make the program even more accessible, and our dream is to make it free for every participant!

Why don’t you just charge for tickets? As ticket prices around us rise, CTYP wants to ensure that everyone has access to live theatre. Theatre brings communities together and we believe that every person should be able to experience it. A few years ago, to make it more convenient for our audience, we introduced pre-reserved seats for a nominal $5 reservation fee. We also offer seat cushions and blanket rentals by donation as well as run a concession which has drinks, hot dogs and other treats. But at the end of the day, it is crucial to us that show remains free for audiences to attend.

Will I get a tax receipt? If you donate through Indiegogo we are unable to issue you a tax receipt. If you would like one, please feel free to donate directly to CTYP at https://tickets.carouseltheatre.ca/TheatreManager/1/logindonation=0

I can’t afford to donate…What can I do? We work in the arts – we get it. If you are unable to donate financially, there are other ways you can help support us. You can:

 A) VOLUNTEER- the TSP village runs through the hard and generous work of an amazing team of volunteers and we are always looking for more help. Sign up here: www.carouseltheatre.ca/about-carousel-theatre/volunteer/shift-signup/

B) Pass it along- We know that not everyone can donate but that someone might know a great-great aunt in Tulsa or have an in with our next celebrity guest. E-mail, Share, Like, and Repost @Carouseltheatre with #TSP2016

C ) Come see the show. Without an audience, our show will just be a bunch of talented teens hanging out in a park. The audience is who brings theatre to life. We run from July 29th-August 13th at the Performance Works Outdoor Stage on Granville Island, Vancouver BC. Reserve seats in advance for $5 or just, well, show up! It’s free!

When do I get my perks? The campaign ends on July 30th which is our opening night so expect your perks in the mail by August 10th. You will be mentioned and thanked on social media within 72 hours of your donation. If your chosen perks involve complimentary tickets to the show, we ask that you book 24 hours before your chosen performance so that will can ensure you get the best seats possible!

Can the Perks be shipped internationally? If you are donating from afar, please let us know at the time of your donation. Video thank you’s will be distributed online. Tangible perks like printed photos and signed posters can be shipped across Canada and the USA. Shippable perks for donations of $250 or more can be sent internationally

Can I give after the campaign ends? We will never turn down donations. You can continue to donate at every performance of TSP from July 29th-August 13th and you can even donate year round on our website- https://tickets.carouseltheatre.ca/TheatreManager/1/logindonation=0

How can I audition for the program? If you are or know a teen who loves Shakespeare and theatre you may be interested in joining the TSP family. Auditions are in January for actors ages 13-18. Click here to sign up for our mailing list to get notifications on auditions. (http://visitor.r20.constantcontact.com/d.jsp?llr=4eitmfcab&p=oi&m=1101840097439&sit=zhvlbgwcb&f=20eb190e-71e8-432d-a94c-a158abbf9492)

Thank you for your generous donations and welcome to the CTYP family!
story_txt:
Who We Are!


This summer we are producing Much Ado About Nothing and all
its wit, romance, and mayhem, set in the electric 1970s. Much Ado About Nothing
runs from July 29 to August 13 at the Performance Works Outdoor Stage on
Granville Island. We are hoping to raise $2,600 to help cover production and program
costs. This is where you come in! Help us continue to make this amazing program
free for the audience and affordable for the participants. 



What Do We Do?
What does it mean to support the Teen Shakespeare Program (TSP) and who does it
affect? Every summer, CTYP opens its doors to 16 vibrant, unique and talented
teen actors’ ages 13-18 who have a passion for Shakespeare and performance.
Led by Head Instructor Mike Stack, students embark on an intensive
pre-professional training process where they build not only skills that will
carry them forward in the professional theatre industry, but skills that they will carry with them throughout their lives. The program builds confidence, teamwork and communication skills and fosters a strong sense of community. 

“…watching them both with highlighters and pencils
marking their scripts so painstakingly is the most beautiful and incredible
sight for us. I think it is so important that we give each child something to
feel good about themselves for – something to shine at – and drama is what
Carousel has given my boys. “ 


                                                                                                     -  Parent of TSP
Participants 
The program culminates in a two-week run of the production at the
Performance Works Outdoor Stage on famed Granville Island where the actors learn about the joys,
challenges, and surprises that come along with performing outdoors for a live audience. In 26 years,
over 500 youth have come through the program and made Shakespeare a part of
their summer.
For the Teen Shakespeare Program, the Bard’s comedies,
tragedies and histories are not the stuffy domain of highbrow academics. Whether
you are 2 or 92, a professor of English Lit or someone who doesn’t know who
Shakespeare is, TSP productions are accessible to all. We are dedicated to
providing high quality Shakespeare interpretations that highlight the talent
and accomplishments of young people in our community while being free for
everyone to enjoy.  

“Starting
out in Hamlet, I was nervous even for our first read-through, stumbling over
the words and meter. Now, I am confident on stage performing Shakespeare.”

                                                                          - 
Laura Reynolds, Former TSP Participant
Bursaries are available to support students
with demonstrated financial aid and each year, a merit-based scholarship is awarded to a participant who is going on to pursue a
post-secondary education in theatre or anything else! Actors, scientists, and
politicians alike represent where Teen Shakespeare alumni find their calling but
it is their love of theatre, ignited by TSP, that unites each and every one of
them. 



2015 recipient of the Teen Shakespeare Program Scholarship Laura Reynolds with Artistic Director Carole Higgins
Number Crunching the Teen
Shakespeare Program



Expenses
Set $2,500
Props $500
Costumes
$3,500
Lighting,
Sound $1,000
Theatre
Rental $7,050
Scholarships
& Bursaries $2,200
Instruction&
Program Management $23,000
Marketing
$8,500
Concession
$1,500
TOTAL: $49,750
Revenues
Tuition
$11,600
Reserved
Seating $2,000
Concession
$2,500
Grants
$30,200
TOTAL: $46,300

DIFFERENCE: $3,450
Help us move from the red to the black!


2014 recipient of the Teen Shakespeare Program Scholarship Sofia Bunting-Newman with parents (foreground), Artistic Director Carole Higgins, Head Instructor Mike Stack and Assistant Instructor Melissa Oei
Fun Facts!
# of participants over 26 years: 520
#of audience members over 25 years: 152,000 +
Scholarships and Bursaries Awarded: $6,000 + in
the last ten years
# of rehearsal hours per year: 150 (and this doesn’t include
all the work the actors do at home!)
# of volunteer hours: 7,500+
# of hot chocolates poured: 5,000+
# of geese intermissions: 1 
( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gl8fGonIgvM
)


Inaugural recipient of the Teen Shakespeare Program Scholarship Seamus Fera (centre) with Teaching Artists (L-R) Mike Stack, Carole Higgins and Melissa Oei and the cast of The Teen Shakespeare Program 2013: Hamlet


Risks, Challenges,
and FAQ
What happens if we
don`t reach our goal? As the old proverb goes, the show must go on. The
show is slated to run but your contribution will help CTYP take the program and
production to the next level. Your support allows us to provide bursaries and scholarships to current and future students and continue the long tradition of FREE Teen Shakespeare performances for years to
come. 
Why don’t you just
raise the cost of tuition? One of our key values is that the
program should be accessible to all youth in Metro Vancouver no matter what
their family’s financial circumstances are. We have been so lucky to have had a
wide variety of participants from all over the Lower Mainland - from West Van to
Coquitlam. Rising production costs and the importance of maintaining a high quality experience for participants and audiences necessitated a small increase in tuition in 2014, and we don’t want to raise the
tuition any more. In the coming years we want to make the program even more
accessible, and our dream is to make it free for every participant! 
Why don’t you just
charge for tickets? As ticket prices around us
rise, CTYP wants to ensure that everyone has access to live theatre. Theatre brings
communities together and we believe that every person should be able to experience it. A few years ago, to make it more convenient for our audience, we introduced pre-reserved seats for a nominal $5 reservation
fee. We also offer seat cushions and blanket rentals by donation as well as run a
concession which has drinks, hot dogs and other treats. But at the end of the
day, it is crucial to us that show remains free for audiences to attend.
Will I get a tax
receipt? If you donate through Indiegogo we are unable to
issue you a tax receipt. If you would like one, please feel free to donate directly
to CTYP at https://tickets.carouseltheatre.ca/TheatreManager/1/logindonation=0
I
can’t afford to donate…What can I do? We work in the arts – we get it. If you are unable to donate
financially, there are other ways you can help support us. You can:
 A) VOLUNTEER- the TSP village runs through the
hard and generous work of an amazing team of volunteers and we are always
looking for more help. Sign up here: www.carouseltheatre.ca/about-carousel-theatre/volunteer/shift-signup/


B) Pass it along- We know that not everyone can donate but
that someone might know a great-great aunt in Tulsa or have an in with our next
celebrity guest. E-mail, Share, Like, and Repost @Carouseltheatre with #TSP2016
C ) Come see the show. Without an audience, our show will
just be a bunch of talented teens hanging out in a park. The audience is who
brings theatre to life. We run from July 29th-August 13th
at the Performance Works Outdoor Stage on Granville Island, Vancouver BC.
Reserve seats in advance for $5 or just, well, show up! It’s free!
When do I get my
perks? The campaign ends on July 30th which is our opening night
so expect your perks in the mail by August 10th. You will be mentioned
and thanked on social media within 72 hours of your donation. If your chosen
perks involve complimentary tickets to the show, we ask that you book 24 hours
before your chosen performance so that will can ensure you get the best seats
possible!
Can the Perks be
shipped internationally? If you are donating from afar, please let us know
at the time of your donation. Video thank you’s will be distributed online. Tangible
perks like printed photos and signed posters can be shipped across Canada and
the USA. Shippable perks for donations of $250 or more can be sent
internationally
Can I give after the
campaign ends? We will never turn down donations. You can continue to
donate at every performance of TSP from July 29th-August 13th
and you can even donate year round on our website- https://tickets.carouseltheatre.ca/TheatreManager/1/logindonation=0
How
can I audition for the program? If you are or
know a teen who loves Shakespeare and theatre you may be interested in joining
the TSP family. Auditions are in January for actors ages 13-18. Click here to
sign up for our mailing list to get notifications on auditions. (http://visitor.r20.constantcontact.com/d.jsp?llr=4eitmfcab&p=oi&m=1101840097439&sit=zhvlbgwcb&f=20eb190e-71e8-432d-a94c-a158abbf9492) 
Thank you for your generous donations and welcome to the
CTYP family!

story:
The Women Who Mapped The Stars has been in development for a year, and we need your help to get to the next step!

Before we jump into our world premiere production next season at Central Square Theater, our script need to go through a crucial process. Central Square Theater in partnership with The Poets' Theatre are hosting a WORKSHOP PRODUCTION of The Women Who Mapped The Stars this spring. This is our first chance to explore the play in three-dimensional space, and see how movement, lights, sound, and projections can be used to tell this story. It allows us to see the script in new ways and refine it even further. 

In order to successfully complete this crucial step, we need your help. This workshop production is a more intensive process than a reading, and it is separate from the world premiere. To fund it, we will need a total of $15,000. Can you help us get there? Draft by draft, rehearsal by rehearsal, we're going to spend the next year discovering the best way to tell this story. The process begins on May 14, and with your contribution, this workshop production will launch us towards the final product!

UPDATE: 4/29

EXCITING NEWS!

We are thrilled to report that a generous donor has offered to DOUBLE MATCH any donations up to a total of $5,000! Whether you have pitched in already or have been waiting for the right moment, your donation will go even farther. Your $10 will turn into $30, your $100 into $300, or your $1,000 into $3,000.

This allows us to lower our total IndieGoGo goal to $5,000 - because if we hit that number here, this donor will turn it into $15,000 and we will have officially FULLY FUNDED the workshop production of The Women Who Mapped The Stars! 

We've got 20 days left, friends - spread the word and let's meet our goal! Thanks for being a part of our journey.

 

What have we done so far? 

  • Learned a ton of science and history
  • Written a play
  • Had one workshop
  • Got snowed out of the original date for our staged reading (#newenglandproblems)
  • (Finally) Performed a staged reading to a sold-out house at Central Square Theater on 4/17

 

What’s next?

  • A workshop production! That's what this campaign is for!
  • More research, rewriting, exploration, and workshopping.
  • A WORLD PREMIERE at Central Square Theater, April 19, 2018-May 20, 2018. Check out the whole season here!

 

With your help, we’ll be able to make this workshop a rousing success. New play development, just like science, is a team effort. It takes a dedicated team of actors, designers, producers, technicians, helpers, and advisors to turn an idea into a play. Their talents and time deserve compensation, because artistic work is real work. Creating a play where there wasn’t one before also requires other resources - projectors need to be rented in order to show you the stars, scripts need to be printed, historical props need to be created.

We’ve embarked on this adventure for one simple reason - this story matters. Mina, Antonia, Annie, Henrietta, and Cecilia are only a few of the women, past and present, whose stories have been kept in the shadows. Theatre and science are two of the most effective tools we have for shining light into those dark spaces. What have we been missing, in history and in space? How much will our universe grow if we keep looking? How much more will we discover if we remove the barriers that keep brilliant minds from achieving their potential? This is a story about breaking down these social and scientific barriers. There is still more progress to make towards equity and more discoveries on the horizon. 


Whether you pitch in $10 or $1000, you can become an invaluable part of bringing this play to life. In The Women Who Mapped The Stars, Cecilia talks about her research as “building a bridge out of [her] own body through the fog to the other side.” When you want to create something new, you have to take a leap of faith. You have to start building that bridge into the fog before you know what’s on the other side. Cecilia found the true makeup of the universe on the other side of her bridge. We’re starting to get a glimpse of the other side of ours, and there’s an inspiring, innovative, and exciting new play over there. Help us build the rest of the bridge - help us get there. Support The Women Who Mapped The Stars today!

 

Learn more about science, history, and how an idea becomes a play! Follow along here:
https://starmappers.wordpress.com

Check out our amazing cast and design team - the people who will bring this workshop to life!
https://starmappers.wordpress.com/cast-and-crea...

story:
We are the creators of the Monologando Contando Ando festival, with which we seek to open spaces for the Latino community in New York City, in addition to raising funds for the artistic work of our theater company.
For seven years we are working on art and culture, with their support we will raise funds to hold Festival Monologando Contando Ando.
The people who help us to realize this dream, will have their names written in our programs as Angeles.
With your contribution will make a culture open to the entire Latino community in New York.
We need 4,000 dollars to assume in some the expenses that the event Monologando Contando Ando requires.
Cost of theater and other.
Art with a purpose, help! Is our motto,
God bless you.

Somos los creadores del festival de Monólogos  Monologando Contando Ando, con el cual buscamos  abrir espacios para la comunidad Latina en la ciudad de New York, además reunir fondos para el trabajo artistico de nuestra compañia teatral.

Desde hace siete años estamos trabajando el arte y la cultura, con su apoyo recolectaremos fondos para realizar Festival Monologando Contando  Ando.

Las personas que nos ayude a realizar este sueño, tendrán su nombres escritos en nuestro programas como Angeles.

Con tu aporte hará una cultura abierta a toda la comunidad Latina en New York. 

Necesitamos 4,000 Dolores para asumir en algo los gastos que el evento Monologando  Contando Ando requiere.

Costo del teatro y predication. 

El arte con un propósito, ayudar! es nuestro lema,

Dios lo bendiga.
