story:
"MY NAME IS RACHEL CORRIE": a fundraising appeal for the Winnipeg MayWorks launch of the critically acclaimed stage play

MayWorks Winnipeg is a multi-disciplinary festival, which focuses on the relationship between working class issues and their artistic expression in song, poetry, photography, dance, art and drama.

As part of this year’s annual festival, MayWorks is pleased to premiere the Winnipeg production of the internationally renowned play, “MY NAME IS RACHEL CORRIE” — drawn from the diaries of American activist and International Solidarity Movement member, Rachel Corrie, and edited by actor Alan Rickman & journalist Katherine Viner.

OUR FUNDRAISING GOALS AND WHY IT'S IMPORTANT THAT YOU DONATE

In connection with May 2016’s play launch, MayWorks Festival of Labour and Arts is now seeking donations in support of the successful premiere of “My Name Is Rachel Corrie” — donations, collected to offset many critical production costs, including: actors’ wages, set design expenses, venue rental fees, promotion and other miscellaneous items.

The production history of “My Name is Rachel Corrie” — from its initial 2005 London staging, to its infamous 2006 New York cancellations — has in the past been mired in controversy and opposition owing to some of its political content in respect of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

In the spirit of artistic expression, freedom of speech and the spirit of Rachel herself (who was killed in the protection and service of vulnerable Palestinian peoples), we are asking you to donate what you can towards MayWorks’ successful launch of Rachel’s life story.

We have established a fundraising goal of $7,500.00 (CAD), which, with your generosity and commitment to festivals and works which speak to the relationship between working peoples and the arts, is tenable over the course of the next 4 weeks.

Our performances of “My Name is Rachel Corrie” are scheduled for May 5, 6, 7, 13 and 14, 2016 at Winnipeg’s Irish Association of Manitoba. All shows directed by Andraea Sartison of One Trunk Theatre, with a cast that includes: Gwendolyn Collins, Heather Russell, Gislina Patterson, Liz Whitbread, Brittany Thiessen and Erin Shwartz.

For details on our 5 scheduled performances of “My Name is Rachel Corrie,” please visit: www.mayworks.org or on Facebook by searching "My Name is Rachel Corrie: Winnipeg MayWorks 2016."

ABOUT “MY NAME IS RACHEL CORRIE” AND RACHEL CORRIE HERSELF

"MY NAME IS RACHEL CORRIE" — From the journals of Rachel Corrie as edited by actor Alan Rickman and journalist Katherine Viner • Directed by Andrea Sartison • Performed by: Gwendolyn Collins, Heather Russell, Gislina Patterson, Liz Whitbread, Brittany Thiessen and Erin Shwartz • Presented with the assistance of the Tara Players Theatre Company and the Irish Association of Manitoba.

RACHEL ALIENE CORRIE (April 10, 1979 – March 16, 2003) was an American Evergreen State College student and member of the International Solidarity Movement (ISM) who traveled to the Gaza Strip during the Second Intifada. She was killed by a Caterpillar D9R armoured bulldozer operated by the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) while protesting the destruction of a house by the IDF in the Gaza Strip — apparently acting as a human shield. The details of the events surrounding Rachel's death, as she stood between an Israeli bulldozer and a Palestinian home are disputed. While an Israeli military investigation ruled the death to be an accident, the ISM maintains that Rachel was run over deliberately. In 2012, The Haifa District Court, in a lawsuit filed by Rachel's parents, ruled that her death was an accident, and rejected the claim that Israel was at fault over Rachel’s death.

The play's script is taken from excepts of Rachel’s journals and correspondence over the last decade of her life. The picture it paints is of a young woman with a "fire in her belly" — an unquenchable thirst for justice, for hope and a poignant belief that a single person can change the world. She is both ordinary and extraordinary, a regular American genX-er, yet set aside from her generation because of her talent and worldview.

Director Andraea Sartison (One Trunk Theatre) uniquely stages this one woman show with an ensemble of top Winnipeg performers encapsulating the many sides to Rachel Corrie. Debuting at Mayworks Festival of Labour and the Arts 2016.

“...Theatre has no obligation to give a complete picture. Its only duty is to be honest. And what you get here is a stunning account of one woman's passionate response to a particular situation.

And the passion comes blazing through in Corrie's eloquent reaction to her father's inquiry about Palestinian violence. As she says, if we lived where tanks and soldiers and bulldozers could destroy our homes at any moment and where our lives were completely strangled, wouldn't we defend ourselves as best we could?..”— Michael Billington, The Guardian (2005)

ABOUT “MY NAME IS RACHEL CORRIE” AND RACHEL CORRIE HERSELF"MY NAME IS RACHEL CORRIE" — From the journals of Rachel Corrie as edited by actor Alan
Rickman and journalist Katherine Viner • Directed by Andrea Sartison • Performed by:
Gwendolyn Collins, Heather Russell, Gislina Patterson, Liz Whitbread, Brittany Thiessen and Erin Shwartz • Presented with the assistance of the Tara Players Theatre
Company and the Irish Association of Manitoba.
RACHEL ALIENE CORRIE (April 10, 1979 – March 16, 2003)
was an American Evergreen State College student and member of the International Solidarity Movement (ISM) who traveled to the Gaza Strip during the Second Intifada. She was killed by a Caterpillar D9R armoured bulldozer operated by the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) while protesting the destruction
of a house by the IDF in the Gaza Strip — apparently acting as a human shield.
The details of the events surrounding Rachel's death, as she stood between an
Israeli bulldozer and a Palestinian home are disputed. While an Israeli military investigation
ruled the death to be an accident, the ISM maintains that Rachel was run over
deliberately. In 2012, The Haifa District Court, in a lawsuit filed by Rachel's parents, ruled that her death was an accident, and rejected the claim that
Israel was at fault over Rachel’s death.
The play's script is taken from excepts of Rachel’s journals and
correspondence over the last decade of her life. The picture it paints is of a
young woman with a "fire in her belly" — an unquenchable thirst for
justice, for hope and a poignant belief that a single person can change
the world. She is both ordinary and extraordinary, a regular
American genX-er, yet set aside from her generation because of
her talent and worldview.
Director Andraea Sartison (One Trunk Theatre) uniquely
stages this one woman show with an ensemble of top Winnipeg performers
encapsulating the many sides to Rachel Corrie. Debuting at Mayworks Festival of
Labour and the Arts 2016.
“...Theatre has no obligation to give a complete picture.
Its only duty is to be honest. And what you get here is a stunning account of
one woman's passionate response to a particular situation.
And the passion comes blazing through in Corrie's
eloquent reaction to her father's inquiry about Palestinian violence. As she
says, if we lived where tanks and soldiers and bulldozers could destroy our
homes at any moment and where our lives were completely strangled, wouldn't we
defend ourselves as best we could?..”— Michael Billington, The Guardian (2005)

story:
Who are we?

Combining the artistic visions of Manchester based visual artist, Howl Creative, and Leeds based companies, LSMarley and Brink Dance Company, “Howl” is a collaborative project that aims to create engaging, socially conscious and communicative art that represents modern day youth culture and speaks for the young people of today. More information can be found on each of the organisations here:

 

https://www.facebook.com/howlcreative.uk/

https://www.facebook.com/Brinkdanceco/

https://www.facebook.com/LSMarley1/

 

Through a continuous creative relationship Brink Dance Company and Howl Creative have investigated the collaboration between visual and performance art inspired by personal interests in rave and youth subcultures. After successfully applying to the SHINE Emerging Artists programme and receiving a small cash bursary, the collaborators were provided the opportunity to exhibit at Light Night Leeds and Lightwaves Festival, Manchester.

 

Meeting at the company’s research and development residential, LSMarley and his unique compositional soundscapes became the third artistic voice of Howl, providing an otherworldly and experimental depth to the work, whilst capturing the music trends of youth culture today.

 

We are launching a crowdfunding campaign to ensure the highest quality of work can be produced, therefore we are in need of specialist equipment to achieve this aim. Contributors donations will enable us to create this thrilling, engaging and powerful experience for our audiences.

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

As stated above, the main reason we are crowdfunding is so we can purchase specialised equipment for the installation. This equipment is as follows:

 

High quality PA system for LSMarley’s music that can handle heavy bass.

Mesh screen that allows the animation to be projected onto but also allows the dancers to be seen behind.

High quality projector for the animation.

 

Fortunately, we have been supported through the SHINE bursary, so our fundraising target is £750 (although, if we do raise more than this, this means we’ll be able to invest in other things such as costumes, which currently the dancers are sourcing themselves).

 

However, we don’t want to just take your money and not give you anything in return! Below is our list of perks for when you donate a certain amount:

 

£5 – You get a personalised thank you across Brink Dance Company’s social media

£15 – You receive a signed photo of the artists involved

£30 – You receive a copy of rehearsal footage taken from our residency at the HopBarn in Newark.

 

The Impact

 

Without people’s contributions, the art will not reach its fullest potential in creating the best and most enriching experiences for its audiences. The equipment we need to make this possible is essential to the final outcome of our work and we know any contributions will greatly support the integrity and quality of the piece.

 

We want to ensure the work speaks true for the younger generations whilst bringing people together through an intimate and exciting experience. Through our chosen mediums, we hope to encourage more people to engage with contemporary art and use our artistic vision to celebrate young people and human experiences. It is very rare that art takes into full consideration the reality of young people, and this is a real opportunity to develop a new generation of interest in socially conscious, high quality art. If the experience is not as good as we hope it to be, we risk missing out on this audience and fully communicating our message as creatives.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

We appreciate that not everyone has money to spare. While we value donations of any amount, we would also massively appreciate it if you shared this campaign across your own networks on our behalf.

 

Also, as part of this campaign we will be running a number of fundraising activities, so if you feel you’d rather not just donate, but want an experience to go along with it, then please check out our events! To find out more about these we will be shouting about them here:

 

@howl_creative

@brinkdancecompany

 

Thank you for taking the time to read this, and thank you in advance for any support you can give us.

 

The “Howl” Creative team

story:
Vertigo is determined to increase our shows’ accessibility. Attending these shows and engaging in this art should not be exclusive—we believe that any inaccessibility to our space would thoroughly defeat the point of our work. It is for that reason that Vertigo has developed the following goals:

  • Vertigo aspires to have free admission to all shows.

We are extremely aware of the financial difficulties many students and young people on our campus face. We are an economically diverse community, and we firmly believe that a student’s financial situation should not prevent them from engaging in the new art on this campus. Vertigo plans to eliminate our admission fees so that we can increase the attendance to our shows and expand our audience to include those who may not have been able to see this kind of theatre before.

  • Vertigo aspires to have ASL interpreters present at our shows.

We believe that ableism is one of the most overlooked problems currently facing our campus in general, and in the theatre community. We have seen firsthand the ways in which students with physical disabilities have been excluded from Northwestern experiences, including the artistic experiences that others have taken for granted. Vertigo wants everyone to be a part of the evolution of our work and the new pieces that we bring to campus, and so we plan to employ interpreters who can help us make the words accessible to everyone.

  • Vertigo aspires to utilize text projections and improve accessibility to our venues and special events.

Throughout our season, Vertigo has made it a priority to engage the community in workshops, staged readings, and events happening in Chicago. We want to make sure that not a single student at Northwestern is unable to be physically present in these spaces, or to be included in the topics being presented or the work being shared. Every voice on this campus counts. Every voice on this campus matters, and we want to increase the accessibility that marginalized voices have to our space, and that our spaces and community in turn have to them.

HOW YOU CAN HELP:

Vertigo Productions will be running this Indiegogo campaign on this year’s Giving Tuesday (November 29th) to compensate for the losses we will face once we begin implementing our Accessibility Mission. We intend to execute this plan right away for our Winter Reading Series. This fundraiser will allow us to have a budget allocated to the hiring of interpreters, increasing accessibility to our spaces, in addition to free admission for our shows. 

 

Vertigo has set our sights on a fundraising goal of $3000. This budget will make it so that we are able to have accessible, free shows throughout the rest of the year. The number of students we would be able to engage in a rich variety of new work through the execution of this plan would be staggering, and we feel very strongly that doing so would fulfill our mission to be an organization that is dedicated to improving our community through art and the uplifting of new voices.

 

We are hoping to partner with other organizations to circulate this campaign and reach a broader donating pool—especially those who have a yearly income and are not full-time students. Of course we anticipate that the student body will be contributing to our campaign, but we hope to expand our reach of donors. Organizations who partner with us will be credited in each of our productions/events that benefit from these changes, and we would be overjoyed to find additional ways to reciprocate through a mutually beneficial relationship.

story:
Short Summary

The Arkadina Project is one of the few shows that have been selected for the 2016 International Fringe Theatre Festival. FringeNYC, the largest multi-arts festival in North America, will present the 20th Annual Festival from August 16 – 27, 2016. 

TAP is a comedy so dark you'll feel guilty for laughing so hard. With high-tech elements such as live go-pro performances, actors lit entirely by cell phones, and a set dressed with projections the audience is sure to forget this was once considered a classic.This hilarious, high-tech modernization of Anton Chekhov’s “The Seagull”  follows Kostya, Nina and Masha on their struggles with celebrity obsession, unrequited love and parental suffocation.  Sex Scandals, Sell Outs, and Smirnoff. But no Seagull. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise at least $3500 for this project. All the proceeds that have been so generously donated to us will go into making this show truly spectacular (i.e. sets, electronic equipment, salaries, etc.)! Every year, the NYC Fringe festival receives thousands of plays, and we are fortunate enough to be one of the proud few who have made it in. THIS IS A BIG DEAL!!!

In addition to getting a warm fuzzy feeling after you realize you've contributed to what critics have called "The next Hamlet" (source not found), for a donation of $25 or more, your generous contribution would be highlighted by:

·  Featured recognition in playbills

·  Premium reserved tickets and seating

·  Arkadina Project Memorabilia


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, that's totally fine! Just follow us on all the social media and share our journey with family and friends. The greatest marketing tool we have is you guys! And, of course, be sure to check out the show at The New York City International Fringe Festival August 16-27. We look forward to seeing you!

story:
Our Story

Rogue Theatre Company began with two actors who wanted to create risky, compelling, and thought-provoking theatre in Toronto. It has evolved into a dream of building a community and network of like-minded individuals, and, out of that, supporting and nurturing each other's works and skills. Diana Bentley and Brooke Morgan are ambitious, driven young women who have spent the past several years studying in New York and London and have arrived back in Toronto to become a force in the bustling scene here. 

After the success of their one-act play "DEUCE" at the Lab Cab Theater festival this past September, they began their quest finding a play to really sink their teeth into. Reasons to Be Pretty came into their hands after much searching and debate. It is a guts-out, heart-ripping, fireball show that opens the door for you to reflect on your own betrayals, fights with lovers -- and the work you put into looking good before you walk out the door every morning. It is everything they hoped for: a story about really hearing and really listening, and about the power of words and the stories we tell ourselves and others to make "sense of it all."

When the idea of the show quickly turned into a plan of attack, they began discussions on locations. Many trips to galleries and studios later, they spoke with Jamie Webster, a member of the N/A Collective, a not-for-profit studio space for artists located on Dundas West, who graciously offered up his space for the dates of the run. It had become clear that this was going to be the beginning of exploring unusual venues for their work. It is a deliciously, gritty, re-done space that allows the opportunity to avoid the old "the actors are on a stage and I watch them" pattern, and to make sure that Reasons to Be Pretty quickly becomes a very visceral, shared, and close experience between the audience and the actors.

Rogue Theatre grew out of dreams of building a community of actors, producers, stage hands, directors, and collaborators who are all after the same common goal of creating meaningful work and answering the age-old question: ‘"Is this worth my time?" At the end of the day we are storytellers, lovers of emotionally open and free interactions, and ambitious to make our mark in Toronto. It is our hope that you share with us the enthusiasm of what we are seeking to accomplish and supporting us in any way possible. 

The show will run from November 28th to December 4th at the N/A Collective, with shows from Tuesday through Sunday at 8pm and matinees on both Saturday and Sunday at 2pm. 


The Impact

With any artistic endeavour comes the challenge of money. The only way our production and company can work and can produce such exciting material as Reasons to Be Pretty is with your support. We are trying to raise $3000 privately so that the show can happen. Our hope is also that, if we meet our target in fundraising, we can put money towards our spring show. This money will ensure that Rogue Theatre will grow and become a voice for a riskier, sexier, and more enlivened type of theater in Toronto. 


What We Need & What You Get

All money that is raised through our efforts on Indie-Go Go will be put towards the production costs of Reasons to Be Pretty: renting  the space both for the production and in the rehearsals leading up to it, lighting design, sound effects, the set, costumes, right down to the posters for our advertising, and payment  individual members of our Equity Co-op for their services in bringing the production to life.  From rehearsal to production we need $3000.00. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If money is not an option, there are other ways you can help. The mouth is a wonderful thing, especially when it is used to share good information -- like, how to come and see Reasons to Be Pretty when it hits the Toronto stage November 28th. Tell your friends. Tell your Mom. Hell, tell your 8th grade gym teacher. We would love to have each and everyone of you. Our Story

story:
Short Summary

School Dance is the story of a group of endearingly awkward teens and their hormone-fueled quest for social acceptance. Set in the special kind of hell that is the high school dance, this award winning comedy is a nostalgic and boisterous theatrical party.

School Dance is about acts of bravery. About facing your own self loathing and coming out on top. Inspired by ‘80s cartoons and John Hughes films, the show features helpful unicorns, a hole in the space-time continuum, invisible teens, an epic bike race set to Bonnie Tyler, and an incredible amount of awkward dancing. 

School Dance marks Action/Adventure’s first foray into creating work for both adults and teenagers. Australian playwright Matthew Whittet wrote the play with the Adelaide, Australia-based Windmill Theatre Co. for audiences both young and old. The show connects with teenagers where they are at and adults where they used to be, with just enough awkward nostalgia to make everybody happy. It’s a highly personal work that, just like its central protagonists, is funny, sad, scary, weird, really stupid, endearing, and kind of repulsive.

Action/Adventure is proud to present the North American premiere of:
SCHOOL DANCE
By Matthew Whittet
Directed by Tamara Carroll
March 17th-April 9th
Thursdays-Sundays 8:00 PM

Featuring:
Christy Bigelow
Noelle Eaton
Jon Gennari
Brian Kuwabara
Pat Moran
Sam Reiter
Zoë Rudman
Samson Syharath

Stage Manager: Nicole Gladwin
Sound Designer: Richard Moore
Costume Designer: Sydney Dufka
Set Designer: Tyler Buswell
Lighting Designer Kim Williams

What We Need & What You Get

This is an ambitious show, in every way! For ten years, Action/Adventure has been producing inventive, accessible theatre funded almost entirely with ticket sales - which is a wonderful testament to our devoted audience. In order to produce this North American premier, we have to set our budgetary sights higher. We are committed to paying our collaborators, and providing a quality, engaging theatre experience with high production values. We were awarded a Regional Arts and Culture Council (RACC) project grant, which has helped us bring the project to the stage. Additional funding will expand our ability to reach as many young audience members as possible - with free tickets, actor engagement, and school outreach - in addition to maintaining our artistic commitments,  

The Impact

Reaching young audiences with work that respects and challenges them is more important now than ever. Action/Adventure has a long history of performing for non-traditional theatre audiences, and we are choosing to be intentional about including teens under that umbrella. By taking some of our financial dependence off of ticket sales, we can ensure that every young adult who wants to see the show can do that!

Other Ways You Can Help

Whatever you can donate will be wildly appreciated, but, more than anything, we want you to see the show! We're running now through April 9th, and tickets are available on our website (actionadventure.org) Can't make the show? We would love it if you could spread the word! Like us on Facebook! Follow us on Twitter (@ActionAdventure)! Share the event! https://www.facebook.com/events/244810395925716/

Thank you!!! We love you!!!

video by Chris Hatcher - Field Guide Films

We were awarded a Regional Arts and Culture Council (RACC) project grant, which has helped us bring the project to the stage. Additional funding will expand our ability to reach as many young audience members as possible - with free tickets, actor engagement, and school outreach - in addition to maintaining our artistic commitments,  

The Impact
Reaching young audiences with work that respects and challenges them is more important now than ever. Action/Adventure has a long history of performing for non-traditional theatre audiences, and we are choosing to be intentional about including teens under that umbrella. By taking some of our financial dependence off of ticket sales, we can ensure that every young adult who wants to see the show can do that!

Other Ways You Can Help
Whatever you can donate will be wildly appreciated, but, more than anything, we want you to see the show! We're running now through April 9th, and tickets are available on our website (actionadventure.org) Can't make the show? We would love it if you could spread the word! Like us on Facebook! Follow us on Twitter (@ActionAdventure)! Share the event! https://www.facebook.com/events/244810395925716/
Thank you!!! We love you!!!
video by Chris Hatcher - Field Guide Films

story:
Bread Crumbs!

What even IS nonbinary anyway? A computer program? A tropical drink? A word that caused you to have an existential crisis in your thirties when you finally realized oh my god, I think I might be one of those, but I'm married and have two kids already and what am I supposed to do now I have SO many bras? Join drag artist Harvey Gent (Jasmine Joshua) in a magically musical, raucously hilarious, and wholly autobiographical queer spectacle, featuring pregnancy, trekking across tidepools in your underwear, and peeing one's pants in front of Very Important People.

Jasmine began developing Bread Crumbs in 2018 with Eddie DeHais, and have done two workshops of the show as part of the Scratch Workshop Series in 2018 and 2019 as well as a version at MAP Theatre in 2019.  These have all been important steps in the show's development, and now Jasmine has the opportunity to bring their story to the ACTLab Solo Festival! This is thrilling news in this show's development, which will allow us to bring the show to new audiences, and help us look towards the future and life of the show.

Why We Need Your Help!

The funds we are raising for this project will allow us to fly director Eddie DeHais from Providence where they are studying at Brown-Trinity Rep, and pay for stipends for Jasmine and their whole staff, as well as cover makeup, costume, lighting, and administrative costs.  Any additional funds raised beyond our goal will support future iterations of the show.

Come On Out!

Support Jasmine on this next step in their queer journey and then join us Feb 14, 15, and 16 at ACTLab to laugh, cry, and question your very notions of gender!

Tickets available here: https://acttheatre.org/actlab/breadcrumbs/

story:
Launching Wild Art

 

Helmed by experimental Director Allison M Keating, Wild Art is a firecracker new performance company based in the booming arts town of Los Angeles.

The new seasons starts with the original play H&G, a public outcry
premiering at Paloma Street Studios in February 2016.

Wild Art creates artistic projects that are relevant to NOW, charging people to examine and question the world we live in.  Our performances herald unfettered self expression and are daring, ambitious, visually striking, exciting and never without a sense of danger.


H&G, a public outcry

a hysteric fun play about our imminent demise

H&G, a public outcry is a hyperbolic participatory performance placing the audience in the shoes of Hansel & Gretel, to explore America’s new fear of extreme weather through a dreamlike, hysterical, surprising journey of survival from drought to flood. Poised in a poetic landscape, this powerful live-music performance relies on a distorted performance style filled with shadow imagery and song to express what cannot be put into words.  Drawing from the third worst drought in US history and Hurricane Sandy, source material includes Hansel and Gretel, newspaper articles, American folk and rock songs, and text generated by John Michael Johnson.
H&G, a public outcry Creative Team:
Produced and Created by Allison M Keating
Mother played by Lucille Duncan
Suburbanite by Craig Gibson
Father played by Murphy Martin
Guide by Lisa McNeely
Music Composition by Jonathan Becker

Puppet, Projection, and Poster Design by Hsuan-Kuang Hsieh
Set, Props and Light Design by Mark Kanieff
Musical Director and Sound Design by Jeronimo Rajchenberg
Produced by Nora DeVeau-Rosen

H&G, a public outcry was created through a series of workshops in The School of Theater at the California Institute of the Arts.

WILD ART needs YOU

We have raised 80% of what we need for this new art project.  You will help us make up the last little bit! Help us meet our goal to...

  • pay our artists
  • clothe (somewhat) our actors
  • serve hundreds of audience members
  • create dozens of puppets
  • house our performances
  • and all of the other un-interesting stuff like insurance, gas, fundraising and credit card fees, and blah blah blah

With your donation, you will be helping to support the work of Allison M Keating and her new company, Wild Art.  Thank you SO MUCH for helping us make socially engaged artworks, for supporting the experimental arts tradition in America, and the burgeoning art scene in Los Angeles.

  We can't do it without your help!

A Letter from the Director

Dear Amazing Stupendous Friends and Family,

As a director, this is the fourth fundraising campaign I've run for projects that spark imaginations and question the status quo.  Every year my productions get more and more press, bigger and bigger audiences, with higher production values.  You, and you alone are responsible for the creation of Wild Art, a new performance company based in Los Angeles.  I have spent ten years imagining running my own arts company, and today, because of your help, I finally have created the company of my dreams.

You are responsible for my success as an artist and the amount of work I have been able to present to audiences in New York, Edinburgh Scotland, and now Los Angeles.

Thank you, from the bottom of my heart, for making my dreams come true.

With Love,
Allison M Keating

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Can't contribute financially?  No sweat.  
    It will be just as helpful if you spread the word about our show! 
    Repost our posts on social media and follow our #whatittakes campaign to see what it takes to create a play.  
    Come to the show! 
    Invite your friends!  
    We can't wait to see you!

We can't wait to see you!

story:
Take a Risk.  Change the story.

Last year, with the help of supporters like you, we began to build a community that honors creating opportunities for women in theatre.  Due to a serious void in opportunities for women in meaningful and powerful positions both on and off the stage, we created the Philadelphia Women's Theatre Festival. 

Now, it's year two and as we quickly approach our 2016 Festival, we need your help!

Your support is crucial to our success and central to our mission. We know how important the arts are to you and we would like to ask you to make a tax-deductible gift.  Your donation will help us present performances and educational opportunities ranging in style and scope during our 2nd Annual Summer Festival from August 3rd – 7th, 2016.

PWTF fosters and encourages women in the performing arts by offering unique opportunities for exposure, professional and artistic and personal development and a platform for performance.  We foster and encourage women in the arts of all disciplines: directors, playwrights, performers, designers, technicians, administrators and more.

This year, we are being hosted as an Organization in Residence in the Ira Brind School of Theater Arts at the University of the Arts in the heart of Philadelphia. We are incredibly grateful for the opportunity to produce work in an institution that has valued the creation of art for one hundred and forty years. (Happy Anniversary, UArts!) 

2016 Festival events  include:

· Original Staged Readings
· 4 Presented Works (devised theatre, solo performance and one-act plays)
· A Cabaret and Honoree Ceremony
· 3 Professional Development Workshops to coincide with performances
· A Stand-Up Comedy Hour


Our Impact

Last year, we took a RISK.  We asked, ‘Philly, what the f%$@&’?

And, with your help, we launched the Philadelphia Women’s Theatre Festival to celebrate the creativity of women.

·  We provided resources, support and exposure to women hungry for opportunity.

·  We received more than 100 artist and playwright applications.

·  We presented 7 shows, including new works created by local women.

·  Created professional development programming and a panel of Philadelphia’s female arts leaders

·  Showcased the work of more than 40 directors, designers and   performers

·  Honored Jennifer Childs, of 1812 Productions, as our fist Story Changers Award recipient.

We took a RISK, and you know what?  Our risk paid off.

Hundreds of you came out in support of our mission and in support of the work being created in our city and beyond. What started as an idea over cocktail hour with zero dollars behind the project turned into more than $10,000 raised to fund our first festival.  The amazingly enthusiastic response we received showed us that not only are women hungry for opportunity, but the people of this city are hungry to see our work.

Our week-long festival of public performances includes work ranging in style and scope so as to capture the attention of our community and make Philadelphia a destination for new artistic ideas and a hub for women artists of all disciplines. 

Affordability and accessibility will enable us to attract a multifaceted audience including students, young adults and seasoned theatre goers.  By providing both fiscal and artistic support to all contributing artists, we will ensure that the Philadelphia community has access to high quality artistry that may not otherwise be seen.


WHY is “starving artist” the accepted norm?  Your contribution will help us create PAID opportunities for women in the arts.

We have big dreams to create an engaging and immersive festival that will provide exciting and meaningful opportunities for women in the arts.  We are committed to financial and artistic fulfillment.

Your contribution will help us cover our general operating costs, but, more specifically, will cover the cost of fairly paying our artists for their talents, skills and education.  We estimate that 2016 artist stipend will total $7,650.  This accounts for 50% of our budget and  does not include any payment to our all-volunteer staff.


Our Challenge

As women, we take risks every day.  At some point in our lives, we all take risks to pursue our passions –Our passions to move, to create, to sing, to dance, to teach, to write, to direct, to engage. It’s not always been easy, but that hasn’t stopped us and it shouldn’t stop YOU!

Last year, we took a risk.  We spoke up. Last year, we asked ‘Philly, WTF??’ And you asked with us!

We asked WHY…

Why are male playwrights produced more frequently than female playwrights?  Why is male leadership the rule and female leadership the exception?  Why do we have to play by anyone else’s rules?

We also asked...

WHY aren’t artists paid properly for their work?  WHY should we be satisfied with little to no pay time and time again?  WHY is “starving” artist the accepted norm?

Change isn’t always easy, but…

We have taken tremendous steps towards realizing our mission and we have a darn good festival that positions Philadelphia as a national leader in honoring women's contributions to the arts. 

We envision a future wherein Philadelphia showcases the new work of women, exposing our City to the unique and innovative ideas of a diverse community of women. 

We are committed to women’s artistic voices and, this year, we are taking it to the next level! Celebrate women’s voices with us and, while you’re at it, take a risk with us – you know you want to!

Help us to change the rules.  Help us support our artists and the cultural landscape of our city.

Take the risk and ask – Philly, we love you… but WTF?

By donating to the 2016 festival, you can change the story by taking a risk with us.  Your gift will help to provide crucial resources so that our talented artists receive both artistic and financial reward for their skills.  With your help, Philadelphia can become a national leader in recognizing the creativity of women.

Take a risk. Change the story.


To learn more about the 2nd Annual Philadelphia Women’s Theatre Festival, visit our website.

There are more ways than one to contribute:

Share this campaign with your friends!
Get involved as a festival volunteer!

We would like to thank the generous and incomparable John Mullany of Ripples in the Pond Productions for filming and editing our video. 


Philadelphia Women's Theatre Festival is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a nonprofit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Philadelphia Women's Theatre Festival must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
We are a small dedicated team of students from all over the University of Michigan campus, independently presenting a production of Jason Robert Brown's Tony Award-winning musical "PARADE." 


Our goal is to present PARADE as never before, with a focus on its message of heroism in the face of adversity, and the painful relevance of oppression a century later.

PARADE is about Leo Frank, a Jewish factory manager in Georgia at the dawn of the twentieth century who is wrongfully accused of the murder of a young girl. When his trial culminates in only a life sentence, a gang of vigilantes come together to lynch the innocent man. This powerful narrative is an indictment of bigotry and a celebration of hope in the face of adversity.

Through the generous partnership of Hillel and West Side United Methodist Church, our goal is to present this production against the backdrop of a church sanctuary, as well as take our rehearsals to various locations on campus (such as Hillel) to open up dialogues on interfaith and race relations in America today.

Your donation will help pay for music expenses, licensing fees, lighting equipment, and audio equipment. 

We want to make this the best, most inclusive production of PARADE ever put on by a small group of students, but it won't be possible without your generosity! 

What We Need

Your donation will help cover:

  • Music expenses
  • Licensing fees
  • Lighting and audio equipment
  • Additional funding to take rehearsals and workshops to various events on campus

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Help us get the word out about this production!
  • Join the production team and help us make some theatrical magic!

story:
Who We Are

harunalee is an ensemble of performers and designers who collaborate across artistic disciplines to create experimental plays and performances written by Kristine Haruna Lee. Since 2010, they have been developing and producing work in New York including to the left of the pantry and under the sugar shack (La MaMa Club), War Lesbian (Dixon Place Artist Residency and Commission), Plum de Force (Bushwick Starr Propeller Project Series), and Drunkfish Oceanrant  (JACK in collaboration with Built for Collapse). Their works-in-progress have been presented by Prelude Festival .11+.13, Asian American Writer’s Workshop, 2g, Target Margin Lab Series, Ars Nova Ant Fest, and have been supported by LMCC and the Mental Insight Foundation. They are currently artist in residence at Brooklyn Arts Exchange where they are developing their new play Dog Gone Day,

What is Dog Gone Day?

Dog Gone Day is a play that Andrew R. Butler and Kristine Haruna Lee began dreaming up in 2013 at a Chipotle in Greenwhich Village. We performed excerpts of the show  at Little Theatre and Food for Thought at Danspace, and then were given this incredible year-long residency at BAX | Brooklyn Arts Exchange. We have two shows coming up on April 22 & 23, which is a culmination of our time working on this play at BAX, and we need your help to cover artist costs, as well as equipment rental for the design elements of the show. 

What's the play about?

It's about ‘A’ who is a a mnemonist which is like a memory expert, and 'K' who is a synesthete, which is a person whose brain mixes their sensory responses (so they might see smells, or hear colors). They seem to be inside of A's brain, where they time-travel through memories of their past and present lives: Cabo 1992, a medieval forest, a doctor’s office, a porcelain bathtub, Venice 1515.

All in search of something terrible that neither of them can quite remember.

Dog Gone Day is a trip inside one person’s intimate memory palace, where time travel takes place on neurological impulses, and scenes arrive and dissolve as quickly as the fleeting thoughts in our brain; they have the distinct weight of life altering memories falling like sediment to the floor of our subconscious.

What It Costs

Here's the breakdown of our budget:

  • $3800: Artist Stipends
  • $300: Rental Equipment
  • $200: Set Materials
  • $200: Transportation
  • $500: Contingency
We have some incredible artists involved: Kristine Haruna Lee (playwright), Andrew J. Scoville (director), Sarah Lurie (lighting design), Greg Laffey (set design), Christen Cappello (sound design), and Charlie Murray (AD).
And our phenomenal cast includes:
Andrew R. Butler, Jess Almasy, Mike Mikos, Josh Gelb, Eliza Bent, and Nikki Vega.

For This Production

We are focusing on lighting design. We want to provide our designer Sarah Lurie with the resources to recreate the inside of a brain; using lights to evoke neurons firing and memories arriving and dissolving.

We are also raising money in order to work with this stellar group of actors and designers who can put up a play that assumes a non-linear, experimental form. We want to see how this piece works, share it with an audience, and learn what we need to know to continue building on it. 

Art-Making Is A Risk

It is always a risk to make a new work of theater. We face challenges like ensuring the audience is given context for what they are about to see, especially when the play takes an experimental form. It will also be a challenge to realize this extremely complex design element in the time constraint that is given. However, we live for this moment, creating work that pushes formal boundaries and audience expectations. 


harunalee is a sponsored artist with The Performance Zone Inc (dba The Field), a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the performing arts community. Contributions to The Field earmarked for harunalee are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 906 New York, NY 10038, phone: 212-691-6969 or for our national charities registration. A copy of our latest financial report may be obtained from The Field or from the Office of Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.
story_txt:
Who We Are harunalee is an ensemble of performers and designers who collaborate across artistic disciplines to create experimental plays and performances written by Kristine Haruna Lee. Since 2010, they have been developing and producing work in New York including to the left of the pantry and under the sugar shack (La MaMa Club), War Lesbian (Dixon Place Artist Residency and Commission), Plum de Force (Bushwick Starr Propeller Project Series), and Drunkfish Oceanrant  (JACK in collaboration with Built for Collapse). Their works-in-progress have been presented by Prelude Festival .11+.13, Asian American Writer’s Workshop, 2g, Target Margin Lab Series, Ars Nova Ant Fest, and have been supported by LMCC and the Mental Insight Foundation. They are currently artist in residence at Brooklyn Arts Exchange where they are developing their new play Dog Gone Day,


What is Dog Gone Day?

Dog Gone Day is a play that Andrew R. Butler and Kristine Haruna Lee began dreaming up in 2013 at a Chipotle in Greenwhich Village. We performed excerpts of the show  at Little Theatre and Food for Thought at Danspace, and then were given this incredible year-long residency at BAX | Brooklyn Arts Exchange. We have two shows coming up on April 22 & 23, which is a culmination of our time working on this play at BAX, and we need your help to cover artist costs, as well as equipment rental for the design elements of the show. 
What's the play about?


It's about ‘A’ who is a a mnemonist which is like
a memory expert, and 'K' who is a synesthete, which is a person whose brain mixes their sensory responses (so they might see smells, or hear colors). They seem to be inside of A's brain, where they time-travel through memories of
their past and present lives: Cabo 1992, a medieval forest, a doctor’s office, a porcelain bathtub, Venice 1515.
All in search of something terrible that neither
of them can quite remember.
Dog Gone Day is a trip inside one person’s intimate memory palace, where time travel takes place on neurological impulses, and scenes arrive and dissolve as quickly as the fleeting thoughts in our brain; they have the distinct weight of life altering memories falling like sediment to the floor of our subconscious.   What It Costs Here's the breakdown of our budget:


$3800: Artist Stipends
$300: Rental Equipment
$200: Set Materials
$200: Transportation
$500: Contingency

We have some incredible artists involved: Kristine Haruna Lee (playwright), Andrew J. Scoville (director), Sarah Lurie (lighting design), Greg Laffey (set design), Christen Cappello (sound design), and Charlie Murray (AD).
And our phenomenal cast includes:
Andrew R. Butler, Jess Almasy, Mike Mikos, Josh Gelb, Eliza Bent, and Nikki Vega.
    For This Production 

We are focusing on lighting design. We
want to provide our designer Sarah Lurie with the resources to
recreate the inside of a brain; using lights to evoke neurons firing and memories
arriving and dissolving.


We are also raising money in order to work with this stellar group of actors and designers who
can put up a play that assumes a non-linear, experimental form. We want to see how this piece
works, share it with an audience, and learn what we need to know to continue
building on it. 
    Art-Making Is A Risk It is always a risk to make a new work of theater. We face challenges like ensuring the audience is given context for what they are about to see, especially when the play takes an experimental form. It will also be a challenge to realize this extremely complex design element in the time constraint that is given. However, we live for this moment, creating work that pushes formal boundaries and audience expectations. 


 harunalee is a sponsored artist with The Performance Zone Inc (dba The Field), a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the performing arts community. Contributions to The Field earmarked for harunalee are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 906 New York, NY 10038, phone: 212-691-6969 or for our national charities registration. A copy of our latest financial report may be obtained from The Field or from the Office of Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.

story:
Playwright, Mark Anthony Smith, brings us T.I.T.S. In the spirit of Moliere, T.I.T.S. is here to challenge religious and social beliefs and hypocrisy. Edgy, raunchy and down-right offensive. Rhyming, Music, Drunkenness, Denial and so much more!

T.I.T.S. was first created as a one act 10 years ago at Citrus College.  Not until several years later did Mark decide to incorporate his love for Moliere and rhyming couplets to create a full-length stage play.  His goal was to challenge religious beliefs, shine a light on hypocrisy and explore each character's sexual missteps and appetites.

With your generous assistance we will be able to secure a prime Hollywood Fringe 2016 venue, offer our cast a professional rehearsal space and create a lively and hilariously raucous theater experience.

We appreciate all forms of support...getting the word out...graphic design experience...technical assistance...or just a few words of encouragement!


Thank You!
The T.I.T.S. Cast & Crew

story:
Information

We had a really beautiful show that was made over a whole year. Two Legged Animal was Ziggy’s first full length performance produced by Ausform, the show previewed at the Wickham Theatre in February 2015 for one night only to a completely sold out audience. Their reaction was wonderful and we were incredibly proud.

Sadly the video that we commissioned of the show for booking purposes got corrupted and all we have is still photography. The problem is that the show is so unique and as this was first work with Ziggy as a lead artist; we are now unable to obtain bookings for what is a great show.

If you could donate a little (or a little bit more!) to help us remount the show in order to document it you’d help to secure the future of a show which we have worked on for so long & help to bring it to hundreds of audiences in the UK and beyond. 

Breakdown

Hiring Theatre  £350
Videographer  (including post-production work)  £400
Travel & accommodation for musician   £100
Our technician  £100
Rehearsal space (1 day before filming)  £100
Performers & musicians fees  £400
Producing support  £200

TOTAL: £1650

We’re putting in £150 to the project but we need £1500 to make this happen. 

Risks & Challenges

We need this money in order to re-stage the show for the shoot, Without hitting at least 90% of our target we will not be able to fulfil some of the perks described to do with viewing the film. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please do share the campaign to bring us closer to our target!

Love,
Ziggy x

story: We are run by students, so naturally we are lacking in the financial aspects of running a theatre company. Negative Space is putting up a three show season. Our first show, God of Carnage, runs June 9-13th. Our second show, The Estess Flower, is part of the KC Fringe Festival and runs July 16-26. Our last show, [Title of Show], will run the first week of August. We need your help to cover the costs of rights, venues, sets, props, and other costs that always come up when working on a show. We are all under the age of twenty, and this company is something we created to gain first hand experience in the world of theatre, and we can't gain that experience without your support. We hope you will consider finding this local theatre company, and hope you come see our shows this summer.

We hope you will consider finding this local theatre company, and hope you come see our shows this summer.

story:
The project

“Basically, I’m afraid of everything in life, except filmmaking.”                                     Lars Von Trier

‘Lars’ is a journey inside the Danish director Lars Von Trier's mind. All the play is performed in English language. We chose to abstain from direct quoting his movies. We generated instead – working on analogies – an independent imaginary by letting Von Trier’s biographical experiences dialog with H.C. Andersen’s fairy tales. With ‘Lars’ we decided to overturn psychoanalysis’ perspective. We are not interested in treatment for human pathogen microcosm, we are charmed by their fables. We write streams of consciousness, we align mind worlds, we create systems of signs, interactive conceptual boxes, searching for the alchemy of a new irony. 

"Lars" é un viaggio nella mente del regista danese Lars Von Trier. Lo spettacolo è in lingua inglese. Abbiamo scelto di astenerci dal citare direttamente i suoi film, generando invece -lavorando sulle analogie- un immaginario indipendente facendo dialogare le esperienze biografiche di Von Trier con le favole di H.C. Andersen. Con "Lars" abbiamo deciso di ribaltare l'angolazione prospettica della psicoanalisi. Del microcosmo patogeno dell'uomo non ci interessano le cure, ci seduce il folklore. Scriviamo flussi di coscienza, allineiamo mondi della mente, costruiamo sistemi di segni, scatole interattive concettuali, alla ricerca dell'alchimia di una nuova ironia.

Plot

In 1991 Von Trier’s masterpiece 'Breaking the Waves' is awarded the Golden Palm at Cannes. Lars decides to summon all his strength and try to get to the festival for the closing ceremony.

After many umpteenth failures in the attempt of reaching Cannes and, most of all, of defeating his plethora of obsessions and phobias, Lars consents to being hypnotized by Mesmer in order to get to Cannes, relying on hypnosis therapeutic effects.

Mesmer is a bizarre hypnotist as much in appearance as in methods he uses on his patient: he imposes on Lars quite embarrassing process, at times, as playing the lead character in a grotesque psychodrama session.

The relationship between Mesmer and Lars is in all respects a trial of strength.           At stake is the loss of control on things, people, events and even one's past.

Nel 1991 il capolavoro di Von Trier "Breaking the Waves" viene premiato a Cannes con la Palma D’Oro. Per l’evento, Lars decide di farsi forza e provare a raggiungere il festival.

Dopo molti falliti tentativi di raggiungere Cannes e, soprattutto, di sconfiggere la propria pletora di ossessioni e fobie, Lars accetta di farsi ipnotizzare da Mesmer. Obiettivo è raggiungere Cannes grazie al percorso terapeutico dell’ipnosi. 

Mesmer è un ipnotista bizzarro tanto nell’aspetto quanto nei metodi che applica sul suo paziente: sottopone Lars a procedimenti anche particolarmente imbarazzanti, come può esserlo fare da protagonista in una strampalata seduta di psicodramma.

E’ a tutti gli effetti un braccio di ferro il rapporto tra Mesmer e Lars. La posta in gioco è la perdita del controllo sulle cose, sulle persone, sugli eventi, persino sul proprio passato.

Kokoschka Revival

We are an Italian acting company founded in Milan in 2013 by a group of Paolo Grassi academy former students who yearned to get rid of the academy constraints.
 We chose to call ourselves Kokoschka Revival: Kokoschka is the name of the well-known expressionist painter, but it also means “hen” in Croatian and “popcorn” in Albanian.

We approach the theatre with musical ear.
 The relationship between control and loss of control is getting the centre of our investigation. We are developing new work methods which can affect writing, body movement and music research with this polarization. We move between aleatoric art chance and self-constraining codes.

 Since January 2014 we have been investigating Lars Von Trier as an author, as an artist and as a public person. Every interview is an outing about his paranoia, his numerous phobias, his obsession with death, accompanied by an almost chronic hypochondria. Almost all these wounds are related to a mother figure who, in the son’s narrative, exhibits disconcerting traits. She's committed to her ideal of absolute freedom, she governs a house where grown-ups walk around naked and children act as adults. 

Siamo una compagnia teatrale italiana fondata a Milano nel 2013 da un gruppo di ex allievi dell'Accademia Paolo Grassi desiderosi di sbarazzarsi dei blocchi insiti nella formazione accademica. 
Abbiamo scelto di chiamarci Kokoschka Revival: Kokoschka come il celebre pittore espressionista, ma anche come "gallina" in croato e come "popcorn" in albanese.

Ci approcciamo al teatro con l’orecchio dei musicisti. Il rapporto fra controllo e perdita di controllo sta diventando il centro della nostra ricerca, lungo la quale andiamo sviluppando nuove metodologie di lavoro che influenzino la scrittura, la ricerca sul movimento corporeo e quella sulla musicalità. Ci muoviamo tra il caso dell’arte aleatoria e i limiti dell'autoregolamentazione.

Da gennaio 2014 ci stiamo occupando dello studio di Lars Von Trier come autore, come artista e come personaggio pubblico. Ogni sua intervista è un outing: outing sulla sua paranoia, sulle sue fobie, sull’ossessione per la morte, accompagnata questa da un’ipocondria pressoché perenne. Ferite quasi tutte riconducibili a una figura materna che, nel racconto del figlio, mostra caratteri sconcertanti: votata all'ideale di libertà assoluta, governa una casa in cui i grandi girano nudi e i bambini fanno gli adulti. 

Help Lars to arrive at destination

The big jump is done… now we need your help to avoid the crash on the ground.

Please, help ‘Lars’ to land safe and sound! Your contribution is vital to us!

Thanks to you we will be able to perform ‘Lars’ in Italy and in his native land, Denmark.

We will use the collected funds to produce the play (we need scenography and costumes, etc… ) and to cover travel and residency costs.

Thank you!

Il salto è stato fatto... ora abbiamo bisogno del tuo aiuto per evitare lo schianto al suolo.

Aiuta "Lars" ad atterrare sano e salvo! Il tuo contributo è essenziale!

Grazie ad esso potremo mettere in scena "Lars" in Italia e nella sua terra natia, la Danimarca. 

Useremo i fondi raccolti per produrre lo spettacolo (dobbiamo creare le scenografie, i costumi, etc...) e per coprire i costi di viaggio e residenza.

Grazie!

story:
Intro

We have a lot of ambitions for this event, but some of them won't be achieved without your help. This is a fully crowd sourced and crowd funded event, which means all the organisers and contributors are going to be out of pocket to create this experience, a truly amazing group of people all working really hard to make this event awesome.

Our goals

What we're aiming for so far:
- 2 rooms. 
- Massive main room filled to the brim with high end large scale lighting and effects including fog machines, geysers, lasers, strobes, blinders, beams, projections, and more. With DJs spinning Techno, Minimal, and Psy-Trance, and maybe some Deep House to start the evening and socialise.
- Second room with the off the rekord crew and DJs spinning Deep House, Techno, Tech House, and DnB.
- Glovers performing amongst the crowd.
- Hot food available on site. (discounts for donators)
- Chill out areas.
- A side room filled with graph artists doing live art pieces!
- Poi and visual arts performers amongst the crowd.
- Instagram style photos of the crowd being displayed on the projector.
- Portable toilets for the ladies (logistics to be determined i.e. priority for donators, etc.)

Why donate?

1. We'll have to limit the amount of people we send location details to, by donating you'll be invited to join our priority guest list which guarantees access to all details just incase we exceed capacity. 
2. Ladies who donate will be given priority for the portable toilets.
3. You will receive special deals for the onsite food.
4. Without more funds we will have to remove some of the best features (e.g. toilets, additional speakers, costly stuff)
5. If only 500 people donate $5, we've reached our target.
6. There may be additional benefits during the event.

story:
Who We Are

Bad Neighbour Theatre is a young experimental theatre company based in New York City. We make work in Russian and English, drawing from a wide range of literary material in both languages.

Our latest venture is The Emily Triptych, performed by Miranda McCauley, directed by Charlotte Day, and designed by Amanda B. Friedman.

The Triptych is a translation into drama of something drama often overlooks: the stillness and silence from which great thoughts proceed, and with them, great words. It is an opening up of deep introspection – its language, its patterns, its idiosyncratic beauty – to the external eye. It is an effort to create an atmosphere in which Emily’s thought, and her poems, can live.

What We're Doing

After four months of development, we are ready to show the Triptych to audiences: at home in NYC this July, and at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe in August. In New York, we are hoping to perform at the Alchemical Theatre Lab, a whitebox theatre in downtown Manhattan. In Edinburgh, we are already registered to perform at the Quaker Meeting House, a central Fringe venue.

Our figure of $7000 includes:

  • Air fares for the performer and three crew members (about $3000)
  • The ~£470 balance of the Edinburgh venue rental.
  • At least $500 for New York venue rental
  • Two weeks' accommodation in Edinburgh for four people, at a total of £1400
  • UK visas for crew members
  • Compulsory Fringe insurance at £85
  • Publicity in Edinburgh at £100
  • 10% Contingency

What You Mean to Us

In the past, we have relied on donations from generous supporters in many parts of the world. What this means is that not all of our supporters have been able to see our work. They have made it possible for us to produce Measure for Measure, The Little Prince, The Woman in the Dunes, The Old Woman, and to rehearse and workshop The Emily Triptych - without asking anything in return. They, you, have made it possible for us to exist.

Now, we have the opportunity to bring our work to a wider audience: a critical step in making our artistic practice more economically sustainable. Just as your generosity this Fall got Bad Neighbour on its feet, so now your generosity can help take us to the next level.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute financially? There are many other critical ways you can help us develop as a company. The foremost of these is spreading the word. Follow us on social media, tell your friends about us, come and see us do what we do! Keep abreast of developments by visiting www.badneighbourtheatre.org/

We make work in Russian and English, drawing from a wide range of literary material in both languages.Our latest venture is The Emily Triptych, performed by Miranda McCauley, directed by Charlotte Day, and designed by Amanda B. Friedman.The Triptych is a translation into drama of something drama often overlooks: the stillness and silence from which great thoughts proceed, and with them, great words. It is an opening up of deep introspection – its language, its patterns, its idiosyncratic beauty – to the external eye. It is an effort to create an atmosphere in which Emily’s thought, and her poems, can live.What We're DoingAfter four months of development, we are ready to show the Triptych to audiences: at home in NYC this July, and at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe in August. In New York, we are hoping to perform at the Alchemical Theatre Lab, a whitebox theatre in downtown Manhattan. In Edinburgh, we are already registered to perform at the Quaker Meeting House, a central Fringe venue.Our figure of $7000 includes:
Air fares for the performer and three crew members (about $3000)
The ~£470 balance of the Edinburgh venue rental.
At least $500 for New York venue rental
Two weeks' accommodation in Edinburgh for four people, at a total of £1400
UK visas for crew members
Compulsory Fringe insurance at £85
Publicity in Edinburgh at £100
10% Contingency
What You Mean to UsIn the past, we have relied on donations from generous supporters in many parts of the world. What this means is that not all of our supporters have been able to see our work. They have made it possible for us to produce Measure for Measure, The Little Prince, The Woman in the Dunes, The Old Woman, and to rehearse and workshop The Emily Triptych - without asking anything in return. They, you, have made it possible for us to exist.Now, we have the opportunity to bring our work to a wider audience: a critical step in making our artistic practice more economically sustainable. Just as your generosity this Fall got Bad Neighbour on its feet, so now your generosity can help take us to the next level.Other Ways You Can HelpCan't contribute financially? There are many other critical ways you can help us develop as a company. The foremost of these is spreading the word. Follow us on social media, tell your friends about us, come and see us do what we do! Keep abreast of developments by visiting www.badneighbourtheatre.org/

story:
Hello everyone! My name is Cody Siemiatkowski, the director of this production. First and foremost, thank you all for even taking the time to read this pitch. Theatre is a collaborative process not just between actors, directors, stage managers, and designers; it is a collaboration with our audience as well.  Without you, there would be little point to making art in the first place. 

A Steady Rain came about because of an assignment given to Cedric Houle (Denny) and myself one and a half years ago during our Acting 2 class under the guidance of Dr. Nicole Hodges Persley. We were both drawn to the nuance of the characters of Denny and Joey (I was assigned Joey at the time) and the interesting way their story is told. A duologue is a rare form of storytelling in modern theatre or film, and because of this, we have been eyeing this script for a student production since the end of that class. Since then, I have been exposed to the art form of Directing, and I feel it is a better place for my talents than as an actor. With this in mind, Cedric and I went forward with our project under the watchful eye of Dr. Hodges Persley, who graciously agreed to be our faculty mentor. 

With both Cedric and I placed in the show, we went about filling up the rest of the team. I asked my old friend Josh Philoon to come on as Scenographer, and for those who don't know that term, he is responsible for every design element in this show. Simultaneously, I had considered holding open call auditions for Joey, but due to the constraints around the other KU shows and everyone's schedules, I jumped when I found out Stephen Elberg was free. Finally, I asked Jake Gillespie, another actor who had expressed interest in working in other aspects of theatre, to come on board as my Stage Manager.

With this team in place, we have the stage set to make an incredible show. But as part of this class, we have also decided to be the first at KU to attempt to crowdfund our show! All proceeds will be going towards making this show a reality, with any leftover funds being donated to the University of Kansas Theatre Department. This will be a free show, so we cannot offer tickets as rewards, but anyone who donates at least $5 will be given a special thank you in our program!

Thank you again to all who read this whole thing. Without you guys, there would be no reason for doing this, so we invite you to come see the show even if you cannot donate. I look forward to seeing you all in person on either May 4th or 6th!

Cody

story:
Who Are We?

The Synthesis Experiment is a new theatre company in Asheville, North Carolina co-founded by Jonathan Lewis and Anna Lyles. Dedicated to the creation of innovative and provocative works of theatre, Synthesis believes that vital and engaging theatre cannot be created without an inherent sense of risk or failure. Synthesis is determined to deliver dynamic, engrossing, and unceasingly daring new productions to the Asheville community, each in their own unusual and unexpected location. Each project, whether a production of an exciting and well-known musical or a new piece of performance art from fascinating new artists, will overflow with thrilling imagery, dynamic staging, and the undeniable pulse of life that is so often missing in the commercial theatre.

 

Why Give Money To Our Theatre?

We at The Synthesis Experiment feel that theatre should be exciting for audiences again and have set out to create provocative and fully immersive pieces of art to serve the Asheville community.  We strive to break the bounds of paint-by-numbers productions of shows by trying to find ways to inject originality and innovation into every work we produce.  As with the creation of every piece of art, there are costs involved to make sure that quality outs.  Help us fill a void in Asheville's theatre scene and help us push the envelope of how immersive musical theatre can be

The Price of Making Theatre

Here's some of our foundational cost in mounting this production:

  • Royalties to license the show - $1000
  • Costumes/Makeup/Equipment - $500 
  • Marketing Costs - $200

Risks & Challenges

We are funding our first production entirely out of our pocket and out of passion, which is an undertaking that we don't mind doing as long as the art gets out to the people.  As such, we are walking a financial tightrope at all times.  Every little bit donated to this campaign ensures the sustainability our of new theatrical enterprise and helps us create the best art we can for the people of Asheville

Other Ways You Can Help

We are constantly looking for artists, actors, and volunteers.  Email us at thesynthesisexperiment@gmail.com for more information on how you can get involved!

story:
WHO IS INKED DANCE?

 INKED Dance questions the social structures of American culture through various mediums to provoke thought and challenge ambiguity in social stigmas.  Through outreach, performance, and education: Inked Dance promotes tolerance and acceptance from the cultural down to the individual level of understanding in order to recognize stereotypes and subvert against them.  
Inked dance operates under the direction of Brian Moe, artistic director and composer.  Brian Moe received his MFA in dance from CSULB in 2012, but also has degrees in Psychology, Dance, and Music (BA, BFA, AAS respectively).  He has received numerous recognitions and awards for his ability to do both music and choreography to create truly cohesive works on a large scale.  
The importance of the 'Nightmares' production can not be put into words.  This is the closing performance of INKED Dance's inaugural season that will take place OCTOBER 25th and 26th, 2013 at 8:30 pm.  We have graciously been able to co-present with Leo Garcia at Highways Performance Space in Santa Monica.  This large, evening length performance blends together film, dance, and theater to create a surreal nightmarish environment where the audience will come to realize their fears.  A successful presentation at the space will help INKED Dance become a force to be reckoned with in the LA Dance scene.  It will also help generate interest in the company as we strive to become a fully recognized non- profit organization.  
With your generous contributions, we will be able to cover the costs of filming (light, camera, editing, set), costumes, lighting design, and on stage sets.  We will reward your donations handsomely with our deep gratitude, humble thanks, and or course all of the perks listed in the donation section.    If our goal is not met, we will still use all the funds gathered to put on this performance ti the best quality and standard that we can afford.  
Highways is known for presenting experimental and cutting edge performance art, dance, and film.  Our presentation of 'Nightmares' is an important asset to the community at large as that it comments on the fears we all share as human beings.  And it leaves us with a very important realization that "our own Nightmares are only as bad as we allow them to be."
If you would like to help us further, we are always asking for help with promotions on social media forms.  Word of mouth is still a popular method of information transference, but nothing is easy or as visible as sharing a link on Facebook.  If you believe in this project as much as we do, and you would like to do your part above and beyond the contribution you have made, we ask that you help us promote the event to make other aware of this truly unique evening of dance and film.

story:
THE POWER OF THE PLAY 

Both my parents are and were incredible artists. I have long since given up the idea of having a corporate 9-5 job.  What I aspire to be is a writer, producer and creator of magical projects that make a difference in other people’s lives. This is why I wrote MY PRIVATE REVOLUTION. I feel that my play has the voice of many.  It speaks to abuse, loneliness and depression and how we can overcome these problems.

THE PLAY’S STORY

MY PRIVATE REVOLUTION is dynamic one-woman show about overcoming abuse and finding healing and forgiveness.  It is a rhythmical and powerful journey addressing social issues and celebrating the power of individual choice.  A thought provoking, transformational and heart wrenching play filled with drama, music and dance. 

THE SUPPORT FOR THE PLAY 

When I produced my previous two plays, Indiegogo  was only a concept in someone’s mind and I had to work five jobs to make those plays come to life! With much appreciation to the creators of Indiegogo I’m hoping to raise $35,000 to produce my new play and work only two jobs!  After raising the funds I can then spend the remainder of my time focusing on rehearsing and creating and awesome show for you!

Most of the funds will go for the venue and personnel.  In addition, because of my love of music, I have original songs that we will need to pay for the musical rights. We also have to pay for rehearsal space, marketing, lighting and sound. It is such an amazing learning experience creating an Off-off Broadway play. Especially if you want it to feel like Broadway!!!

The major budget expenses:

•VENUE

•ADVERTISING AND MARKETING

•PRODUCTION COSTS – Sound, Lighting, Set Design, Music, Costumes 

•WRITER, DIRECTOR, CHOREOGRAPHER, SINGER

•MUSICAL LICENSING

Do visit & Like us on MPR's own Facebook fan page!

story:
Now celebrating its 10th Anniversary, the critically-acclaimed, award-winning RADIOTHEATRE has established itself as the premiere company for LIVE ON STAGE audio theater in New York City.  Not only does RADIOTHEATRE preserve the art of the audio drama from the "Golden Years" of radio, but, it combines the simple craft of storytelling with the “Theatre of the Imagination” and 21st Century technical advancements in the world of SOUND DESIGN and ORIGINAL MUSIC, for which it's won 2 NY Innovative Theatre Awards, nominated for a prestigious Drama Desk Award, nominated 13 times for NYIT awards and 5 years in a row as Best Performance Group.  
 
Besides creating unique LIVE productions unlike any other theatre group, RADIOTHEATRE has devoted itself to offering high-quality productions of genres traditionally bypassed in the Theatre World...HORROR, SCIENCE FICTION and ADVENTURE!  To that end, it has produced over 80 shows in NYC and on tours, featuring tales from the masters of terror, including festivals of adapted stories by H.G. Wells, Edgar Allan Poe, and Bram Stoker, as well as, classics like KING KONG, FRANKENSTEIN, THE ALFRED HITCHCOCK FESTIVAL and original tales of ghosts, mad scientists and the like.
 
RADIOTHEATRE is also the only NYC theatre company to faithfully bring the tales of H. P. LOVECRAFT - the Grandmaster of 20th Century Horror - to the live stage, having produced and performed over 20 Lovecraftian tales for sold-out audiences at the annual H.P. LOVECRAFT FESTIVALS in New York City.  "A CULT HIT IN THE EAST VILLAGE!"  NY TIMES

Beginning OCTOBER 2nd- 31st, 2014, RADIOTHEATRE plans to mount
THE 6th ANNUAL H.P. LOVECRAFT FESTIVAL in NYC.  This time, we're pulling out all the stops, bringing Lovecraft’s most well-known stories to life on stage, including THE DUNWICH HORROR, THE SHADOW OVER INNSMOUTH, and the legendary THE CALL OF CTHULHU.  On OCT 30/31, RADIOTHEATRE will present a portion of the live festival at FEINSTEIN'S in SAN FRANCISCO, as well.
 
In addition, this year, our HPL fest will also be presenting some of the best Lovecraftian FILMS donated by the "H.P.Lovecraft Film Festival - Portland, Oregon" celebrating its 20th Year in 2015!...all  in one of the most haunted buildings in New York City - THE KRAINE at 85 East 4th St. From theater to film, THE 6th ANNUAL H.P. LOVECRAFT FESTIVAL will be one of the MUST attend events this Fall!   
 
Up until now, our mom and pop company has been able to survive fairly well in the difficult NYC theatre world....and critics and audiences agree that there is nothing like RADIOTHEATRE amidst the hundreds of stage productions in NYC each year.  However, to continue our work, this time we are reaching out to all of the fans across the globe - RADIOTHEATRE fans, old time radio fans, contemporary performance art fans, Horror fans, and Lovecraft fans, alike - to help support us in reaching our goal.  With your contribution, you can help bring The H.P. LOVECRAFT FESTIVAL to life. From the bottom of our hearts, we want to thank you all for helping support our cause.
 
And to all you true believers out there, we say, “CTHULHU FHATGN!”

story:
It's Amazing What You Can Do With A Dream, Elbow Grease, and a Taste For Human Flesh ...

Last year, over one hundred volunteers showed up to help turn a Victorian sawmill into the most downright unsettling Halloween event in Northern California.  Nearly two thousand people made it through the doors, and another two thousand willing victims were turned away with their flesh still intact.

Now that we know how much Humboldt thirsts to get its blood drained, we're bringing it back - with more scares, more days, online ticket sales, and of course a lot of raw adrenaline.


What We Need and What You Get

Basically we need a starting budget to help get this terror off the ground.  The more money we get, the more we can spend on rare components for our summoning ceremonies -- uh -- we mean special effects.  Plus donating isn't exactly a painful experience and you get some awesome perks

  • Free tickets to the event (duh.)
  • Limited edition commemorative buttons. Last year these things went fast!
  • Limited edition t-shirt with art based off of this year's poster.
  • Same art on a hooded sweatshirt, because Humboldt's cold.
  • There's other cool stuff. Just read the info in our perks section.


The Impact

Let me make this as simple as possible:

  • This is FUN.
Eureka needs this.  Honestly, where else can you go in Humboldt to get your really world class scare on? Yes, last year we raised over 10,000 for two great non-profits, yada yada yada. More importantly, we're a lot of grown people who love to pour latex on our faces and pretend that monsters are bursting out of our insides. Help us forget our responsibilities for a few weeks per year and join together under the common banner of crafting nightmares. We're fearsmiths, and that sort of mental illness needs to be celebrated.


Other Ways You Can Help

This shouldn't be too surprising:

  • Get involved directly. Come find our facebook page and become a volunteer.
  • Spread the word! About the fund raiser, about the event, whatever. Publicity is a good thing.

Thanks for helping to support our creepy creepy habit..
