story:
Greetings… Julie Gannon here.

On the 21st night of September 2013 I’m turning the big 4-0. The theatre part of me is currently knee-deep in rehearsals for an evening of epic proportions. At first I was planning an extravaganza showcasing my original song, dance, and performance art parodies laced with the elite talent I’ve encountered over my 39 years gracing the stages of Earth. Yet, that seemed limiting. It would have much more impact if this party had a purpose; the intent of helping as many children from across the globe as possible who desperately need miraculous transformation in their lives. So I prayed on it with the Cloud Stud, and BAM, I got my answer.

It’s called “Cirque Du Julie: Sur Le Mur“ (a homage to my circus brethren and the gloved one). This is staged on Saturday night September 21, 2013 at the Berkeley Carteret in Asbury Park, NJ with an 8pm curtain. You’ll experience an arena of comedy and tragedy in a way you’ve never seen before.

At the heart of the event is “The Ray of Hope Foundation”. Out of all of the non-profits I’ve been involved with, this one I owe my spiritual life to.  To give a bit of background; every child deserves to know what happiness and love is. Since 2001, The Ray of Hope Foundation continues to reach out to children suffering from debilitating illnesses, and giving these kids and their families support in any way they need during this crucial time in their lives: spiritual support, financial backing, community involvement, listening and prayer. And then there are the countless miracles this group has played a part in. I’m talking about the stuff they write books and make movies about, people. Mind-blowing healings from all walks of life (click here to read numerous accounts of personal miracles that occurred through the Skop Rosary Society including my own).

We all know this… there’s power in numbers. So which part of the Cirquel will you join? Perks galore for each category. Every copper penny beyond production costs fills The Ray of Hope Foundation’s cup til it runneth over and over. In return, all of the lives transformed by those donations are attributed to you because you took the leap of faith and thought enough to spare the dime.

Please, search your heart and let’s together take massive action to make this possible.

Ladies and Gentleman, this is YOUR Cirque Du Julie, Sur Le Mur…

A crash, a flash, a beam of light explodes,
In time to drums, in time to shouts, rhapsody.
It’s off the wall, it’s slicing through your heart
The speed of light, the roar of celebration, a player’s part.
A life is spent in exploration of
Delight, of song, of dance, of love
And what these do when thrust from one good soul
Toward another waiting with mind and arms opened wide!

And if that mind is a bit askew?
One that sees as very few do?
A mind the lions tamed,
Incapable embarrassment, much less shame?
A brain shot one too many times from a cannon?
Say, the mind of… Julie Gannon?
Simply grit your teeth and hope your inner child’s still inside,
And go for the ride.
Revisit a time and place untouched and pure
Cirque du Julie: Sur Le Mur

A crash, a flash, a beam of light enflames,
A ray of hope!
And so begins the passions, the dance, the games,
Played for charity, played for love, played for all to win.
A ray of hope,
A gift from within given to those in need of the voice of a violin,
The leap of a dancer, the warmth of a clown.
A ray of hope,
A gift from within given by you as you join the circus that just pulled into town,
Just as you always wanted to.

Cirque Du Julie: Sur Le Mur
Saturday, September 21, 2013 7:30pm
Berkeley OceanFront Hotel
1401 Ocean Avenue Asbury Park, NJ

7:30pm-8pm Pre-Show Cocktail Party with open bar and light fare
8:30pm-9:30pm Theatrical Showcase featuring Cirque performers, Broadway and Regional singers and dancers, performance artists, and a few familiar faces ;)
9:30pm-12:30am-Show Party blowout with dessert and open bar

For more information, visit www.surlemur.org or text "surlemur" to 96362
story_txt:
Greetings… Julie Gannon here.
On the 21st night of September 2013 I’m turning the big 4-0. The theatre part of me is currently knee-deep in rehearsals for an evening of epic proportions. At first I was planning an extravaganza showcasing my original song, dance, and performance art parodies laced with the elite talent I’ve encountered over my 39 years gracing the stages of Earth. Yet, that seemed limiting. It would have much more impact if this party had a purpose; the intent of helping as many children from across the globe as possible who desperately need miraculous transformation in their lives. So I prayed on it with the Cloud Stud, and BAM, I got my answer.
It’s called “Cirque Du Julie: Sur Le Mur“ (a homage to my circus brethren and the gloved one). This is staged on Saturday night September 21, 2013 at the Berkeley Carteret in Asbury Park, NJ with an 8pm curtain. You’ll experience an arena of comedy and tragedy in a way you’ve never seen before.
At the heart of the event is “The Ray of Hope Foundation”. Out of all of the non-profits I’ve been involved with, this one I owe my spiritual life to.  To give a bit of background; every child deserves to know what happiness and love is. Since 2001, The Ray of Hope Foundation continues to reach out to children suffering from debilitating illnesses, and giving these kids and their families support in any way they need during this crucial time in their lives: spiritual support, financial backing, community involvement, listening and prayer. And then there are the countless miracles this group has played a part in. I’m talking about the stuff they write books and make movies about, people. Mind-blowing healings from all walks of life (click here to read numerous accounts of personal miracles that occurred through the Skop Rosary Society including my own).
We all know this… there’s power in numbers. So which part of the Cirquel will you join? Perks galore for each category. Every copper penny beyond production costs fills The Ray of Hope Foundation’s cup til it runneth over and over. In return, all of the lives transformed by those donations are attributed to you because you took the leap of faith and thought enough to spare the dime.
Please, search your heart and let’s together take massive action to make this possible.

A crash, a flash, a beam of light explodes, In time to drums, in time to shouts, rhapsody. It’s off the wall, it’s slicing through your heart The speed of light, the roar of celebration, a player’s part. A life is spent in exploration of Delight, of song, of dance, of love And what these do when thrust from one good soul Toward another waiting with mind and arms opened wide! And if that mind is a bit askew? One that sees as very few do? A mind the lions tamed, Incapable embarrassment, much less shame? A brain shot one too many times from a cannon? Say, the mind of… Julie Gannon? Simply grit your teeth and hope your inner child’s still inside, And go for the ride. Revisit a time and place untouched and pure Cirque du Julie: Sur Le Mur A crash, a flash, a beam of light enflames, A ray of hope! And so begins the passions, the dance, the games, Played for charity, played for love, played for all to win. A ray of hope, A gift from within given to those in need of the voice of a violin, The leap of a dancer, the warmth of a clown. A ray of hope, A gift from within given by you as you join the circus that just pulled into town, Just as you always wanted to.

story:
Me & My Monkey!

Hello Everyone:
I am Bradley Spann. I am an actor/writer in Boulder currently producing my first one man show. My background: I have performed with the Open Fist Theatre company, The Evidence Room, The Colorado Shakespeare Company,  The Met Theatre, and The SITI Company to name a few. My training: I have an MFA in Contemporary Performance from Naropa University where I studied The Viewpoints, Roy Hart Voice work, Grotowski, and self scripting. I also studied Meisner for two years at The John Ruskin School of Acting in Santa Monica, Calif.  
I am currently seeking funds to help promote my show, pay my designers, pay a videographer, pay a photographer, and to produce a DVD of the show. 
Here is the description of my show:
Actor/Writer Bradley Spann takes you on an unforgettable and often hilarious journey through the trials and tribulations of a dress wearing monkey, a dopey raccoon, four hormonal sisters, an absentee brother, a sociopath, a traumatized mother, and a family owned & operated motel. A tale culminating in the bicentennial year of our country that you won’t find in any history book.
This show is a turning point in my career. This is the first time I am stepping out and writing/performing a solo piece. I feel all my training plus the years of living in among people who were inherent storytellers has led me to create my show. My goal is to have this be the first of many shows I will create. I see this show as my learning curve. I feel it is a strong show. I also know I have lots to learn. My goal is to be a fringe artist that tours the world performing at fringe festivals. I am excited to do this show and I want everyone to be a part of it. 

What I Need & What You Will Get

Here is the Break Down: 

The funds I raise will be spent as follows:

$300 for promotion: The printing and distribution of post cards for my show. Plus the creating/printing of the show program

$200 each to the lighting and sound desginers 

$200 still owed to my director

$100 Costume plus props.

Here are the perks:

$10 For this amount I will publicly thank you via a facebook posting.

$25 For this amount I will send you a handwritten letter of thanks for contributing to my show. I will also give you a big hug in person if you are in Boulder. And you also will get the perk outlined above.

$50 For this amount I will thank you in the program of my show plus you will get the perks listed above.

$100 For this amount you will get a ticket to see my show in the fringe. If you are not in Boulder I will send you a link where you can see excerpts of the show.

$500 For this amount you will get a producing credit in the program of my show plus two tickets to the show. If you are not in Boulder I will send you a DVD of the show.

$1000 For this amount you will get a producing credit in the program of my show plus two tickets to the show. If you are not in Boulder I will send you a DVD of my show. I will also send  you a limited edition t-shirt of the show. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially I understand. These are hard times. If you still want to get involved there is a way you can help: Invite people to see my show! Here is the information. Please share it.
Me & My Monkey
Actor/Writer Bradley Spann takes you on an unforgettable and often hilarious journey through the trials and tribulations of a dress wearing monkey, a dopey raccoon, four hormonal sisters, an absentee brother, a sociopath, a traumatized mother, and a family owned & operated motel. A tale culminating in the bicentennial year of our country that you won’t find in any history book.

CAST: Bradley Spann

ART FORM: Solo, Theater, Spoken Word

RATING: PG - Parental Guidance Suggested: Some material may not be suitable for children

WARNINGS: Adult language

DURATION: 50 min.

SCHEDULE:

Thu Sept 19 7:00 pm*
Sat Sept 21 4:00 pm
Mon Sept 23 5:30 pm
Wed Sept 25 7:00 pm
Fri Sept 27 5:30 pm
Sat Sept 28 8:30 pm

VENUE: Dairy East Theater

TICKETS: $12/$10 general/students & seniors

TICKET DEALS: *2-for-1 Deal: Sept 19

For more info go to: http://www.boulderfringe.com/programs/2013/theater-2013-programs/bradley-spann/

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

Vagabond Acting Troupe celebrates 21 years of educational and professional theater - from exploring the edge with our adult ensemble, to helping new playwrights get their work seen, to freeing the voices of young up and coming actors! We've only been in our building for four years though - and we would like to stay here for a bit longer. But though our fees are the lowest in the region, our overhead is now right up there with the more expensive companies. And our rent is increasing! So - want to keep Vagabond around in the 30 Fairview space for another few years? Help us raise money to pay the increased rent through May!

What We Need & What You Get

Right now we're just asking for that assurance that the rent will be paid through May 2014! $10,000 will help us make it to May. But we could definitely use more to pay the staff, the electricity, the oil bill! So even if we reach our $10,000 goal - keep on donating! That will help us make it through summer!  YOU DO NOT NEED TO MAKE YOUR DONATION HERE - You can go straight to Vagabond and donate there. But if you want to donate here for ease of credit card, that's great too!
    -  Donate $5,000 or more and get a sponsorship credit in the program, a chair named in your honor, two tickets to our 21st Anniversary Party, a special presentation at our 21st Anniversary party and a banner outside our theater naming one of our spaces after YOU (your name, or the name of your choosing) for the 21st Anniversary Season - and the knowledge that you helped your community's live theater in a time of need!      
    - Donate $1000 to $5,000, get that sponsorship credit in the program, and a chair in your honor, two tickets to our 21st Anniversary Party, a special presentation at our 21st Anniversary party and your name on a banner outside the theater - and the knowledge that you helped your community's live theater in a time of need!!
    - Donate $500 to $1000, get a sponsorship credit in the program, and a chair named in your honor and your name on a banner outside the theater, and a ticket ($40 value) to our 21st Anniversary Party on January 3 - plus the knowledge that you helped your community's live theater in a time of need!! 
    - Donate $100 to $499 and have a sponsorship credit in the program, and a chair named in your honor, and your name on the banner outside the theater this season - and the knowledge that you helped your community's live theater in a time of need!
   - $50 to $99 and have a sponsorship credit in the program, a chair named in your honor, and the knowledge that you helped your community's live theater in a time of need!
    - Donate $25 to $49 and have a sponsorship credit in the program and the knowledge that you helped your community's live theater in a time of need!
- Donate $1 to $24 and have our special thanks for helping us save our community's live theater in a time of need! THANK YOU!

The Impact

Live theater is one of the most intimate, life changing of the performing arts. The way Vagabond does it, we're using it from both sides - to teach tolerance, understanding and cultural awareness to audiences, and to teach communications, confidence and tolerance to students!

Named NUMBER ONE on the PHL 17 HOTLIST just last month, named a five star non-profit by greatnonprofits.com, highlighted by the Huffington Post as a five star non-profit - and a multiple Barrymore Award nominated company -  Vagabond's track record for creating strong works with student and adult performers for family audiences is validated not just by judging committees at the Barrymore Awards, but more importantly by the people we have impacted - YOU!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD - and tell people about your individual experiences with us and why you hope we can raise the money!
  • You can use the Indiegogo share tools by clicking and sharing on your facebook and twitter accounts!
  • Offer your help to run other small fundraisers! We need people to help organize other ways that people can help us! Man hours are our most important resource in keeping prices down so we can reach every interested student in the region!
  • Help us track down roofing tiles to be donated so that our team can get up and put a new roof on the theater!
  • Come on in and be a volunteer! We need volunteer help in every area of our theater - that's how we keep our prices so low!

Help us track down roofing tiles to be donated so that our team can get up and put a new roof on the theater!

Come on in and be a volunteer! We need volunteer help in every area of our theater - that's how we keep our prices so low!

story:
BLESSINGS.

I am Deatrice Nicia De'Lovely, a Northern CA self-published poetess and dramatist. I have been creating inspirational poetry for decades now catering to a predominantly female audience. My poetry emphasizes the pain, purpose and power of women. As a trauma survivor of a fast urban upbringing, where not even my beloved mother was exempt of abuse, I obligate my literature to encouraging assertiveness, confidence, and self-esteem to the neglected. All of my literature derives from events relevant to me, yet instead of entertaining being once victimized I use these experiences to heal, empower and commend US (universal sisterhood) as we continuously thrive in rapidly changing conditions.

Urban Roses Soliloquies is more than a performance; it is a testament of perseverance through poetry and dance by an electrifying ensemble of local talented performers including the extraordinary DANCE-A-VISION of Oakland, CA. This evocative performance acknowledges the struggles, strengths, trials and triumphs of the urban female. It is the exposure of taboo living and the discovery of vigor, self-worth, love and healing during the storms. It is my goal to share this great Urban Roses Soliloquies production with the Northern CA most often demoralized, trivialized and unrecognized Bay Area young women. Your contributions will enable me to present Urban Roses Soliloquies to diverse multitudes of girls and women of Northern CA; those in need of encouragement and those worthy of applause. Urban Roses Soliloquies gives recognition to every female, empowering and commending through verse and dance. My belief...

  1. EVERY GIRL has a voice.
  2. EVERY WOMAN has a story.
  3. EVERY PERSON has a purpose.

Like many visionaries and entrepreneurs I rely on my regular 9-to-5 to fund my projects. On August 15, 2013 I took a leap of faith and self-produced my first Urban Roses Soliloquies show. Theatrically it was a success, but with limited funds came many limitations. For instance, it is my dream to put on this performance free of admission for the women and girls of our Bay Area shelters, group homes, foster homes, high school and advocacy nonprofit organizations. Although the show went on for paying guests, I was unable to produce a second show for those whom I consider my target audience.

My goal is to raise $8,000.00 so that I can share my uplifting production with US (universal sisterhood). The anticipated $8,000.00 will help fund the following necessities:

  • Venue reservation fee
  • Recitalists compensation
  • Marketing materials
  • Audio/visual equipment rentals
  • Professional Photographer and Videographer
  • Wardrobe and make-up
  • Security
  • Stage props and other miscellaneous items

Now as my most sincere gratitude to you for your kind generosity I have prepared some very heartfelt perks. All contributions are highly regarded, as the impact of every dollar will be felt by someone’s mother, someone’s daughter, someone’s grandchild and so-on. Urban Roses Soliloquies is more than my production; it is my ministry.

If you are interested in becoming a volunteer of the Urban Roses Soliloquies production please contact me via email at poetryandcupcake@gmail.com. I am Deatrice Nicia De’Lovely, and I AM an Urban Rose.

Much love Love LOVE to You All!

************************************************************************************************************

SEEDS OF ENCOURAGEMENT

Sometimes we forget how vibrant, lovely and absolutely necessary that we are during the desperate droughts and drifts.

Sometimes, when the chill of air freezes our fingertips and chaps our lips we stop trying to smile and uplift.

Sometimes... We can’t properly see beyond the sea of mud, concrete, metal and debris during the storms –But

No matter how deeply the frost affects our roots we must carry-on growing.

No matter how thick the fog, territorial the rain, cold the snow or weak the terrain...

As women

AS WOMEN

We HAVE to go-on

With imbedded resilience we must grow-on

Even when our weeds are showing

Because we are Urban Roses

And WE....

Can blossom through any pain.

Copyright © Nicia De'Lovely 2013

story:
Short Summary

Hey! I'm a 15 year old dancer who has been offered an amazing oppurtunity to represent Canada at The World Ballet, Jazz and Modern Championships in Poland this year.  I am one of 44 dancers going on this amazing journey, but I need your help! As dance isn't considered as an official sport, we do not receive any government funding. We train just as hard and are just as committed as any Olympic athlete. We are also artists, sharing our passion for dance with the rest of the world.

What's the money used for?

  • Each of us are responsible for our plane ticket, accommadation while in Poland, choreography fees, and costume fees.
  • Every dollar I raise, will go directly to this trip. Even if I don't reach my goal, the amount I raise will help tremendously.

The Impact

  • Your contribution would mean so much to me.  This is an absolute dream and you can be a part of making it come true!

Every little bit counts! But if you're unable to contribute, you can still help me out by sharing this campaign with your friends and family!

story:
WRITER'S BENCH JAM 3

 Lady Champ (Chicago Champions) and Tonic (Chicago Tribe) are re-introducing an event in the heart of Logan Square (Logan Square Eagle monument) to help younger generations be inspired by artists and dancers of their peers. The basis of our mission is to bring a free all ages event to the community, and let those who are interested express themselves freely with confidence. Our event will consist of a bboy/bgirl battle, all styles battle, and an exhibition battle, along with live music, an art showcase, and dance cyphers. This event will be held at the Logan Square Eagle monument, off of N Kedzie and N Milwaukee in Chicago, IL 60647.

What will your contributions help us achieve? Your donations will help with the Dj's, judge's, and competitor's compensations. This event is a non-profit event and all our fundraising goals will pay for fees associated with the event. The remaining amount will be given to a Boocoo youth cultural center (Evanston, IL) that encourages art/dance/music. In today’s society, where art and music is lacking in the youth, we want to bring the hunger for creative thinking and promote artistic freedom.

story:
a play

waiting to be created 


UPDATE:  IF THE CAMPAIGN HAS ENDED, YOU CAN STILL HELP AT  inotherwordstheatre.ca

BUY A LITTLE BLACK TOTE, GET ADVANCED TICKETS TO THE SHOW OR CLICK THE DONATION BUTTON ON SITE. THANK YOU!!!!


In Other Words Theatre proudly presents their devised production: MUSE.  

About The Project: MUSE  FAQs

Q:  What the heck is devised theatre?

A:  Devised theatre is theatre created collectively in the rehearsal hall by the artists—versus following a finished, polished script created by a playwright. Making theatre in this way offers unique, surprising and engaging performances for artists and audiences.

Q:  But I’m seeing scenes of the play in the video, has it already been created? 

A:  No, this is just the beginning.  We have begun a scaffold (a sort of outline, rough script or storyboard that serves as a starting place and can be deconstructed, re-written, turned upside down or even tossed away if needed) with some scene and character ideas, and this is what we used for the filming. We wanted to give you an idea of where we are going with the play.

Q:  So, what’s it about?

A:  MUSE  tells the tale of two women: Grace, who is an institutionalized, musically gifted young woman, and her nurse, who carries a guilty secret from the past and wants desperately to connect with her charge.  Grace’s caregivers—in an attempt to reconnect her with the outside world—have forbidden her to escape into her music. 

The story takes place inside of Grace’s head.  The audience serves as her imagination. Over the course of the play, Grace and the audience create a song together as the story of shattered loyalty and the power of the imagination unfolds around them.

Q:  Cool! What do you need the money for?

A:  Grace's imagination is both a key character and a setting in the play, and creating the world inside her head with live sound, interactive video projections and light will be crucial to its success.  In Other Words is incredibly fortunate to have a new media artist on board to help us bring Grace’s inner life to the stage. Now all we need is the funding in order to pay for these design and production elements.  Our goal is to raise $2,500 for new media equipment and artist fees.

Please note: It is our policy to always pay for people rather than for things whenever possible.  The lion’s share of this funding will go to the artists who will make the technical magic happen.

About The Company: In Other Words Theatre

We are a non-profit theatre company in Nanaimo, BC dedicated to devised theatre, artistic collaboration, and finding new ways to tell stories using different forms of language and ways of communicating. Our goal is to empower both artists and audiences by exploring theatre and performance in engaging, imaginative ways. We love collaborating with other artists (and sometimes audience members, too) to produce unique performance pieces. 

In Other Words was founded by theatre artist and educator Barbra French in 2012; MUSE will open our very first season and will run at Nanaimo Centre Stage October 10 – 26, 2013.  Barbra has been devising theatre collectively since 1998, and was the Artistic Director of the Etcetera Theatre Collective in Edmonton (2002-2006). For more information on Barbra or the company, please visit inotherwordstheatre.ca.

About You: Rewards and Gratitude

We are truly grateful for any help and support you can offer. In order to say “thank you,” we have come up with a few tokens of our appreciation. Please know that each and every dollar you so generously give means a lot to us; we love you for it!

About Other Ways to Help: Connect and Share!

There are lots of ways you can support us without putting money down on this campaign.  Spread the word and share this campaign with your all contacts.  Send out emails about our show or our company.  If you know anyone who has a space we can rehearse in for free, email us.  Get a group together and buy tickets to the show (that’s probably the most important thing you can do for us).  Come to a fundraiser, or donate something for it.  Connect with us and volunteer. We appreciate any and all help you can offer—however it comes—and we thank you from the bottom out of hearts!

Email barbradfrench@inotherwordstheatre.ca for details on how you can get involved. And be sure to use the SHARE tools here!

story:
Make Dance a GoGo : Burlesque series the perfect Christmas gifts!  ( possibly.. ^ ^ )

Here we are with the exciting new releases! And we need your support to make our release part of your holiday gifts! ( possibly... ^ ^ - if we reach $10K goal ) We've been in production for the past 6 months, and we're ALMOST at the finish line. Making our exclusive releases before the holiday is our goal, and your involvement would be tremendous to help us achieve it. 


Why are we here ? Click here for Andrea's IndieGoGo Message.

Get behind the scenes with us! Subscribe on Youtube to stay tuned for new video update! 


What We Need & What You Get

Okay! Here are the logistics :)

We've got the all the footage to create these amazing DVDs for you to take home and master like a STAR that you are. Now all we need is the finishing funds, namely, Post Production ($$$), from video editing, sound engineering and the whole night yard!  Your patronage will guarantee you these exclusive releases never seen before at a DEEP discount before its official releases. 

Note: If we reach our funding goal ( $10K ), we aim at releasing in Dec., otherwise, it'd be 2012.

We support Breast Cancer awareness

* For EVERY 100 pre-orders of Dance a GoGo Burlesque series ($55) made through indieGoGo, we will donate $100 towards Breast Cancer charity. 

* For EVERY 500 pre-orders of Dance a GoGo Burlesque series ($55) made through indieGoGo, Andrea and her dancers will plan / donate an entire day for Breast Cancer awareness teaching the women in need to dance with joy and embrace their femininity through dancing. 

Help us spread the words
Please help us spread the words & check out the sharing features on the page, we're on Facebook, Twitter and Youtube, Fan us :)

What is Dance a GoGo ® ? 

Dance a GoGo is the ONLY entertainment driven, life style focused Dance Fitness program designed specifically for women to gain confidence, look fabulous and dance like a POP STAR.

Every Dance a GoGo program is repetitive, timeless, no-chit chat, a total experience of - Shut up and DANCE!  Every Dance a GoGo program focuses on creating a world of dance with YOU being the STAR.


Hottie transformation is now made possible with Dance a GoGo -- if you're ready for the challenge. 











Who is behind Dance a GoGo ® ?

Dance a GoGo Creator, Andrea Lin, is a mainstream Music Video dancer, model and choreographer. 

She has worked with many household named celebrities and music stars, such as Britney Spears, Madonna and many more. For more info, please download the Press Kit.














What are Dance a GoGo ® DVD programs ? 

Dance a GoGo: Sexy Nightclub Workout Series ( 3 DVD @ 40min each )

Click Here to view the Trailer.

Dance a GoGo : Burlesque Series ( 6 DVD @ 80min each )

Get a sneak peak below.

story:
Our Story...

We are an artist-driven company committed to a spare, but evocative aesthetic that places the characters and their journey at the forefront of an audience’s consciousness. We're dedicated to presenting big ideas in small spaces and providing the most visceral and immediate experience possible for our audiences. We're called "The Shop" and we plan to offer a wide range of theatrical commodities, from exciting new works to bold interpretations of classic plays. Come sample our wares!


The Production...

Our first production will be the world premiere of a new work by Judith Goudsmit called LOVE IN TRANSIT and will run this summer from July 28th through the 30th at The Red Room, here in New York City. The play is a comic fantasy presenting the lives of two unique individuals, a man and a woman, and their struggles with love, longing, and loneliness in a world of relentless momentum.


The Impact...

This production marks our first step, as a company, into the vibrant New York theatre scene. Its the launching pad for our future  and will serve to legitimize our mission as a company and the kind of theatre that we are committed to creating.


What We Need... 

Our production is a modest one by New York's standards, but as with all things, even this is relative. Our fundraising goal is $2000.00 to pay for the expense of renting space, creating scenery, and outfitting our actors with the essential props and costumes that they need. Holding true to our mission we are keeping things lean and story driven, but even so, we can't do this on our own. We need your help! We know that these are difficult times for some, but any contribution, no matter how large or small, will be greatly appreciated.


We can't thank you enough for your support and hope to see you at the show!

story:
Hey Folks!

Hey Folks, we're "Team Four Messages" and we've got a show going up this spring in NYC. And it's going to cost A LOT of money! Please help to defray the costs of producing a show in NYC. The show, "Four Messages," is a beautiful (we think) musical (sort of) about love, faith, and forgiveness. We believe in it and we hope you will, too! Any help you can give will help ease the tremendous expenses involved.

Team Four Messages has membership in Fractured Atlas, so your contribution is TAX DEDUCTIBLE! Fractured Atlas is an organization that helps artists attempting to raise money for projects, such as we're doing with "Four Messages." Membership in Fractured Atlas can allow supporters of "Four Messages" to make TAX-DEDUCTIBLE contributions! Fractured Atlas a long-standing, reputable organization that has helped countless artists and artistic organizations produce work.

Why "Four Messages" needs your help.

We're not attempting to fund the entire project with this campaign. If we raised $5000, it wouldn't pay for this production. If we raised $10,000, it wouldn't pay for this production. If we raised...oh God, let's stop here before it gets nauseating.

So we're asking you  -friends, supporters, countrymen- to join in as producers on this show. We're "all in" on this one, folks, and could use some help.

"Four Messages" is a show about love, faith and forgiveness, some things we think the world could use a little more of. And maybe this show can help make that happen.

And did we say there were perks? Depending on how much you donate, you could receive one or more of Ned Massey's award-winning albums. You could even receive a fully-produced song written especially for you! Or even a private, in-your-own-home house concert for you and your friends by Ned Massey! But be aware that since your donation is tax deductible, if you decide to take a perk, I have to assign a reasonable dollar value to the perk and your tax deduction will be less the value of the perk -hence for many of you who would like the full donation amount as a tax deduction, NOT choosing a perk might be the best route!

Other Ways You Can Help

We know times are incredibly tough these days, so if you can't make a monetary contribution to the show, we totally understand. But maybe you can tell others about the project, or share the link to this page. Or come see the show! Or just send that good energy! It's all appreciated!

We can't thank you enough for your time and consideration. 

Peace, Love, and Art,

The Team of "Four Messages"

story:
Give us your money.

We're square product theatre. Maybe you already know us, but if you don't, here's some info:

square product theatre was founded in 2006 with an eye toward providing affordable, inclusive, professional theatre to the Boulder community. Now headed into our 8th Season, we have presented a variety of new, innovative performance work including:

  • 9 World Premieres
  • 8 Regional Premieres 

We've showcased our original work in Denver, Austin, and Chicago, in addition to our home base of Boulder, Colorado.

We love collaborating to create and present new, challenging, and thought-provoking work. We hope you'll check us out.

We've got a really exciting season coming up including:

  • the return of Kelsie Huff's award-winning solo show BRUISER: Tales From a Traumatized Tomboy, presented at the 2013 Boulder International Fringe Festival
  • the Regional Premiere of Johnna Adams' Gidion's Knot, presented in collaboration with Boulder's Goddess Here Productions
  • the triumphant return of 5 Lesbians Eating a Quiche, by Evan Linder and Andrew Hobgood
  • and the World Premiere of Peggy Jo & the Desolate Nothing, created in collaboration with our brilliant friends at Buntport Theater Company

We've also been working really hard on a film shoot for SLAB, adapted from the forthcoming novel by Selah Saterstrom. SLAB is a multi-media performance project we’ve been developing for 3 years, which will premiere in the Summer of 2014. Directed by Gleason Bauer, SLAB will feature video by Christina Battle and a sound score by Janet Feder and Paul Fowler. Beyond the premiere in Boulder, we hope to someday bring it to a city near you: it'll be pretty epic.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We're shooting for $10,000. Holy heck, that's a lot of money. But it's for a good cause, we promise. Funding will be used in conjunction with ticket sales and grant funding to compensate artists and production personnel, as well as to help cover the cost of production.
  • If you donate, you'll get some totally rad perks! Like what, you may be wondering. Well: we’ve got ticketing packages, we’ve got a non-speaking role in a show, we’ve got high-fives, singing telegrams, personalized mix CDs, rehearsal invitations, hand-printed t-shirts, and our undying affection. What more could you want? 

The Impact

We're a critically acclaimed, award-winning theatre company. We take our work seriously, but we have a good time, and so does our audience. We're not whistling Dixie over here, y'all.

One of our goals is to consistently provide our community with accessible, inclusive, professional theatre by keeping our ticket prices low. We believe that art is for everybody, regardless of income. The cost of production makes this a difficult goal to meet, but with your help, we can continue to offer affordable theatre in our community. Don't live in Colorado? That's okay! Spread the love from wherever you are and know that people in Colorado will appreciate your generosity!

Here's the deal: we believe theatre has the power to make a difference; to introduce people to new ideas. We aren't traditional. We're risk takers. An investment in square product theatre is an investment in something different. Are you brave enough to be different? We hope so.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone is in a position to help out financially. If you fall into this category, it's cool: we still love you. A lot. We hope you'll take a second to help us spread the word.

  • Forward our email blast to people you think might be interested.
  • Let your friends and family know on Facebook and Twitter
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
Hey: thanks. We won't let you down. We promise.

Beyond the premiere in Boulder, we hope to someday bring it to a city near you: it'll be pretty epic.



What We Need & What You Get

We're shooting for $10,000. Holy heck, that's a lot of money. But it's for a good cause, we promise. Funding will be used in conjunction with ticket sales and grant funding to compensate artists and production personnel, as well as to help cover the cost of production.
If you donate, you'll get some totally rad perks! Like what, you may be wondering. Well: we’ve got ticketing packages, we’ve got a non-speaking role in a show, we’ve got high-fives, singing telegrams, personalized mix CDs, rehearsal invitations, hand-printed t-shirts, and our undying affection. What more could you want? 




The Impact
We're a critically acclaimed, award-winning theatre company. We take our work seriously, but we have a good time, and so does our audience. We're not whistling Dixie over here, y'all. 
One of our goals is to consistently provide our community with accessible, inclusive, professional theatre by keeping our ticket prices low. We believe that art is for everybody, regardless of income. The cost of production makes this a difficult goal to meet, but with your help, we can continue to offer affordable theatre in our community. Don't live in Colorado? That's okay! Spread the love from wherever you are and know that people in Colorado will appreciate your generosity! 
Here's the deal: we believe theatre has the power to make a difference; to introduce people to new ideas. We aren't traditional. We're risk takers. An investment in square product theatre is an investment in something different. Are you brave enough to be different? We hope so.



Other Ways You Can Help
We know that not everyone is in a position to help out financially. If you fall into this category, it's cool: we still love you. A lot. We hope you'll take a second to help us spread the word.

Forward our email blast to people you think might be interested.
Let your friends and family know on Facebook and Twitter
Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Hey: thanks. We won't let you down. We promise.

story:
The Logos Theatre

Here at The Logos Theatre we strive for excellence. Our founder Dr. Nicky Chavers and his wife, Sheri Chavers, started The Academy of Arts as a youth ministry back in 1971. Since then it has grown leaps and bounds and now has its own theater in Taylors S.C.

The Logos Theatre carries on The Academy Of Arts' goal of "Making the Bible Come Alive." With a 55 ft. stage, two side stages, wing space, fly space, and a 20 ft. diameter turn table, productions in The Logos truly bring the Bible to Life, leaving the audience with the unforgettable truth of God's Word.

Here is a little of what we did last year.

 Our goal is to be able to mount The Chronicles of Narnia in February. We want to be able to do our very best in all that we do at The Logos Theatre. In raising the $6,000, we will be able to purchase the necessary tools to project scenery, and captivate the audience, giving them a complete feel of Narnia. However, this project will not just help with Narnia: in helping us reach our goal you will be furthering our impact in the community. 

So we are asking for your help.  


And to show our appreciation we have put together different perks for you to enjoy. Thank you for taking the time to check out our page. 

Please spread the word about what we are doing!

story:
A WORD FROM MR. KUDOI

I was told by the author, a sly, hypocritical young fellow with a bad haircut, to keep this short in keeping with the attention span of those of you reading this.  Suffice to say, The Hotel Ichiban is a romantic musical comedy set in a seedy boarding house in Tokyo in 1985.  High school graduate Hikaru Shiro is desperately trying to get into college, while the other residents of the boarding house cheer him on by throwing parties in his room every day!

But a new manager, a lovely young lady with a tragic past, changes all that!

Love!  Loss!  Romance!  Beer!

The Hotel Ichiban...A New Musical!

story:
SHADES OF TRUTH THEATRE - Takes a revealing look into the lives of a people whose contributions and accomplishments are minimized as well as uncover important events often omitted or overlooked in the pages of recorded history. It seeks to shed a truer light on the history of the African American and challenge its many historical misconceptions creating vivid new images for the World Stage.

I am a full time actor, activist and teaching artist in NYC I started Shades of Truth Theatre nine years ago with a mandate to present theatre with an uncompromising fearlessness. I believe it is our privilege and obligation to re – write history and create living testaments to both the tragedy and triumphs of the Black experience.

The funds we raise will go directly to the costs of our 2014 production of Black Wall Street and further development of the script.

Michael Green, Producer

In the heartland of America there once was a Black Community more than 600 businesses strong. Among these were 41 grocery stores, 30 restaurants, 21 churches, 6 privately owned airplanes, 5 hotels, 4 drug stores, 2 dentists,2 movie theaters, a bank, a post office, a hospital with 15 physicians/ surgeons plus several libraries, schools, law offices and even a bus system! All within a 36 block radius. The year was 1921… in Greenwood, Tulsa Oklahoma aka Black Wall Street

Putting on a multi-media stage production with a 12-person cast is in itself a daunting task. To recreate live on stage 1921Tulsa Oklahoma in order to tell the story of “Black Wall Street” (by Celeste Bedford Walker) the way it needs to be told requires authentic costuming and a layered three dimensional state of art set design. (made portable and suitable for travel)

We must also bring together top notch lighting and sound designers who will work with director Patricia R. Floyd to capture the right mood and tone of the play. Along with the host of actors, stage managers and other technical and logistical assistants needed represents a huge financial challenge for a theatre group that relies primarily on bookings and box office receipts. Your non tax-deductible gift helps us pay the actors you can see on stage, the technical, production staff behind the scenes, as well as marketing and management. It will make it possible for us to offer half-price ticket nights and distribute tickets at highly discounted prices to low-income members of our community. (Primarily students & seniors)

In order to mount our most ambitious production ever, We Need YOU to Help Meet our goals.

What will the money be used for?

Your support will fund up to ten or more performances of Black Wall Streetin New York City New York. Not only would you be helping the show reach over 2,000 people, we’d be able to gain momentum as we move toward an extended run. Most of your contribution will pay for theater rental, rehearsal space, script development & research, directing, lighting design, sound design, video design, box office services, publicity, program printing and advertising. The rest will pay for fees, royalties and licensing. We must hire education experts to develop curriculum materials (study guides) so that “Black Wall Street” can be used as a teaching tool in schools, universities and the community for years to come.

What happens if you raise more money than your goal?

What an exciting prospect!

If the campaign reaches $40,000,00 or $50,000,00 we’ll be able to rent a larger theater with greater production value. Moving us closer to a sustained run of Black Wall Street

 (If the campaign brings in less than our goal…let’s not even entertain that!

Can I donate anonymously?

Yes! When you click your favorite tier, you'll be taken to a page that asks for your name and email address. No one other than our production manager can see your email address, and you can use a pseudonym in that section. You only need to use your real name in the payment section (which is not posted).

How else can I help? Here's how to get involved.

•  Spread the word about this campaign to your family & friends and to those you think would like to know about it (Are you a social media expert? We’d be honored to have your expertise)

•  Join Black Wall Street on social media presence on Twitter or Facebook


Dear Supporter and Friend,

As a “woman of a certain age”, I remember being a freshman in high school and taking the required American History class. We read about Columbus “discovering” America; Jamestown and Plymouth Rock, The Boston Tea Party, etc. In terms of the African-American contribution to building this great country, there was literally a single paragraph on the Triangle Trade, which brought slaves from Africa to the Americas, sugar from the Caribbean to the colonies and rum and goods from the colonies back to Africa. All the way in the back of the book, which we never even reached, was a picture of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. and perhaps a page that encompassed both the Civil Rights and Black Power movements. I wondered what had happened to the Black people between 1865 and the Montgomery bus boycott. I was fortunate to have educators in my family who gave me books by and about Black people which encouraged my thirst for knowledge of my history.

I first became aware of the Greenwood Massacre in 1991. I was directing a production that focused on the bombing of the MOVE house on Osage Avenue in Philadelphia. I was appalled that local government headed by an African-American mayor, Wilson Goode, had literally dropped a bomb on citizens of the United States on May 13, 1985, ultimately destroying roughly 60 homes. I was shocked to find that this was not the first time in American history that bombs had been dropped on Black Americans in this country. I discovered the 1921 Tulsa race riots.

At a time in our history when the election of President Barak Obama has unleashed a backlash from a small but vocal element of unfettered racism; when the murder of a Black teenager “armed” with Skittles goes without consequence; when a popular television personality with a large African-American following admits to wanting to host a party with the catering staff dressed as slaves with little black boys tap-dancing for the entertainment of White party-goers; Black Wall Street is not only American history, but a cautionary tale.

I am personally asking you to support this project. It is important on so many levels. It is important to continually re-enforce to the African-American community the levels of success it is able to achieve, even on an uneven playing field. It is important that the entire country be aware of both the accomplishments of, and the terrorism against, American Blacks post-Emancipation. It is important to speak out and discuss, in order to heal.

Please give and please give generously.

Warmest regards,

Patricia R. Floyd

Director, Black Wall Street

FloydDirector, Black Wall Street

story:
About the Show

This November, the Agency Theater Collective is very excited and proud to be producing I Wish to Apologize to the People of Illinois. This world premiere play tells the true story of Stuart Levine, the fallen Chicago power broker whose lurid testimony brought down some of Illinois’ highest-powered politicos. Sex, drugs and electronic cigarettes are just the tip of this mucky iceberg.

Check out the Chicago Tribune article about the show!

We at The Agency believe I Wish to Apologize to the People of Illinois tells an important story about our city, our state and the people who live in both. Agency company members Tim Touhy and Andrew Gallant have been researching and writing this play for over a year and a half using courtroom transcripts, news reports, interviews and group devising techniques in their process. We believe the script Tim and Andrew have created is unlike anything you'll see onstage anywhere else and we can't wait to share it with you.

With an innovative script, our dynamite cast and your support we are certain that I Wish to Apologize to the People of Illinois will be a big success.

What We Need & What You Get

I Wish to Apologize to the People of Illinois is a huge undertaking for our company, the largest production in our history. To make this project the success we know it can be, we are working to raise $12,000 in order to cover our production costs.

Specifically, your donation will help us pay for: theater rental, costumes, set construction, lighting equipment, sound equipment and marketing costs.

We know that $12,000 is a lot to raise, but we are also going all out with the perks we are offering to our donors. To name a few: a years worth of Meisner acting classes at Green Shirt Studio, a tour of Chicago with the playwrights, invitations to our cast party, a 10-week Meisner acting class, an official show poster autographed by the cast and crew, an original short play based on your life performed at No Shame Theatre, sessions with a certified life coach and tickets to the show. In addition to these perks, we will list your name and thank you on our Facebook page and website.

The Impact

The Agency Theater Collective has been operating for a little over two years and we are proud of what we've achieved so far. In 2012 we were named runner-up "Best New Theater Company" by the Chicago Reader. We have produced four mainstage productions and have been running our weekly event, No Shame Theatre, for 100 consecutive weeks (as of September 28th).

The interest we have already had for this show has been staggering. This is an important moment for The Agency, and we want you to be a part of it. We are a company with big dreams and your support in producing I Wish to Apologize to the People of Illinois will help us reach them. We are the Agency and so are you.

Other Ways You Can Help

We are sincerely grateful for any donation you can make to support our project. In addition to a donation, you can also help by sharing this campaign with your friends, family and co-workers. Also, we hope you'll come see our show!

story:
Who we are and what we are trying to do :-)

Hi there! My name is Rob Tode, and I am the new Theater Director for Capital High School in Santa Fe. This is my first year teaching at Capital, and I arrived to find a beautiful theater space in slight disrepair and some amazing kids with little direction. I also was informed, after I ordered the scripts for my first play, that not only was my budget Zero Dollars ($0), but as a result of the previous teacher not paying for some royalties, my new budget was Negative three hundred (-$300) :-(

I decided to mount the production of "The Actor's Nightmare", by Christopher Durang, since I could do it with very little money, and because I love the play. We just finished a successful run of performances, but had a fairly small turnout, audience-wise. My plan is to take this production to the Eastern New Mexico University High School Drama Festival in Portales, NM, and we need your help...We made enough from our school performances to pay our old debt and to pay for our entrance fees for the festival, but thats about all we could cover.

What We Need

I want to raise $3000 to at least pay for the students accommodations and the cost of the district bus. So here is what the funds will be used for:

  • Bus Transportation to and from the Festival (approximately $1500-we have to use and pay for a district bus)
  • Hotel Accommodations for the student actors/crew/chaperones (approximately $1500-25 kids, 3 chaperones for 3 nights)
  • Any extra funds raised will go towards meals for the students

The Impact

You can make a difference to enrich the lives of the students involved. The impact would be immeasurable. None of my students have ever been to this festival before, and they will get the opportunity to share their talents with other students from across New Mexico & Texas. They will also be attending other productions as well as numerous theatre workshops offered during the 3 day festival. Your help will truly make this an amazing educational experience for these kids.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate, please consider sharing our campaign link on your page. It would mean the world to us. If you read all the way down to here, thank you so much for hanging in there. Only 2 more sentences after this. I wanted to keep this as short as possible, so feel free to email me if you have any other questions about our journey. And we will be updating this page with pictures and videos during the life of this fund raiser :-)

story: n/a

Send Us to Outer Space!

No One Receiving is a new play that pays homage to sci-fi classics such as Silent Running and Hitchhiker's Guide, while telling the timeless story of an activist who refuses to give up, even when it's game over. No One Receiving will run from Febrary19-23 as part of the 35th annual Rhubarb Festival at Buddies in Bad Times Theatre in Toronto, an arts and cultural space with a long history as a hub for Canada's LGBTQ+ creative communities.

Check out our facebook invite for the show, and let us know if you'll be here to see it!

Maggie MacDonald and Stephanie Markowitz have been making art together since 2006. For our new show, John Southworth and Roxanne Luchak will be part of the team as well. John Southworth recently created and staged the musical Easterween, and he has recorded several critically acclaimed albums. John also starred as an evil bureaucrat in a "Ted's Talk" companion piece to the show Young Drones.  Roxanne Luchak is a video artist and musician, known for her work as a member and projectionist with Toronto band Kids On TV.  

Previous works by Stephanie and Maggie include the Rat King Rock Opera (2006,2007: music written and performed by Bob Wiseman, Laura Barrett);  Paper Laced with Gold (2012: music created with/performed by Stevie Jackson and a troupe of our very own Dreamlander-style artists); Young Drones (2013, 2014: music, lyrics created with/performed by the Bicycles, featuring John Southworth).  Hear about our collaborative work in this interview conducted for the 2012 HATCH Residency:


We are independent theatre artists not affiliated with an established company. We are not receiving support from any funding bodies for the creation of our new work, so support from our friends and fellow artists is especially appreciated. 

With your support, we will create a visually vibrant sci-fi show that uses humour to investigate and discuss difficult feelings that artists and activists alike must go through in the struggle to reinvent the possible. Let's talk about those long dark nights of the soul, through which we must press on, and find hope in the face of despair. In space.


What We Need & What You Get

  • We need $1125 to pay for props, costumes, gear, photography, visual aids, script development, and to cover the cost of materials and photocopies, and mailing out your donor rewards.
  • To reward supporters, we have some unique and rare art objects to share, including 10 original drawings by the show's author, and a zine and EP with a silk screened vellum (tree vellum!) cover. Maggie used to draw graphic zines; most recently she has illustrated scientific presentations with Green Neuroscience lab. Treat yourself while helping us create!
  • Every little bit counts. We will put this show on even if we don't meet the goal. We're scrappy that way.

The Impact

  • Lately Canadians are opening up to talking about despair. But what about activist despair, and artistic despair? These are deep blue emotions brought on by a reckoning with outside forces, and one's refusal to conform or give up, even if it seems like the campaign will fail, or your art will never reach anyone. But through art and music we can find solidarity, community, and comfort, even across great distances of space and time. That's what this project is about.
  • Together Markowitz and MacDonald have a track record of creating imaginative shows on small budgets. By donating to our new project, you can be part of the effort to create the next one. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please spread the word about our show, and tell your friends to check out the Rhubarb Festival and Buddies in Bad Times Theatre.

Thank you for your support!

Running and Hitchhiker's Guide, while telling the timeless story of an 
activist who refuses to give up, even when it's game over. No One Receiving will run from Febrary19-23 as part of the 35th annual Rhubarb Festival at Buddies in Bad Times Theatre in Toronto, an arts and cultural space with a long history as a hub for Canada's LGBTQ+ creative communities. Check out our facebook invite for the show, and let us know if you'll be here to see it!Maggie MacDonald and Stephanie Markowitz have been making art together since 2006. For our new show, John Southworth and Roxanne Luchak will be part of the team as well. John Southworth recently created and staged the musical Easterween, and he has recorded several critically acclaimed albums. John also starred as an evil bureaucrat in a "Ted's Talk" companion piece to the show Young Drones.  Roxanne Luchak is a video artist and musician, known for her work as a member and projectionist with Toronto band Kids On TV.   Previous works by Stephanie and Maggie include the Rat King Rock Opera (2006,2007: music written and performed by Bob Wiseman, Laura Barrett);  Paper Laced with Gold (2012: music created with/performed by Stevie Jackson and a troupe of our very own Dreamlander-style artists); Young Drones (2013, 2014: music, lyrics created with/performed by the Bicycles, featuring John Southworth).  Hear about our collaborative work in this interview conducted for the 2012 HATCH Residency:We are independent theatre artists not affiliated with an established company. We are not receiving support from any funding bodies for the creation of our new work, so support from our friends and fellow artists is especially appreciated.  With your support, we will create a visually vibrant sci-fi show that uses humour to investigate and discuss difficult feelings that artists and activists alike must go through in the struggle to reinvent the possible. Let's talk about those long dark nights of the soul, through which we must press on, and find hope in the face of despair. In space. What We Need & What You Get
We need $1125 to pay for props, costumes, gear, photography, visual aids, script development, and to cover the cost of materials and photocopies, and mailing out your donor rewards. 

To reward supporters, we have some unique and rare art objects to share, including 10 original drawings by the show's author, and a zine and EP with a silk screened vellum (tree vellum!) cover. Maggie used to draw graphic zines; most recently she has illustrated scientific presentations with Green Neuroscience lab. Treat yourself while helping us create!

Every little bit counts. We will put this show on even if we don't meet the goal. We're scrappy that way. 

The Impact
Lately Canadians are opening up to talking about despair. But what about activist despair, and artistic despair? These are deep blue emotions brought on by a reckoning with outside forces, and one's refusal to conform or give up, even if it seems like the campaign will fail, or your art will never reach anyone. But through art and music we can find solidarity, community, and comfort, even across great distances of space and time. That's what this project is about. 

Together Markowitz and MacDonald have a track record of creating imaginative shows on small budgets. By donating to our new project, you can be part of the effort to create the next one. 
Other Ways You Can HelpPlease spread the word about our show, and tell your friends to check out the Rhubarb Festival and Buddies in Bad Times Theatre.
Thank you for your support!

story:
JR THEATRE COMPANY is thrilled to be producing a show that engages an audience in thought of identity, abandonment, parenthood, and passion.

JR Theatre is an independent theatre company focusing on bringing shows with small casts and character-driven stories to Toronto.

Synopsis: the dreamer examines his pillow by John Patrick Shanley is a surreal, intimate look at the beautiful and dark forces of love.  The play explores the aftermath of love, whether it’s after an explosive affair between two lovers, or the dwindling, harsh lack of love from a widowed father to his daughter. 


Help Us Build Our Dream!

We have had wonderful sponsors in past productions, and this year we look forward to your continued generosity. Out goal is to raise $1,500 with the help of our wonderful indiegogo go-getters.

$800.00 - Department Materials (Set, Props, Lights, Sound, Wardrobe/Costumes, Front of House Materials, Production Meetings)

$700.00 - Printing Materials (Posters, Postcards, Programs, Scripts, Schedules, etc.)

$1,300.00 - Rehearsal Space & Theatre Rental (Fully Paid)
$500.00 - Rights for Play (Fully Paid)

Our team of professionals have been working tremendously hard to put on this show, and we are so excited to share this extraordinary piece of contemporary theatre with you!

Would you like to receive signed posters from the cast? Advertisement space on our website and programs for your business? How about a "Producer" Title for the show? See below what other exciting perks we have for you, our generous dreamers!


The Impact

• You are giving professional actors, stage managers directors, lighting, sound, set, property, and costume designer an opportunity to work in the beautiful world of independent theatre in Toronto.
• Art, be it a painting, dance, film, or theatre can change a person's life - we sincerely believe that with your help, THE DREAMER EXAMINES HIS PILLOW will do just that. We hope this play will keep our audience on the edge of their seats, fully engage, and take from the whole more than just an enjoyable experience. We want to give them a piece that changes their life.


Other Ways You Can Help

Don't got the funds, but still want to help? Wonderful!

1. Spread the word!!!

• Tweet @JRTheatreCo and Hashtag #JRDreamer

• Share this Indiegogo to your friends and family who have a love for John Patrick Shanley, theatre, and sharing experiences of heartfelt experiences.

• Share our Promo Teaser Video (link below) on your Facebook, Twitter, and other Social Media Networks!

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WEvFnAD4oiw

2. VOLUNTEER!!!

Are you living in Toronto and want to see THE DREAMER EXAMINES HIS PILLOW for free?

Volunteer as our Front of House Staff (Smart-Serve Certified Preferred). E-mail jrtheatrecompany@gmail.com with Subject title "VOLUNTEER FRONT OF HOUSE/USHERS"

Thank you, wonderful people! Lots of love from the DREAMER Team of JR Theatre Company!

story:
Hello all you wonderful ladies and gentlemen!

The Indian Students’ Associations at the University Of Miami and Nova Southeastern University are proud to bring to you a brand new intercollegiate Bollywood-Fusion competition, Dance Ke Deewane! However, we need your help to get it started!

What’s Going On Exactly?

We have partnered with the local chapter of the non-profit organization, Project Sunshine, to raise money to brighten the lives of children that face medical challenges. How are we doing this? By creating a new Bollywood-Fusion competition in which teams from around the nation will compete! Dance Ke Deewane will be hosted on November 22nd, 2014, in North Miami.

What Is Bollywood-Fusion?

Bollywood-Fusion is just one of the many types of Indian dances! Particularly, Bollywood-Fusion is known for its captivating and energetic style of dance that incorporates a mixture of Hip Hop, Bhangra, Garba/Raas, Contemporary, and Indian Classical dance. Bollywood fusion has been recently gaining global attention in the media on shows such as America’s Got Talent and So You Think You Can Dance.

Why We Need Your Help:

As you can imagine, starting a collegiate competition is no easy task! We are trying to raise at least $5,000 to cover the cost of the necessities required for the competition. Ultimately, all the proceeds from the competition will be donated to Project Sunshine. The expected audience turn out to Dance Ke Deewane is about 1,000 members - the goal is to raise as much money as possible for Project Sunshine while spreading the beautiful art of Bollywood-Fusion Dance.

story:
Help get Jean Abreu Dance company to China

Jean Abreu Dance (JAD) is thrilled to launch our very first Indigogo ‘crowdfunding’ campaign.We’re embarking on one of our largest and most ambitious touring works to date and we'd love to perform this work in Beijing, China. We need the help of our fans and supporters to make sure we can deliver this latest beautiful piece called 'A Thread', a collaboration with the Brazilian sculptor and visual artist Elisa Bracher. 

Jean Abreu Dance was founded in 2009 and has since established a strong reputation for emotionally powerful and provocative dance theatre performances and education projects across the UK. Our latest performance was 'BLOOD', which toured across the UK in 2013 and which sold out the Linbury Studio at the Royal Opera House London for 2 performances in June 2013. A captivating, multi sensory solo performance by Jean Abreu, BLOOD was a celebration of the strange beauty of life and one mans scientific exploration of his flesh and blood featuring microscopic images of bodily fluids from Gilbert & George's 'The Fundamental Pictures', 'New Testamental Pictures' & 'The Rudimentary Pictures'. 

'Giant cellular patterns of crimson red and sallow yellow eddy and wash around Abreu as he dances. They look wonderful' 

The Guardian on BLOOD, 2013

'A Thread' has been created over the last 9 months working with artists from across three continents where Jean has been in residency, with the visual artist Elisa Bracher in Brazil and with dancers, choreographers and mentors in China, gathering his ideas and materials to make this beautiful new piece, supported by the British Council. At the heart of the piece is the concept of balance, ‘Myth’ and and an investigation into the human psyche, our never ending search for a connection to the 'other', examining the web of stories that reflect our hopes dreams, desires, longing and understanding about the world around us. We love collaborating with artists from other countries, we think this enriches what we do. We learn so much about the ourselves, the work, different cultures and this is what drives JAD to exist; the dialogue between cultures. 

We are working hard to do the necessary ground work to turn our dreams of going to China into a reality. We are asking you for money to help pay for six extra dancers in Beijing, China who have the specialist skills in ancient Chinese martial arts which we would like to incorporate to enrich the movement and choreography.

We have some really special incentives to get you excited about what we are doing by donating to the company gifts from £20 for staying in touch with the company news to £1,000 for copies of a beautiful photographic image from our latest solo performance BLOOD, signed personally by no less than renowned contemporary British artists Gilbert & George and JAD Artistic Director Jean Abreu.

And, remember even if you can't help us out financially this time around, if you like the sound of what we are doing do hit the 'share' button and help spread the world about our awareness campaign. Thank you!

story:
Hi! Do you like supporting new artists as they venture into the performing world? Well, here is your chance!

We are four young artists from the Maritimes who recently graduated from Holland College's School of Performing Arts. 
And we like theatre.
Over the last couple of months, we have been working our butts off piecing together our new Sketch comedy show, "Ladies and GentlemAn...Of the Island". Under the amazing guidance of our director, Jan Rudd, we managed to build and create an original piece from the ground up. 
Over the past few weeks, we have had the immense privilege of sharing that show at the beautiful Guild theatre in downtown Charlottetown. 

It has been a blast so far and we couldn't be prouder of Ladies and GentlemAn!

Of course, the costs add up when you put together a show and we are definitely not made of money. We are, in fact, made of flesh and bones. So to help us cover the costs, we created this campaign!
We think it's amazing that we get the opportunity to showcase original, affordable and accessible theatre to such a supportive community and we'd love to continue down this road. With your donations, you'll be helping us do just that!
Thanks for taking the time to read this! And remember: "You is kind. You is smart. You is important." 

What We Need & What You Get
  • Every cent we receive will go towards paying the cost of producing the show!
  • After tallying the production costs (technician, renting space, and stinkin' HST) the grand total equals 3,000 bucks. 
  • Even if we don't reach our goal of 3,000, EVERY little bit helps! I would even suggest pennies, but we don't use those in Canada anymore.
  • And if we ever went over our goal (I mean, that's like our wildest dream right now) we would use the extra money to compensate those who have helped us behind the scenes AND - put it towards producing more original theatre in the future! HOORAY!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand money is tight - what with the economy and ridiculously overpriced cellphone bills, so if you can't donate but still want to help, here are some ways:

  • Share this link on your Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, etc etc 
  • Come see our show if you're in Charlottetown and tell your friends! And even your Grandma. Because we're pretty sure she'd like it too.

story:
MayDay is a devised theatre ensemble formed in London in April 2012. This Is a Reconstruction, a show about an apocalypse, is our first work together. Please help us make it possible!

 

The Project

'To be honest with you, I didn't expect it all to end like this...'

A panel of gods looks down on where the Earth used to be. There is dancing. There is silence. There is a volcano. There is confetti. There are stories to be found in the search for something missing.

Combining storytelling, dance and live foley sound effects, MayDay presents the impossible task of staging the apocalypse.

Join the young and doomed MayDay for the end of it all.

An apocalypse is a terrible thing to waste.

This Is a Reconstruction will be a live performance of what it looks like when five artists try to put an apocalypse on stage. Beginning with looming apocalyptic predictions inspired by the Mayan Long Count calendar, we are looking into why humans continually predict their own demise and how the world always seems to carry on...

 

Who We Are

MayDay stages impossible situations in order to tell stories about our everyday experiences. We are an emerging theatre ensemble working collaboratively to devise performance. We find different and exciting ways to tell stories; stories that explore what it is to fail and what it is to be human.

MayDay is Anna Clover, Ilayda Arden, Mawgaine Tarrant-Cornish, Jackie Vitale and Jessica Brooks.

 

What We Need

The premier of This Is A Reconstruction will be at Oxford House Theatre in Bethnal Green, East London on 7th and 8th September 2012.

To make the best work that we can and to make our first show a success, the funds that you help us raise will be invaluable. As a young company, we are working hard to realise this fun and fast-paced project. Your help will mean that people will find out about it and see our work. You’ll be helping us design weird and wonderful ways to show the end of the world!

The funds we raise here will be put towards our existing budget and spent in the following ways:

$148 will pay for two weeks rehearsal space in the run up to our show.

$217 will cover our public liability insurance- a must for any public performance.

$125 will go towards our print marketing – flyers and posters so that people know about our work.

$210 will help us create the set for our show and contribute to costumes and props.

So, in total, with your help, we need to raise $700 to make this project happen. Anything above and beyond our goal will be invested in the future of the company and our next project.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can follow us on Twitter

Like us on Facebook

Share this fundraising page

Keep an eye on our work and come to see the show!

And if you think theres anything else you'd like to help us with, let us know!

An apocalypse is a terrible thing to waste.

story:
As we approach the new year, all of us at Adaptive Arts are preparing for our fourth season!

In the past year, we have premiered readings of 9 new plays, two of which have now been published, developed a workshop program and world premiere showcase for a teen playwright looking to pen his unique perspective on Autism, partnered with 3 new cultural organizations to raise awareness, and are now deep in rehearsals for our next production!

None of this would have been possible without the support you have given us. In the past year, you have not only financially supported us as we strive to keep our shows free to an audience who cannot always afford to see theater, but you have donated your talents and time in ways too numerous to count. As we approach 2013, we again ask for your support.


Why Support Adaptive?


"I'm thrilled to be a part of this community of talented collaborators making great art that also makes a difference. Theatre should be for everyone, but few theatres live that truth like Adaptive Arts. Their work doesn't just make theatre accessible for individuals with autism, but humanizes those stories for individuals without. Help keep their doors wide open with a donation today!"- August Schulenburg, Artistic Director, Flux Theatre Ensemble

"I believe in Adaptive Arts because it gets back to the heart of what theatre is: a collaborative art form in which everyone is a participant. Working with Adaptive reminds me of my responsibility as an artist and human being to foster an environment of support, understanding, and creative collaboration."- Christina Kosyla, Educator/Actor

A little about the production your support will bring to life:

Our upcoming production of "All Hail Hurricane Gordo" by Carly Mensch, marks a turning point for Adaptive. This will be our first production dedicated to showcasing a voice that is a bit less than typical, a voice much closer to those on the Autism Spectrum than those we typically see in the theater. 

Nearly 12 years after being abandoned by their parents, Gordo and Chaz have found their own warped sense of normalcy. But, when they begin to lease out their parent’s bedroom, to a young
woman named India, they are forced to question their lives and just what choices they really are making.


All Hail Hurricane Gordo
By Carly Mensch
January 15th-20th, 2013
Featuring: Gabby Sherba, Brandon Johnson, Alex Engquist, and John Greenleaf*
Directed by Marielle Duke
Performances are January 15th, 16th, 17th, and 18th at 8pm and January 19th and 20th at 2pm and 7pm.
The Secret Theatre is located at 4402 23rd Street in Long Island City.

As always, there is no cost for admission, but there is a $15 suggested donation. All donations go towards keeping Adaptive Art’s Educational Residency Programs free to schools serving Autistic Students in NYC. Tickets can be reserved by emailing rsvpadaptive@gmail.com or calling (845) 667 0757. Reservations are encouraged as seating is very limited.
