Our upcoming production of "All Hail Hurricane Gordo" by Carly Mensch, marks a turning point for Adaptive. This will be our first production dedicated to showcasing a voice that is a bit less than typical, a voice much closer to those on the Autism Spectrum than those we typically see in the theater.  Nearly 12 years after being abandoned by their parents, Gordo and Chaz have found their own warped sense of normalcy. But, when they begin to lease out their parent’s bedroom, to a youngwoman named India, they are forced to question their lives and just what choices they really are making.

All Hail Hurricane GordoBy Carly MenschJanuary 15th-20th, 2013Featuring: Gabby Sherba, Brandon Johnson, Alex Engquist, and John Greenleaf*Directed by Marielle DukePerformances are January 15th, 16th, 17th, and 18th at 8pm and January 19th and 20th at 2pm and 7pm. The Secret Theatre is located at 4402 23rd Street in Long Island City. As always, there is no cost for admission, but there is a $15 suggested donation. All donations go towards keeping Adaptive Art’s Educational Residency Programs free to schools serving Autistic Students in NYC. Tickets can be reserved by emailing rsvpadaptive@gmail.com or calling (845) 667 0757. Reservations are encouraged as seating is very limited.

story:
A Punk Rock Premiere

Zeitgeist Stage Company (Boston, MA) presents the East Coast professional premiere of Simon Stephens' PUNK ROCK from May 3 through May 25 at the Boston Center for the Arts. 

Contemporary and unnerving, Punk Rock explores the pressures, underlying tensions, and potential violence amid a group of affluent, articulate, angst-ridden seventeen-year-old students as they flirt, bully, and pontificate their way through their senior year and college prep in a British Secondary School.

Inspired by the tragic student violence at Columbine High School in April of 1999, Punk Rock analyzes the root causes of such violence. Based on the playwright’s experience as a teacher, Stephens describes the play as “The History Boys on crack.”

Help Fund the Show's Physical Environment

Zeitgeist Stage is looking to fund the production values including sets, lights, & costumes.  The show is set in the upper library of a British grammar school.  The students attending the school all wear uniforms, as do all secondary school students in Britain. 

The funds will help create the physical environment, the book shelves, their school books, their uniforms, their book bags, and the lighting in that library.   

More about the Show

Punk Rock looks at the pressures these secondary school students experience as they prepare for their college entrance exams.  An act of bullying results in an act of violence, causing everyone including the perpetrator and the audience to ponder the question "Why?".   There will be talkbacks after every performance with mental health professionals attending the Sunday matinee talkbacks.

Help Spread the Word

Please help spread the word about the show and the campaign.  The campaign runs into mid-May and the show runs until May 25.

story:
Canadian Burlesque

Holly von Sinn, often seen tramping about as the (un)lovable hobo Howard van Sant, is making her debut at The Great Canadian Girlesque Expo in Toronto (Jan 18-19) and then roaming over the border to Bushwick Burlesque in New York.

Branded as the purveyor of bad habits, Holly von Sinn hits the burlesque stage like a tornado across the prairies. With her mix of dance, clown and passion she will make you laugh and make you moan. This red headed fire-cracker is always ready to throw back a whiskey and dance the night away. She has been performing in Edmonton for almost five years and is the producer of the smash hit soloist night Sinners, Freaks and Geeks, as well as Vice President of the Edmonton Burlesque Festival.

Holly has shared the stage with the Grand Beaver Judith Stein as well as April O'Peel, Melody Mangler, Murry Hill, Angie Pontani, Burgandy Brixx and Tigger!. The World Famous *BOB* said she has a twisted motherfucking mind, so raise a glass and hold on to your ass for Holly Von Sinn!

Help a Hobo out!

While hitch-hiking from Edmonton to Toronto would be in true hobo-style, its not easy for a showgirl to drag all her suitcases across the country, so your contribution will help Holly von Sinn achieve this great adventure, and take the great opportunity to not only showcase her talents for new audiences, but to connect with some of the best in the business!

Please help out Holly with a Christmas bonus. The funds will help with her costs of travel to both cities, and in return, there are lots of great perks from sponsors - and even a few treasures from this up and coming burlesque babe herself - to sweeten the deal!

story:
A New Floor for Hubbard Hall

Friends,

We have another great summer matching campaign that will give you a chance to help us make art and community happen far into the future while doubling your gift.

We have recently received $20,000 from a private funder and a few private donors towards the preservation and restoration of Hubbard Hall. As you know, the Hall is a jewel of our community. Volunteers have worked tirelessly for 38 years now to maintain and restore this gorgeous and historic building. It's time we invested further in its restoration, so that future generations will be able to experience this gorgeous space - and so visitors from around the world can see an 1878 opera house still in full operation.

 

Now we are aiming to match this $20,000 with another $20,000 raised from additional donations by the end of September- with the goal to replace the floor in Hubbard Hall by February 2017!

 

Have you ever noticed how cracked and worn the floor is? Ever wished the actors in our plays could walk while talking, rather than needing to strategically stand still long enough to deliver dialogue before braving the squeaks and creaks we all hear as soon as they move? Have you ever stood downstairs and heard the floor shake under artists' feet as they simply move across the space? Did you know the piano started to crack through the floor last fall, leading us to put across a partial cover on the floor temporarily, just to ensure the piano didn't crash onto the first floor?

                  

Will you help us?

You can give online at Hubbard Hall, call 518-677-2495 and give your gift over the phone or walk in during our regular business hours (Tues-Friday 10 am-5 pm). Any gift - $50, $100, $1,000 - will help us toward our ultimate goal of replacing the floor by February. With a new floor in the Hall, artists and audiences will see our community pride first-hand and be able to admire the gorgeous Hall without worry.   Have no doubt - the restoration of the floor is the first on a long list of restoration projects we will pursue over the next few years, including restoring the walls and ceiling and adding better-accessible bathrooms to the building.

On behalf of the entire Hubbard Hall family, and especially the thousands of people, of all ages and interests, who will benefit from our programs in the coming year, thank you again for your incredible support. I am so proud to be the Executive & Artistic Director of this amazing organization. And I can't wait to see you at our next event.

Sincerely,

 

David Andrew Snider

Executive & Artistic Director

story:
About Me:

"She's the raven-haired beauty with legs from here to OH MY GOD!"

From the moment Madeline began studying Burlesque in 2006, she knew she was home. 

    She fell in love with the art, the costumes, the characters...and more importantly, the process. With a degree in Fashion Design and over 20 years of sewing experience (She started making Barbie clothes at age 4), she's always felt that once there’s a concept for a performance, the costumes often make themselves. While she partners with costumer Melissa Coindreau to make her elaborate and dazzlingly sparkling gowns and garments, most of her costumes are painstakingly embellished by Madeline herself with love. 

    Her never-ending desire to learn has led her to study with some of the best teachers and coaches: Her Mentor: Ava Garter , Satan’s Angel and the much missed Joan Arline. In her never-ending goal to always improve her representation of the Art of Burlesque and the Tease that she strives to keep Classic and Legendary, she has also learned from Tiffany Carter, Shannon Doah and Kitten DeVille

    Madeline’s focus in her performances is on creating the illusion that her audience has been catapulted back in time to the 40’s and 50’s. Her characters, cloaked by the authentic make-up, hair and costumes reminiscent of that era, revel in the music and storytelling of years past. She has been called, “Dazzling”, “A legend in the making” and “keeping the spirit of old Burlesque alive”. She hopes to make all of her teachers and legends proud and entertained for years to come!

Experience...

Performing since 2007

Teaching Burlesque and Feather Fans since 2010

Hollywood Burlesque Festival

Las Vegas Burlesque Festival

Awarded "Most Classic" at the 1st Annual Burlympics 2013

Southwest Burlesque Showcase 2013 and 2014

Tease-O-Rama 2012

Colorado Burlesque Festival 2011

Dixies Burlesque Show 2011

Why I need your help

Not only is this my first international festival, it is also the first time I'm performing internationally AND the first time Im going to EUROPE! Yeah, I know! I have never been. It is such an honor to be going to this festival but it is very expensive. It means so much to me to be a part of this for the experience, the connections and relationships I'll be making and learning about Burlesque trends in other countries. I know I will truly be inspired. 


What I Need & What You Get

  • Your contributions will directly impact airfare and transportation, shipping of props and costumes, lodging in London during the festival, festival passes and incidentals.
  • Airfare + Baggage= $1900
  • Lodging= $1000
  • Festival Passes= $250
  • Food + Incidentals= $1000
  • Ground Transportation= $200+
  • If I do not reach my goal, I will apply all of the funds received to the trip.

PERKS!

  • The Perks you receive will be a personal thank you from me for your help in reaching my goal. It has been a long-time goal of mine to perform outside of the US and I cannot believe I am achieving that dream this year. 
  • I will be posting updates on my preparation for the trip as well as daily status updates from London on Facebook and Instagram. You will get to see your contribution in action! 
  • You can get a photo taken by Miss Missy Photography- one of which is below! 

Another perk is for a private class in the art of Classic Strip Tease in Hermosa Beach! 

More photos and perks to come! 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute at this time, its all good! Send me your love, write me a note or post on my wall on Facebook. 

  • Help me spread the word! It's easy to share right from this page!

story:
The P A C’s Landing  – A Collaborative Dance Film

WHAT IS  P A C?  

The P A C, aka Perkins and Collaborators is a project-based collective of an emerging choreographer, cinematographer, writer,  and dancers looking to merge their skills and intellect in the pursuit of a collaborative artistic experience. While the concept of integrating multi-disciplinary art forms in performance is hardly revolutionary, it is a necessity for the creation of newly discovered and thought-provoking paradigms. With this community of artists we look to confront new artist possibilities as we stretch beyond what is familiar. We strive to challenge and grow our understanding of Art and how we present it.  This project expands upon an earlier work, Forward, and is collaborated with new creative architects in the making of a work entitled Landing.

INTRODUCTION

My name is Maxwell Parr Perkins and I am kicking-off a new dance film project to promote active collaboration between choreographer, cinematographer, writer, and dancers.  I am a NYU – Tisch School of the Arts graduate and a U.S. 2011 Presidential Scholar in the Arts recipient.

During an Art History class, I became interested in the historical lineage of American photography and how it impacts our popular visual culture. While stumbling upon a painting created by Marcel Duchamp, entitled Nude Descending a Staircase, No. 2, I was inspired.  His painting was my visual epiphany for the creation of my work Forward.  Duchamp’s painting led me to understand space and how it could be used as a character in my work.

I gathered a group of talented dancers to develop and present my choreographic piece, Forward.  My artistic expression of Forward  was enhanced by the collaboration of music and sound with composer Byron J. Wu, NYU graduate-Music Theory and Composition.  Working with Byron allowed me to add dimension to the piece.  The combination of his musical score with the choreography gave it a new life. While we are both creative people, having an extra set of senses allowed for new information and ideas to flow.

ABOUT  LANDING

In the performance of Forward, the piece ends with the dancers lined-up and walking to the edge of the stage, exiting into the audience. This is where Landing begins. The dancers stumble into the unknown, symbolically free-falling off the stage and into darkness. This unknown reality is metaphorically what humans are constantly confronted with in our daily lives.  As we maneuver and allow the unpredictable randomness of life, it shows us a new sense of balance.

To expand the many concepts being explored in Landing, it seemed logical to create a film of this new work so as a viewer you are able to fully experience the idea of scrambling through the unknown.

In the creative process, I am excited to be collaborating with Jake Saner, Amber Holloway and four dancers.   Jake Saner is a NYU graduate and freelance cinematographer in NYC.  He has invaluable experience filming dance and a wonderful perceptive eye as a filmmaker.  Amber Holloway, a freelance writer, graduate from Alabama School of Fine Art, and fellow 2011 U.S. Presidential Scholar in the Arts recipient, composed a series of poetic verses which act as our narrator and soundtrack to the piece.  Working with Amber helped me set the emotional stage with the audio for the world of Landing.  Her multi-dimensional talents have impacted the overall creative process.  The four guest dancers – Hannah Cullen, Kyle Filley, Mariel Harris, and Jacoby Pruitt, all from the NYU Tisch Dance- class of 2015, bring beautiful expression and movement.

Together these collaborations - a filmmaker, a writer, talented dancers, me as choreographer and fifth dancer are the creative team for Landing.

WHY I NEED YOUR SUPPORT?

Creativity is always restless! This is why I am asking for your support to help fund the works of these emerging artists.  Filming will take place late May 2015. 

The project funding request is $2,460. The funds go towards modest stipends for the collaborator’s time, creativity and hard work, for venue space rental, costumes, and film-days expenses.  

The project is a collective group of emerging, thinking artist in the pursuit of their dreams and goals.  I promise you will be proud of the film and all of the emerging artist. Your investment will be used wisely.

Here’s where the funds will go:

$600 to the Cinematographer/Film Crew

$300 to the Writer

$300 to the Choreographer

$400 to the Dancers

$360 to Venue for "space" rental *

$300 Costumes

$200 Food/Beverage and Transportation

* An additional six hours of filming will occur in public spaces around Brooklyn.

Funds exceeding the goal will pay additional compensation to the dancers and be used for future film festival entry fees.

Interested in our project, but can’t make a donation at this time? Share our funding request.  Follow us on Instagram (@perkinsandcollaborators_) and Facebook. Tell your friends about us.

We appreciate all your support!

THANK YOU.

story:
Our Mission:

At Pulse Theatre Company Chicago, our mission is to ambitiously tell stories, old and new, with a unique outlook and visceral honesty to the human experience. We look to reverently break out of the convention and barriers of archetypes to provide an artistically progressive environment for our collaborators and audiences alike.

Goal:

Our goal is to raise funds in the amount of $5000 or more for our upcoming summer production of Fabulation: or the Re-Education of Undine  Directed by Aaron Mitchell Reese (July 10th-August 2nd)

FABULATION: or The Re-Education of Undine Synopsis

"Knocked up and seriously broke, successful publicist, Undine, is plunged into a topsy turvy world of welfare mothers and drug addicts. She is forced to confront the family she left behind. It's a darkly comic- rags to riches to rags tale of falling down and reaching up to finding goodness within."

Funds raised through our DONATE 5 Campaign will go towards the essentials of our production.

-Rehearsal Space   

-Performance Venue

-Set Building and Props

-Costume Rental

- Actor and Designer Stipends                                                                                                                                                    

What We Need & What You Get

  • In the age of booming crowdfunding, campaigns show up everyday. With this campaign, we are trying to reach 1000 supporters to donate just $5! 
  • The minimum donation is only $5. If you're inclined to give more, that's perfectly fine! Any amount you donate comes with many perks such as discounted tickets, complimentary tickets, tote bags, shirts, signed posters, show artwork, and more! 
  • Pulse is officially a non-profit 501 (c) (3) organization, so anything you donate today you can write off on your taxes! 
  • Even if we don't reach our ultimate goal, any funds raised will go towards our production of Fabulation: or The Re-Education of Undine by Lynn Nottage.

The Impact

  • Fabulation is the epitome of our mission. It is unique and visceral with its outrageous and fast-paced satirical style. It is a hubristic tale that transcends many demographics with a humbling and harsh cleansing theme. Fabulation also provides a platform to break barriers by highlighting an African-American Playwright. In a time where roles for women are growing, more specifically actresses of color, Fabulation provides a great stage for several Actresses of Color! 
  • Pulse Recently raised over $5000 for its inaugural production of A Streetcar Named Desire by Tennessee Williams.
  • People like you keep Pulse going. With your help, Pulse will continue to make a definitive mark on Chicago Stages.
  • Even if you feel you cannot support us financially at this time it would be a great help if you could share the link for the campaign to help us spread the word and get more donations! Thank you for your support of Pulse Theatre Company Chicago.
story_txt:
Our Mission: At Pulse Theatre Company Chicago, our mission is to ambitiously tell stories, old and new, with a unique outlook and visceral honesty to the human experience. We look to reverently break out of the convention and barriers of archetypes to provide an artistically progressive environment for our collaborators and audiences alike.
Goal:

Our goal is to raise funds in the amount of $5000 or more for our upcoming summer production of Fabulation: or the Re-Education of Undine  Directed by Aaron Mitchell Reese (July 10th-August 2nd)
FABULATION: or The Re-Education of Undine Synopsis
"Knocked up and seriously broke, successful publicist, Undine, is plunged into a topsy turvy world of welfare mothers and drug addicts. She is forced to confront the family she left behind. It's a darkly comic- rags to riches to rags tale of falling down and reaching up to finding goodness within."
Funds raised through our DONATE 5 Campaign will go towards the essentials of our production.
-Rehearsal Space   
-Performance Venue
-Set Building and Props
-Costume Rental
- Actor and Designer Stipends                                                                                                                                                     What We Need & What You Get
  In the age of booming crowdfunding, campaigns show up everyday. With this campaign, we are trying to reach 1000 supporters to donate just $5!  The minimum donation is only $5. If you're inclined to give more, that's perfectly fine! Any amount you donate comes with many perks such as discounted tickets, complimentary tickets, tote bags, shirts, signed posters, show artwork, and more! 
Pulse is officially a non-profit 501 (c) (3) organization, so anything you donate today you can write off on your taxes! 
Even if we don't reach our ultimate goal, any funds raised will go towards our production of Fabulation: or The Re-Education of Undine by Lynn Nottage.    The Impact  Fabulation is the epitome of our mission. It is unique and visceral with its outrageous and fast-paced satirical style. It is a hubristic tale that transcends many demographics with a humbling and harsh cleansing theme. Fabulation also provides a platform to break barriers by highlighting an African-American Playwright. In a time where roles for women are growing, more specifically actresses of color, Fabulation provides a great stage for several Actresses of Color!  Pulse Recently raised over $5000 for its inaugural production of A Streetcar Named Desire by Tennessee Williams.
People like you keep Pulse going. With your help, Pulse will continue to make a definitive mark on Chicago Stages.
Even if you feel you cannot support us financially at this time it would be a great help if you could share the link for the campaign to help us spread the word and get more donations! Thank you for your support of Pulse Theatre Company Chicago.

story:
***** DUE TO AN INTERNAL ERROR, DONATIONS FOR THIS CAMPAIGN ARE NOT TAX-DEDUCTIBLE, AS MENTIONED IN THE VIDEO. WE APOLOGIZE FOR THIS CONFUSION, AND HOPE THAT YOU'LL STILL CONTRIBUTE******

_________________

In exactly one month, Kizuna Dance will be at Dancin' on the Edge Studio in Freehold, NJ for a week of teaching classes and Kizuna Dance repertory, rehearsing, and most importantly, creating a brand new work - IKIGAI ! This amazing opportunity will be the catalyst for our first company repertory show in NYC and Boston! 

"The best part was how wild they all danced. I have never seen bodies move that way. I mean this wasn't play acting. This was some serious stuff. Up, down, bending, front, backwards, side and around."

- Freeform Review on Dance-Enthusiast.com ("UKIYO")

            


IKIGAI

Performances: 
Open rehearsal & work-in-progress showing: Fri, Jul 10 at 2pm at Dancin' on the Edge Studio in Freehold, NJ
Work-in-progress showing: Fri, Aug 7 - Sun Aug 9 at the 92nd St Y, as part of Doug Varone's DEVICES Choreographic Intensive.
Full Work Premiere: Fall/Winter 2015 in NYC & Boston

IKIGAI (roughly translated, “a reason for existing”) is a depiction of untranslatable Japanese words through hyper-physical and explosive movement. The work is a study in how language can become movement and vice-versa. IKIGAI treats dance as a language capable of being spoken and written, while simultaneously introducing audiences to the beauty, mystery, and poetry within the Japanese language and culture. 

IKIGAI uses written Kanji characters and the spoken cadences for words found only in the Japanese language to create intricate and interweaving spatial patterns. The performers learn two new ways of communication - through Japanese and through Loft Technique - as they engage with the work culturally and corporeally. 

Loft Technique, which IKIGAI is based in, is a unique blend of house dance, capoeira, various street dance styles, and contemporary floorwork. The combination of these styles allows for movement that flows gracefully in and out of the floor, while simultaneously facilitating the attack and defiant attitude inherent within hip-hop dance. 
As a work, IKIGAI journeys through the full emotional spectrum - from the frustrations of learning a foreign language to the bliss of falling in love for the first time -  while proposing that each of our “reasons for being” is to fully experience the untranslatable and uncapturable moments in life. 

YOUR CONTRIBUTION will go toward providing the full experience for the 7 dancers who are participating in the residency! 


The company will be fully engaged from morning rehearsals to helping students at Dancin' on the Edge Studio learn repertory in the evenings. Don't you think these amazing artists deserve compensation?


                      


                                                   ABOUT KIZUNA DANCE

The mission of the company is to depict aspects of Japanese history and culture through the use of a unique blend of hip-hop, house, and contemporary movements. Kizuna Dance offers the dance community a new and unique approach to cross-cultural productions, bringing relatively little-known parts of a well-known culture through the median of hip-hop vocabulary. This aims to connect the mysterious Japanese culture with movement that is more recognizable and that piques audiences' interest in the culture.  

Kizuna Dance works blend elements of breaking, house and lofting, popping, and waving with modern sensibilities. Artistic Director Cameron McKinney brings his dynamic and idiosyncratic movements to the works, making them resonate with physicality, humanity, humor, and intricacy. 

Performers: Gwendolyn Baum, Brianna Dixon, Reka Echerer, Chelsea Escher, Ezra Goh, Cameron McKinney, Cassidy Samelian

"The talent and quality of each dancer is evident. The male dancers are strong and demonstrate dance athleticism. The female dancers are graceful, flexible, and demonstrate beautiful technique and stamina."

- Freeform Review on Dance-Enthusiast.com ("UKIYO")

What We Need & What You Get

It is crucial to me as a choreographer to provide the fullest experience I can to my company - including actually paying them for their talents! 

We are looking to raise $2000 to support dancers' compensation for the NJ residency, train tickets to/from NJ, August performances! If our goal is reached, we'll also be able to fund our Boston showing of this work in Fall 2015! Your money goes to:

COMPENSATION: Dancers' stipends for a week in NJ (one week away from work is a lot!) and for the August showing.

TICKETS: Covering the cost of train tickets to/from Freehold, NJ

VIDEOGRAPHY / PHOTOGRAPHY: The costs of having the work recorded and also having a trailer for it made, in addition to hiring a photographer.

PERFORMANCE: The initial costs of showing an hour of Kizuna Dance repertory (including this new work created while in residence) AND teaching a master class in Boston

ADDITIONAL COSTS: Marketing, program printing, advertising costs


WHY SHOULD YOU SUPPORT US?

Kizuna Dance is a new company in NYC, but we've already made our mark on the scene because of our completely original, highly-physical, and humorous take on cross-cultural performances. No other company in NYC is doing what we're doing - using hip-hop and contemporary dance to be a relentless and outspoken advocate for the beauty of the Japanese culture. 

This residency project represents a pivotal moment in our rise as a company. We have the chance to share the Japanese culture AND an entirely new way of seeing movement (Loft Technique) to audiences in not only New York, but New Jersey and Boston as well. 

We have the chance to become a major player in the spread of the Japanese culture throughout NYC and beyond. We can only accomplish all this with your continued support and interest! 

SUPPORTING THIS PROJECT ON ANY LEVEL is a clear statement that you value not only dance as art, but also the sharing of cultures between peoples of all backgrounds. 



Risks & Challenges

As an emerging choreographer, I foot all the bills for the company's many endeavors. Working part-time while trying to survive in NYC doesn't leave most flexibility for paying for rehearsals, much less dancers' much-earned compensation. My own personal challenge to continue to provide rehearsal space for this work while staying afloat. Your contribution can help keep the vision of this company alive by ensuring company members receive money for their talents.


OR HELP US THESE WAYS!

  • Add us on Facebook! facebook.com/cameronmckinneydance
  • Share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram - everything!
  • Check out the company's WEBSITE!

story:
Trisha Lee lives in a pink and blue world. Anyone born with a penis is a boy. Anyone born with a vagina is a girl. And that’s just the way it is.

At least, it is until Trisha’s daughter, Jolene, announces she’s genderqueer and wants to be addressed as Jo from now on - sending Trisha into a spiral of furtive Wikipedia searches, reading her bible and asking pointed questions she hopes will put Jo into a category that she understands. You’ve been a girl all your life, how can you just announce you’re not one anymore? 

At once hilarious and heartfelt, Elise Forier Edie's award-winning solo play, THE PINK UNICORN, kicks off 20% Theatre Company’s 10th Anniversary Season and stars Mykel Pennington. Directed by Claire Avitabile, this production takes place at Bryant Lake Bowl Theater for three nights only: September 3, 4, 5 at 7pm.

_____

It is no surprise to anyone that art costs money. In the case of this production, the majority of ticket sales will go directly to Bryant Lake Bowl Theater to cover rental and technician costs, so we must raise funds to cover other expenses, including:

  • the artists
  • postcard printing and postage
  • design materials such as Mykel's costume, props, and set pieces
  • program printing
  • rehearsal space
  • advertising
  • documentation (photo and video)
  • playwright royalties

All of the money raised will go towards this production of THE PINK UNICORN. 

Fixed Expenses: $1400 
(minimal artist fees, royalties, rehearsal space, printing/postage)

Flexible Expenses: $1000
(increased artist fees, photo/video documentation, design materials, advertising/outreach) 

Our goal: $2400

_____

Other Ways You Can Help:

Even if you can't contribute financially, there are other ways you can help!

  • Come see the show, and bring friends! 

  • Join the event page Facebook and share it! 

  • Like 20% Theatre Company on Facebook!

Thank you for your support!

story:
Our Story

The Sacramento acting troupe entitled Amber’s Sweets is bringing the rising cult phenomenon ‘Repo! The Genetic Opera’ to Sacramento audiences by way of spectacle. Part horror film, part rock-opera, the feature film plays in the background as live actors bring the world of Repo! to life on stage in screen accurate costumes, sets, and with plenty of fake blood and gore to drench those daring enough to sit in the “splash zone”.

This stunning combination of film, live theatre, aerial acrobatics and special effects will be held at the Historic Colonial Theatre in Sacramento, CA.

Receiving five stars from the Sacramento Press and the San Francisco Chronicle, ‘Repo! Live’ has been called “an abundance of guts, gore, blood, skimpy clothing, swearing, and audience participation.” and “an impressive, elaborate production that feels like a live concert.”


"Beautiful" - Bill Moseley (Actor)


"Amber's Sweets production value gives both newcomers and Repoites a refreshing glimpse into the Genetic Nightmare." - Nevik Ogre (Actor, Musician Skinny Puppy)


"It blew me away." - (Repo! Co-Creator Darren Smith)


"It fuckin' rocked!"  (Repo! Co-Creator Terrance Zdunich)


"Amber’s Sweets is setting a new benchmark in sophistication. This creative gargantuan was more complex than the original stage production of Repo the Genetic Opera." - Shem Byron, Director and Producer of "The Tutor" Video Series


Please see what we are all about at http://www.AmbersSweets.com


What We Need

We need funding to secure insurance, rehearsal space, venue rental, projection rental, sound rental, and storage for our 2011 season.

story:
Donate directly through Paypal

https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=G89CXCM7Q6C7Q

Donate directly through Network For Good

https://www.networkforgood.org/donation/ExpressDonation.aspx?ORGID2=56-2159087



In February 2012, SpiritHouse Inc will mount a community intervention/production called "Collective Sun," which is part performance, part art exhibit, and part audio installation. Collective Sun shares stories of resilience and hope, for those impacted by the prison industrial complex, and reminds us to love one another beyond ï¿½pieces and public installmentsï¿½ until we can all be whole.

With your generous contribution, we will reach our goal of raising $5000 for this ground breaking work. Your $10 donation will buy stamps to send postcards directly from audience participants to incarcerated members of our community. Your $100 donation will help pay for a teen artistï¿½s stipend. Your $500 donation will turn into a poetry chapbook to be sent to prisoners and an audio compilation of stories and songs by community members living in the crossfire.

Our Story

Over five years ago, a group of organizers, artists, community folk, and members of the SpiritHouse family began using poetry, art and performance to talk about the ways violence, prison and policing had seeped into our homes, our work, our schools and even our trips to the grocery store. We began dreaming about what a community founded in love, where no one gets thrown away, would look like. Moving our desires into practice, we began building spaces where our physical, emotional and spiritual needs could be shared and be met.

The use of art to help ground our visions was natural for us. We had used it for years as survivors of domestic violence and sexual assault, gang affiliated youth, displaced families, drug dependent individuals and those trying to heal fractured families and communities. We used the revolutionary writings of Audre Lorde, June Jordan, Asha Bandele and Ntozake Shange, (to name a few), to look at ourselves, through our own eyes, and to begin building paths toward healing.

With this solid foundation we moved on to writing and performing personal truths. We shared stories about ourselves, our sisters, our fathers, brothers and lovers, labeled offenders continually spinning through the revolving doors of a criminal justice system created to us caged and fragmented. Each performance brought tears and gratitude from community members who found pieces of themselves in our stories.

One 50-year old man at a performance in Oakland, California shared a personal story about there never being enough time to visit his incarcerated mother when he was a boy. ï¿½Weï¿½d visit her and then have to travel 50 or 60 miles to go visit my uncle who was also in prison.ï¿½ Fighting tears he talked about the ï¿½little bit of soulï¿½ she placed in every letter she sentï¿½ and how he still has them all today. Finally he thanked us, ï¿½I didnï¿½t know why I was coming to this workshop this morning,ï¿½ he said, ï¿½Iï¿½m just glad that I did.ï¿½

Mostly rehearsing in living rooms or spaces donated by organizations who understand how vital this work is, and always performing for free, this gift of sharing has touched people of all ages, race, gender identifications, sexual orientations and ability levels. What a blessing it has been to be a part of this bunch of creative Durhamites whose impact is vibrating around the world.

The Impact

Through Collective Sun, families of color gain a voice to proactively address the impact of the prison industrial complex, creating a platform where art and culture become the means for  solution-oriented, civic engagement in local/regional political actions. We plan to present this work in 10 non-traditional spaces, i.e., rural and under-served communities, Historically Black Colleges and Universities, schools and churches that may not have the financial resources to support hosting a 13-member cast and the accompanying workshops.
We will also provide a curriculum geared towards community empowerment, and distribute Collective Sun artwork, chapbooks and postcards with instructions that help families, community members and incarcerated loved ones stay connected.

What We Need & What You Get

Collective Sun needs YOUR help to mount our performance, art show and audio installation. We are seeking additional support to create outreach materials (curriculum, chapbooks, postcards) that will help this project engage a broader community.

If you do not live in Durham or are unable to attend the production we can provide materials for you to begin using our art as teaching tools in your work. Collective Sun is funded in part through an Alternate Roots C/APP award.

For your support, we will send you infinite thanks and various gifts you can check out on the sidebar to the right.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help us bring this intergenerational, multi-media story sharing project to life by:

  • Donating today!
  • Sharing this site with your friends!
  • Hosting a Collective Sun art-making fundraising party! You invite guests of your choice to your home and weï¿½ll bring our art supplies and facilitate the creative reflection of their visions.
  • Donating materials for the final performance/exhibit! {Stamps, fabric, PVC piping, props}
  • Volunteering for performance set up and clean up!

Just send an email to SpirithouseNC@gmail.com to get involved! Thank you so much.

understand how vital this work is, and always performing for free, this 
gift of sharing has touched people of all ages, race, gender 
identifications, sexual orientations and ability levels. What a blessing
 it has been to be a part of this bunch of creative Durhamites whose 
impact is vibrating around the world.
The Impact
Through
 Collective Sun, families of color gain a voice to proactively address 
the impact of the prison industrial complex, creating a platform where 
art and culture become the means for  solution-oriented, civic 
engagement in local/regional political actions. We plan to present this 
work in 10 non-traditional spaces, i.e., rural and under-served 
communities, Historically Black Colleges and Universities, schools and 
churches that may not have the financial resources to support hosting a 
13-member cast and the accompanying workshops.We
 will also provide a curriculum geared towards community empowerment, 
and distribute Collective Sun artwork, chapbooks and postcards with 
instructions that help families, community members and incarcerated 
loved ones stay connected.What We Need & What You GetCollective
 Sun needs YOUR help to mount our performance, art show and audio 
installation. We are seeking additional support to create outreach 
materials (curriculum, chapbooks, postcards) that will help this project
 engage a broader community.If
 you do not live in Durham or are unable to attend the production we can
 provide materials for you to begin using our art as teaching tools in 
your work. Collective Sun is funded in part through an Alternate Roots 
C/APP award.For your support, we will send you infinite thanks and various gifts you can check out on the sidebar to the right.Other Ways You Can HelpYou can help us bring this intergenerational, multi-media story sharing project to life by:
Donating today!
Sharing this site with your friends!
Hosting
 a Collective Sun art-making fundraising party! You invite guests of 
your choice to your home and weï¿½ll bring our art supplies and facilitate
 the creative reflection of their visions.
Donating materials for the final performance/exhibit! {Stamps, fabric, PVC piping, props}
Volunteering for performance set up and clean up!
Just send an email to SpirithouseNC@gmail.com to get involved! Thank you so much.

story:
Greetings.  My name is Rhone Fraser and I am a Ph.D candidate in the Department of African American Studies at Temple University.  I am also a playwright appreciative of the drama of Sonia Sanchez and I am trying to raise the class consciousness of a new generation of artists by presenting to them the drama of Sonia Sanchez.  

I am directing her play DIRTY HEARTS and I need your support to mount this production next month, and spread Professor Sanchez's important message in it.  

Professor Sanchez was one of professors in the very first autonomous Black Studies Department at San Francisco State College in 1968.  She wrote the play DIRTY HEARTS in 1971, the same year that George Jackson was murdered in prison, and the same year of the Attica prison rebellion.  This play is in obvious conversation to the ways that the economic powers-that-be dominate our society and depend on prison.  America depends on prison like no other naton in the world.  This play shows how these powers have successfully created a world that demands subservience to them. When one ambitious businessman, Carl, tries to play their game of power, he discovers a wall that represents the same well-intentioned confront when trying to fulfill the American dream. Carl represents all of us in the American system who are simply trying to make it, and fulfill the American dream.  Within this play is an important story that teaches the nature of the system in which we live and suggests, for attentive artistic audience members, a whole new approach to it.

I need contributors to help us secure a space to tell this important story.  

The funding you provide for this campaign will go straight to our venue, the Adrienne Theater, to secure our performance spaec.  We have unique perks. Contributors in Philadelphia area who give at least $20 will have front row seating to any of the shows they can attend.  Contributors of at least $100 are able to get a program autographed by Professor Sonia Sanchez.

Your contribution will help contribute to exposing the heretofore underappreciated drama of Sonia Sanchez.  It will also contribute to raising the consciousness of a whole new generation of artists that will produce more thought-provoking work.  Special thanks to Jacqueline Wood and Joyce Ann Joyce for their important scholarship on Sonia Sanchez that illuminates the deeper meanings of her plays like "Dirty Hearts."  This project is valuable because it actually shows in a deeper, performative way the powerful statements of Sonia Sanchez.  

Please spread the word.  If you are interested in buying tickets in support of this production, go to:  http://dirtyheartstheplay.ticketleap.com/tickets

We need your help to spread this important story by Sonia Sanchez.  Please join us.

Sincerely, 

Rhone Fraser, Director of Dirty Hearts.

story:
What's the Project?

Nuclear Love Affair is a spectacular investigation of historic events that follows America as she enters the Atomic age and begins her torrid love affair with violence.  We aim to show – through music, media and live performance – the social and political chain reaction caused by the atomic bomb. Focusing on the period of 1941-1969, we aim to decode our nation’s reverence with the atomic age, examining the figurative shock waves of this war-obsessed era and how they still resonate today.  Nuclear Love Affair is presented by Built for Collapse and premieres at The Tank in early May.  

Built for Collapse is a New York City-based arts organization dedicated to building multi-disciplinary communal celebrations that stimulate the senses.  At times an erotic opera, at times a freakish and violent circus, Built for Collapse has been described as a subversive and “creative new approach to theatre.” Founded in 2008 by Sanaz Ghajarrahimi and Ben Hobbs.

The Tank is a non-profit space for performing arts located west of Times Square on 45th Street.  It facilitates new work by emerging performers, designers, writers, directors and producers.


MAY 9th 10th and 11th@ 9:30pm
THE TANK, 45th Street Theatre in Hell’s Kitchen

What We Need:

Rehearsal/Development
  • Rehearsal Space             $650
Design
  • Set/props                         $150 
  • Costumes                        $200
Advertising/Marketing 
  • Postcards                         $350
  • Posters                             $50
Paper
  • Scripts                               $150
  • Programs                          $50
  • Press Release                   $30
  • Other                                 $20
Other
  • Non-profit status                $400
  • Contingency                       $150
                                      Total  =   $2200

In the event that we do not reach our goal of $2200, any money that we receive will go towards rehearsal space and non-profit status. 

What You Get:

    • Thank you on the website
    • Tickets to the production
    • Patronage in all future programs
    • A signed copy of the show's poster 
    • DVD of the performance 
    • Professional photos from the production


Other Ways You Can Help:

Contact us at built4collapse@gmail.com for a wish list of needed items!

Tell your friends!

story:
Short Summary

Hello, my name is Ken Salzman, I am president of SanZman Productions and Artistic Director of The Renaissance Theatre Co. I've been involved in theatre for the last 40 yrs. acting and directing and running different theatres.In the last 2 yrs. we have been working on a project of having a new play produced, called “The Curse of the Pharaoh’s Kiss”. Through a series of readings and rewrites which have been very successful, we are ready to proceed to the next step. I am currently seeking investors for this project to be produced at an existing theatre space in South Pasadena, CA. This opportunity will also give us a chance to try out the theatre space, work with the community and hopefully, continue this success to a future of new and exciting works.

What We Need & What You Get

What we need is $12,000 to rent the space, set and costumes. What you get is a chance to support a new work and theatre that is new, invigorating and an approach to make it happen.

There are some perks - a t-shirt, previews, dinner and openning. But the biggest perk is to be a part of a new show and the beginning of the a new theatre project that will make a difference in the small theatre world.

If we don't reach our goal then we will continue to grow the fund in an account that will be used to see this project happen before the end of the year. What ever we do it will be used for producing new works. Mark my words we will see this project on it's feet.

The new play, by noted playwright, Wade Bradford, is projected for production Aug. 24 to Oct. 7. It is a comedy spoof on the 30’s ‘Mummy’ films. The play, “Curse of the Pharaoh’s Kiss” was written by Mr. Bradford in a ‘Charles Busch style’, with LA and NY award winning male/actress R. Christofer Sands in mind as the ‘femme fatal’ whom we are lucky enough to have involved in this project.

The Impact

The readings of the play have generated positive comments and hopes that it will be seen soon on stage. But we need the support of you, the theatre lover and theatergoer who is interested in seeing theatre with a new feeling of excitement, supporting new playwrights and new theatre works.

I believe that this dedication exists. I believe that this dedication is out there. It’s about courage, intelligence and the heart of the theatre community in the face of these challenges.  And with the help of the excellent team I have put together, we can move small theatre forward. I am completely committed to making the theatre space a creative, groundbreaking and innovative place where actors, directors and technicians can stretch their imaginations. I look forward to working with you. Please take time to give what you can to this theatre project. Thank you.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please let others know of this campaign by sending it to others who might be interested in supporting small theatre. Go to our website: www.Sanzmanprod.com

Also use indiegogo share tools to get the word out!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Raising funds for Music City Theatre Company


Current Production

Songs of a Strong Woman: 

A musical revue in One Act


Music City Theatre Company is based in Nashville, Tennessee. 


Founded by Artistic Director Bradley Moore in 2008, Music City Theatre Company is a professional fringe theatre company. Our mission is to provide the Nashville community with honest, brilliant theatre that takes risks above and beyond what a conventional theatre can do. We will present thought-provoking, socially relevant work with a strong vision.

Music City Theatre Company’s Artistic Director, Bradley Moore, is a graduate of Winthrop University in South Carolina where he majored in Theatre Performance and was honored with the Blair E. Beasley Directing Scholarship. Working on every level of theatre from community to professional, he has been a part of over 100 productions. Bradley has directed many productions including: Twilight of the Golds, Unidentified Human Remains & the True Nature of Love, Anything Goes, For the Love of Broadway, and subUrbia, which he won several awards for.

MCTC's debut production, Songs We'll Never Sing, was presented in October of 2008 at The Lipstick Lounge in East Nashville. It featured three men singing Broadway musical numbers traditionally performed by women. The show was such a HUGE success that it inspired the 2009 production, SONGS WE'LL NEVER SING: BOTH SIDES OF THE STORY which added three women to the mix. 

Upcoming production: 

Songs of a Strong Woman 

Sunday, March 20, 2011 at 8pm
Sunday, March 27, 2011 at 8pm

The Lipstick Lounge
1400 Woodland Street
East Nashville

Tickets: $10 at the door
21 + up

story:
Where the Hell's The Bridesmaid?????  is the culmination of a dream I've had since 8th grade - to write a play that will be performed for people - real audience members - who will laugh, gasp, and cry along with the story.
Being a fan of the mystery with a comedic twist story for all of my life; along with a dream of writing for soap operas (Another World specifically) it makes sense that the elements of a comedic mystery with a dramatic twist - or six - would find themselves combined in my play.  There is laughter, there are What the hell just happened??? moments, there are gasps, and there is a lot of laughter.  The crying will be from laughing so hard - as well as from me from sheer happiness!

ABOUT THE PLAY

Bride demands the perfect wedding. But how can it be perfect when Bridesmaid is missing - shortly followed by the minister? Did Bridesmaid have one too many? Did someone give Bridesmaid one too many - with a "twist"? Is Bridesmaid really dead? A guest list full of amateur sleuths surely guarantees a confession - or something close to it. One murderer? Two murderers? No murderer? Coincidence? Connection? Chaos ensues as each sets out to prove who done it while digging up some deeply buried secrets. As more questions are raised than are answered, each guest sets out to prove they couldn't have done it all the while keeping Bridesmaid "alive" so as to not ruin Bride's perfect day. But what are they to do when the mansions master keels over - right in front of the bride?

An amazing company of fourteen actors and a staff of four will be bringing this off-beat comedy to life during the KC Fringe Festival 2014. 

WHERE THE MONEY WILL GO

With your generosity we will be able to pay for:

  • registration fees
  • copies of the script
  • rehearsal space
  • set pieces
  • props
  • costumes
  • printing of promotional materials
  • programs
  • paying our actors

PLEASE SHARE WITH YOUR FRIENDS

Please share this campaign with your family, friend of friends, enemies, friends of your enemies, and the enemies of your enemies - the more people that know about this campaign the better the chances for success.

LINK TO SHOW SCHEDULE AND TICKETS

The KC Fringe Festival 2014 will be held from July 17 – 27, 2014.

For the performance schedule and tickets to the performances follow this link: http://kc-fringe.ticketleap.com/where-the-hells-the-bridesmaid/details

Thank you for your help with bringing Where The Hell’s The Bridesmaid????? to life – I truly appreciate it!!

story:
What is "Salute to Boots"

"Salute to Boots" is a high quality dance performance organized to raise money and awareness for, The Boot Campaign. This national nonprofit organization is dedicated to Cultivating Awareness, Promoting Patriotism, and Providing Assistance to military personnel, past and present, and their families.

 Produced by Reverie Dance Theatre, the idea for the show came from Reverie's artistic director, Jennifer Gordon. The wife of an army veteran, she's always been passionate about serving our military.

This exciting event will take place on Friday, September 26, 2014 at 7 pm aboard the Battleship New Jersey. It brings together the community and the performing arts with performances by Reverie Dance Theatre, Philadelphia's premiere tap ensemble The Lady Hoofers, Instinct Movement Collective, local performers, a celebrity guest speaker, dining, and more. While being entertained, attendees will enjoy time aboard America’s most decorated Battleship, The New Jersey and take in the Philadelphia skyline alongside the Delaware River.


So what is the Boot Campaign you ask? Well..

The Boot Campaign is a grassroots initiative started by five women from Texas known as the Boot Girls. The campaign encourages everyone to “get their boots on” providing an easy and tangible way for Americans to show appreciation for troops, cultivate awareness of the challenges they face upon return and raise funds for military programs meeting the physical and emotional needs of our heroes. To do this, The Boot Campaign raises money through the sale of boots, t-shirts, and other items. In the process, they not only support our national heroes but promote patriotism to our great nation! More information about The Boot Campaign can be found at www.BootCampaign.com.

What is Reverie Dance Theatre?

Reverie Dance Theatre is a contemporary ballet company from South Jersey with a mission to provide its dancers with the ability to embrace a passion for the art form while working toward artistic excellence. The dance company strongly believes in making dance accessible to everyone and to do so, it is Reverie’s vision to collaborate with local musicians, fine artists, schools, and outreach programs to create a unique experience for audiences in the Delaware Valley.  In addition, a key goal for Reverie Dance Theatre is to instill in its dancers a desire to have a positive influence within their community. www.ReverieDanceTheatre.com


What We Need & What You Get

In order to maximize the donation made to the Boot Campaign, we are doing our best to fully fund the show through corporate and private sponsors. From renting the venue, sound, lighting, marketing, and other show expenses we need your help.

Other then the personal satisfaction of knowing you helped the brave men and women that serve our country and our extreme gratitude, you can receive one or several of these amazing gifts for you generosity! All of these gifts can be viewed in our photo gallery.

  • Boot Campaign gear! (T-shirt, FOBs, and Lapel Pins)
  • Web marketing and social media recognition
  • Tickets to the show!!!

The Impact You Have

Brave men and women serve our country without question each day and often come home for their tours of duty facing many difficulties. Did you know? Nearly 50,000 US troops have been injured since 2001, over 16,000 of those injuries are catastrophic leaving these military heroes with enormous hurdles to overcome when they return home.  The average age of an injured soldier is 23.  Almost 8,000 troops have been killed in action since 2001.  If the average military family size is 4 people, then over 230,000 direct family members are affected by current-day military casualties and loss.

Your donation to make this show a success will make a significant donation to The Boot Campaign possible. This aid will assist wounded military and their families with job placement, mortgage free homes, PTSD counseling, adaptive clothing and so much more.

Help us to show our great nations veterans how much we appreciate the selfless job they do!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

We could use a lot of help to spread the word about the show, The Boot Campaign, and this funding campaign. Reach out to your friends and family via email and social media. We'd love to fill the seats on show day and encourage people to "Get Their Boots On!"

Campaign can be found at www.BootCampaign.com.
What is Reverie Dance Theatre?
Reverie Dance Theatre is a contemporary ballet company from South 
Jersey with a mission to provide its dancers with the ability to embrace
 a passion for the art form while working toward artistic excellence. 
The dance company strongly believes in making dance accessible to 
everyone and to do so, it is Reverie’s vision to collaborate with local 
musicians, fine artists, schools, and outreach programs to create a 
unique experience for audiences in the Delaware Valley.  In addition, a 
key goal for Reverie Dance Theatre is to instill in its dancers a desire
 to have a positive influence within their community. www.ReverieDanceTheatre.com

What We Need & What You Get
In order to maximize the donation made to the Boot Campaign, we are 
doing our best to fully fund the show through corporate and private sponsors. From 
renting the venue, sound, lighting, marketing, and other show expenses 
we need your help. 
Other then the personal satisfaction of knowing you helped the brave 
men and women that serve our country and our extreme gratitude, you can 
receive one or several of these amazing gifts for you generosity! All of
 these gifts can be viewed in our photo gallery.

Boot Campaign gear! (T-shirt, FOBs, and Lapel Pins)
Web marketing and social media recognition

Tickets to the show!!!
The Impact You Have
Brave men and women serve our country without question each day and 
often come home for their tours of duty facing many difficulties. Did 
you know? Nearly 50,000 US troops have been injured since 2001, over 
16,000 of those injuries are catastrophic leaving these military heroes 
with enormous hurdles to overcome when they return home.  The average 
age of an injured soldier is 23.  Almost 8,000 troops have been killed 
in action since 2001.  If the average military family size is 4 people,
 then over 230,000 direct family members are affected by current-day 
military casualties and loss.
Your donation to make this show a success will make a significant 
donation to The Boot Campaign possible. This aid will assist wounded 
military and their families with job placement, mortgage free homes, 
PTSD counseling, adaptive clothing and so much more.
Help us to show our great nations veterans how much we appreciate the selfless job they do!
Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:
We could use a lot of help to spread the word about the show, The 
Boot Campaign, and this funding campaign. Reach out to your friends and 
family via email and social media. We'd love to fill the seats on show 
day and encourage people to "Get Their Boots On!"

story:
update: STRETCH GOAL: $10,000! 

We're so grateful that we've met our bare-minimum goal with your help, So now we're shooting for $10,000! This additional money would mean another invented apparatus to explore, an extra week of training with a coach, or professionally made costumes for the five of us. Can you help us get to our stretch goal?

----------

Hello,

We’re making something. An evening-length ensemble performance – a hybrid of circus and theater – called Tinder & Ash.

It’s a piece about longing. And loss. And rising up from that loss, transformed. It’s a piece about stillness, intimacy, exaltation, and trust. And what better way to explore the tender, brave landscapes of our humanity than the tender, brave, trust-based, and virtuosic nature of circus and theater?

Five of us are coming together to create Tinder & Ash, with an eye towards making theater that’s more physical than a typical play, and circus that’s more honest and intimate than a typical circus act. Circus with storytelling. Theater with circus. Movement and text with a lot of heart and soul.

The five of us are: Megan Gendell, Lauren Feldman, Fe Fox, Amaya Alvarado & Anthony Oliva. Five graduates of the New England Center for Circus Arts professional program.

We’ll be developing this piece in residency in Montreal this summer and in Vermont this fall, with its premiere in 2015.

Your donation will help us cover the costs of space rental, circus supplies, specialty apparatus, rigging, lighting, costumes, set and props, and the human costs of tearing a fistful of time out of our frenzied existence to make a piece of art we’re daring to think is going to be a transformative, virtuosic, and uncommon performance to behold.

If this sounds like a show you’d want to see, and want to have made in the world today, figure a ticket will cost about ten to twenty dollars. Could you support this project by donating one ticket’s-worth? Two? Three? Or more. Or just one. Ten bucks helps. That’s a roll of wrist tape for our duo trapeze act, or an eighth of Aiya’s shoes for hand-to-hand, or a pipe for Megan’s handbalancing canes. Or three bags of feathers for Fe...

We thank you for taking the time to read this, and meet us, and for helping us to make a work of art that’s as muscular as it is soulful, as courageous as it is tender, and as artful as it is unique.

For more information about the piece and the artists, visit tinderandash.com

Thanks y’all!


P.S. No matter how much you donate, even if it doesn't qualify for an official Indiegogo perk, we'll put your name in our program and extend to you our deepest gratitude! Every little bit helps and we'd love to count you among our supporters.

story:
carMen - The All-Male Tragedy

I am a working opera singer who started a music charity twenty years ago to present issue-based opera productions.  Now called Opera Players, the charity prides itself on the quality of the singing and our production values.   

With same-sex marriages being made legal in liberal societies around the world at the same time as homosexuality is being criminalised in repressive regimes, the time seemed right to present an experimental production, an all-male version of an existing work.  Our field is opera and Carmen is the perfect vehicle – it’s even got the word ‘Men’ in the title!  Pared down to just five performers with piano, the focus is on Don José and his journey from sexually repressed and confuses superfan to murderer.

We are very excited by this production and have a wonderful double cast, innovative designers and a committed team.  The audience will be part of the whole experience, invited to be seated on the floor on the very edges of the show, or standing and free to move around during the promenade performance.

What We Need & What You Get

We have decided to launch the production with two weeks in two separate venues in London, the first at The Poor School, King's Cross in July and the second at the Red Hedgehog Café Theatre in Archway in September.  We simply want to raise the capital to hire the two theatres and provide good flyer and poster publicity.

  • The Poor School hire: £1400
  • The Red Hedgehog hire: £1350
  • Print and publicity: £1000

Total needed: £3750.

The performers will all share the box office income, so it is important to us to raise the hire costs separately.

In return, we can offer you a range of small benefits, just to show our appreciation.  You'll see them listed below as 'perks', for donation ranging from just £10 to £250.  Of course, we would welcome larger gifts.  Also, as a registered charity, we can benefit under the government GiftAid scheme by 25% extra, if the donor is a UK taxpayer.

Why us?

We have been going for three years now in our current form and have been particular in returning to venues to build our audiences.  Our first visit to North London last year was a good start, with an average 50% capacity for all performances.  At a theatre in the South of England, where we have been back four times, we now sell out.  people come to us as a company and like what we do.  The team of singers and backstage staff have all given of their time and energy, often for very little money, because they believe in what we are doing.

Our projects are educational within an artistic framework - in other words, we have a message to get across, but we ensure the performance is of a high standard.  We ask audiences not only to enjoy music that they may already know and love, but challenge them to view the story differently, and carMen certainly does that!  In the past we have tackled children and grief with Madama Butterfly and political repression with both Fidelio and Tosca.  And we always offer school or community workshops to complement the performances.

Other Ways You Can Help

Word of mouth is the best publicity.  Please tell people about us and the project.  Our performances are in small venues, catering for audiences up to 100 - it would be great to sell out!!

story:
WHAT IS REBOOT LIVE 2020?

Simply put, it is a return to live theatre. 18 New Irish Plays in front of a live audience.

It is an effort to preserve the social experience of live theatre under pandemic conditions.  Reboot Live brings together 50 artists, writers, actors, directors and technicians to perform 18 new plays over three weeks beginning 25th August 2020, for 24 performances to a live audience of 240. Each of the new plays is 25 minutes long and features two socially distanced actors performing to an audience of ten, who will also be in socially distanced seats.

 

Over three weeks, six triple bills of the new plays will be performed. Each play will have four performances and be live streamed once in the run. 

 

Reboot Live is a back-to-basics approach that has been designed to keep both audience and performers socially distanced. Two actors, no set, telling a human story. 

Even a small audience changes the kinetic energy of performance and enhances the experience. The writers have each come up with unique stories and approaches with the restrictions specifically in mind. 

 

ABOUT THE PLAYS

While the pandemic seems to be the only subject that surrounds us on a daily basis, the plays are not necessarily about Covid19 or the pandemic. Some address social distancing, some are comedies, some dramas, a spy story, a horror story and even a short musical! All are very human tales told by some of the best award winning talent around. 

 

WHO’S INVOLVED?

Some of the artists involved ( in no particular order ) include Deirdre Kinahan, Ken Harmon, Gary Duggan, Katie McCann, Rodrigo Ternevoy, Liam Carney, Gavin Kostick, Pat Nolan, Witt Tarantino, Ciara Elizabeth Smyth, Sean Millar, Finbarr Doyle, Jeda de Brí, Melissa Nolan, Matthew Ralli, Grace Kelley Fitzgerald, Amy Kidd, Peter Reid, Paul Elliot, David Butler, Edel Murphy, Noni Stapleton, Paul Kealyn,  Sorcha Furlong, Aenne Barr, Steve Gunn, Jed Murray, Michael Patrick, Oisìn Kearney,  Aoibheann McCann, Colm O'Brien, Ashleigh Dorrell, Ciaràn McGlynn, Neil Watkins, Sarah Kinlen, Matthew O'Brien, Alexandra Conlon

This is a partnership event with The International Bar, The Events streaming service, THE LOCK INN (www.thelockinn.io), Fishamble's new play clinic, AXIS Ballymun, The New Theatre, DCC Arts Office 

 

THE VENUE*

The International Bar has long been a regular theatre space for over twenty years. It has been used by independent theatre companies and fringe companies. Many well known companies began there. It was where Cillian Murphy and Eileen Walsh were first discovered in  Enda Walsh’s Dublin run of  DISCO PIGS.  Gare Saint Lazare’s Beckett Trilogy with Conor Lovett began there before becoming the worldwide sensation it did and it is also host to the longest running comedy club in the country. Comedians such as Dara O'Briain, Ardal O'Hanlon, Dylan Moran, amongst others began there.

*In order to provide the best conditions for both the live audience, actors and to improve the live streaming experience, we are overhauling the venue to include new theatre lights and sound, fire retardant curtains and other health and safety measures. All efforts have been gone to to ensure the event adheres to current Government guidelines.

 

WHAT WE NEED & HOW CAN YOU HELP?

We need donations. Any amount is appreciated. We are hoping to raise €5,000 to offset costs and to commit to an honorarium for all 50 artists involved.  Despite the current restrictions everyone involved has come together (socially distanced, in person & through zoom meetings) to dedicate their talents and skills to make this the best event possible. 

We would love to be able to offer perks in return for your generosity, however under the circumstances, this isn't something we can do. We can only offer you our heart felt thanks, a shout out of social media and a mention on the online programme.

Alternatively, if you feel you can't donate, you would still be helping us by sharing this link on social media and perhaps even forwarding it to people you know who would be in a position to financially support live theatre during these difficult times. 

Be part of a movement. Be part of a revival.. Be part of Reboot Live..

Thank you!

 

Find out more: www.thelockinn.io/rebootlive.     

#rebootlive

story:
My newest work, The Transfiguration of Benjamin Banneker, is a multi-disciplinary play with a marching band, giant masks, 12 ft puppets,  toy theater sets and moving projection screens. The band is an award-winning group, the Soul Tigers, young men and women who attend Benjamin Banneker High School in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.  Original music is composed by LaFrae Sci, an internationally recognized composer and drummer.  
This play celebrates the life of Benjamin Banneker, a free black man living in Maryland from 1731 to 1806, who taught himself mathematics and astronomy and made important scientific discoveries. In one of his boldest actions, he wrote a letter to Thomas Jefferson asking him to end slavery. In our play, the letter to Jefferson and its response is performed as a drum battle.  His belief that other solar systems beyond our own was remarkable considering he had little access to sophisticated tools and books. A dance with programmed LED costumes brings this belief in the possibility of multiple worlds to life.

 

"With abundant ingenuity that brings to mind the wonders of Alexander Calder's circus, Theodora Skipitares makes of the Trojan War, a central saga of Greek tragedy, a puppet spectacular."
- The New York Times

"Her work is an illuminating exploration into the laboratories of life."
- The New York Times

 

This project has many moving parts, and in addition to paying professional performers, we need to feed and pay the 25 high school students who are performing with us.

story:
Short Summary

Tango is about connection, to your partner, to the music; to move as one on the floor where no one else exists.  It takes years of training and dedication to become a skilled dancer. Tango technique is important; technique frees you and can let you have fun.   I've been a dancer since I was 6 years old. I started dancing Argentine tango 11 years ago and started teaching beginners at folk festivals in 2007. For me to continue to improve and to better teach people I need ongoing  intense training with very skilled teachers. Over the last six years I have been lucky enough to be able to indebt myself to go to Buenos Aires to train with good teachers.
In Canberra there is a very strong community movement which supports tango  without so much of a commercial aspect. The tango club, of which I was president for 6 years, has started to provide models for presenting participatory tango activities that are being picked up by other places nation wide.

What We Need & What You Get

This year, my capacity to  join fellow tangueros travelling to Argentina has been thwarted because  I am paying a large sum of money for my son to join a school trip to Europe. My choice. However I'm unhappy to be  missing out on this regular professional input.

To join this year's group travelling to Buenos Aires, I need $9000 to cover airfares, accommodation, classes and living expenses for about 3-4 weeks for my partner and myself.

Over the years, I've written a tango guide and am in the process of writing a tango manual.  I am a bookbinder, and my intention is to bind the manual with blank pages as well as my text so as to provide space for your own notes from classes.

The tango guide is a short, simple guide of what to do and how to do it in Buenos Aires to have a great time at milongas and in the city. Since I have been several times, it is a working document as I update it after each visit.

As the donation amount increases I can only give of myself: either in terms of my own knowledge and lessons and/or a concise manual. For each donation level I offer different binding options. I am creative and will enjoy making a unique gift for each donor.

If I don't make $9000 at this time, I will keep what ever monies I make for the two of us to go to Buenos Aires as soon as we can save the rest.

The Impact

I take tango seriously; some people start teaching after about 6 months of lessons. I trained and learned for 4 years before teaching beginners at small folk festivals; imagine 15-300 people learning to tango walk! I've taught for adult education and now have a studio in my backyard. To progress as a teacher and as a dancer I need to get yearly high level training, which is not readily available to me in Australia. Granted Argentinian teachers come to Australia, but there is nothing like dancing in Buenos Aires milongas and learning at the source. I would like my beginner partner to experience this with me.

I normally travel with a group of people; it is not always the same people; but I do have a regular travel companion. Paul, and I have met up each year with dancers from all over the world in Buenos Aires during March/April/May.  When new travellers join us, I enjoy showing people the ropes and giving them tips that they wouldn't otherwise get in a guidebook. It is much easier if someone can advise you than to simply venture out on your own into strange milongas in Buenos Aires.

It's hard to blow your own horn, but I've been told that I am a critical figure in the Canberra tango scene. Possibly even nationwide. I encourage people to go ahead with festivals, I make festivals happen (I was co ordinator of a very successful Buenos Aires on the Southern Highlands BASH, last year), I encourage people to become students of tango by getting them to experience different teachers, rather than just remaining one teacher's student.  Tango is  much more than just dancing and going out on a Saturday night: it's a way of life for me .

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't donate to this campaign, maybe you know someone else who can. Please help me by sharing this campaign with people who might take an interest. You might know someone who has never danced tango and who would love to be guided through a journey of personal discovery by exploring the heady sensual world of tango. Or maybe you have just started your tango journey and this could provide an opportunity to see the possibilities open to you.

    I can't believe I'm launching this; it feels weird, but I hope that I can work with you and  make you happy in some small way.

    Thank you so much
    Erika
