experience this with me. I normally 
travel with a group of people; it is not always the same people; but I do have a regular travel companion. Paul, and I have met up each year with dancers from all over the world in Buenos Aires during March/April/May.  When new travellers join us, I 
enjoy showing people the ropes and giving them tips that they wouldn't otherwise get in a guidebook. It is much easier if someone can advise 
you than to simply venture out on your own into strange milongas in Buenos Aires.It's hard to blow your own horn, but I've been told that I am a critical figure in the Canberra tango scene. Possibly even nationwide. I encourage people to go ahead with festivals, I make festivals happen (I was co ordinator of a very successful Buenos Aires on the Southern Highlands BASH, last year), I encourage people to become students of tango by getting them to experience different teachers, rather than just remaining one teacher's student.  Tango is  much more than just dancing and going out on a Saturday night: it's a way of life for me .Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can't donate to this campaign, maybe you know someone else who can. Please help me by sharing this campaign with people who might take an interest. You might know someone who has never danced tango and who would love to be guided through a journey of personal discovery by exploring the heady sensual world of tango. Or maybe you have just started your tango journey and this could provide an opportunity to see the possibilities open to you.I can't believe I'm launching this; it feels weird, but I hope that I can work with you and  make you happy in some small way.Thank you so muchErika

story:
Jewel Casket was originally conceived and written by Peggy Stafford at the MacDowell Colony in 2010.  Last year, Peggy and director Alexandra Aron were awarded a New Georges’ Audrey Residency to collaborate with puppet designer Lake Simons, to develop the world of puppetry in the play. Jewel Casket is currently scheduled to receive a workshop production at Dixon Place, NYC, in June 2014.  

Based on Joseph Cornell’s Taglioni’s Jewel Casket, the play interweaves two stories; one set in 19th Century Russia, where legend has it that the famous Romantic ballerina Maria Taglioni was forced to dance for a Russian highwayman “on a panther skin spread over the snow beneath the stars.” The second story is set in a contemporary couple’s bedroom over the course of a night wherein the two share their dreams with one another, both awake and sleeping. Through juxtapositions of scenes and associated moments within a highly-stylized visual world, Jewel Casket attempts to mimic the architecture of a Cornell box -- exploring themes of memory and desire.

Jewel Casket is a unique theatrical experience -- part object-theater, part puppetry and poetry. During a week-long residency at New Georges last fall, we collaborated with four actors and two puppeteers to create the puppet world for this piece. It was an exciting and productive collaboration for everyone in the room.  The atmosphere was charged with ideas and openness and great deal of respect for what everyone brought to the process.  Lake is currently building the puppets for our workshop production at Dixon Place in June.  We plan to rehearse the play with actors and puppeteers at the end of May for two weeks, culminating in a presentation.

In order to move Jewel Casket to its next critical step, we need funds to pay the artists involved (12 in total), as well as cover material costs for the production and puppet design. We believe that if we can present a rehearsed and highly polished presentation of the play at Dixon Place in June, we’ll be able to launch Jewel Casket into full productions in other theaters, both in New York and around the country.  We need your help to get from here to there! Please consider contributing to Jewel Casket and helping us deliver this beautiful new piece of theatre to the world.

Peggy Stafford’s play, Motel Cherry, was co-produced by Clubbed Thumb and New Georges as part of Summerworks 2012, and was listed in The Huffington Post’s Top Ten Plays of 2012. Her work has been produced and developed at theatres across the country including Playwrights Horizons, Women’s Project, Soho Rep, Two River, Page73, Intar, Circle X, HERE, On The Boards, Seattle Children’s Theatre, as well as The Playhouse in Northern Ireland. Alexandra Aron has directed dozens of new works, including plays by Deb Margolin, Murray Schisgal, Glen Berger, and Carmen Rivera. Her work has been seen in New York at New Georges, Repetorio Espanõl, EST, Actor's Studio, La Mama, Primary Stages, among many others. Her multimedia production "A Night in the Old Marketplace" with music by Frank London has been seen in theaters around the world including Brazil, Denmark, Italy and Poland. She is also the recipient of a Fulbright Scholarship to Argentina. Lake Simons' theatre career encompasses a variety of disciplines including directing, puppetry, movement, scenic design, and performing. Her original productions include: Wind Set-up, Moby Dick, Electric Bathing, Etiquette Unraveled, White Elephant, Alice in Wonderland, How I Fixed My Engine with Rose Water, What's Inside the Egg?, and Paper Plane. Lake is an artistic associate with the Hip Pocket Theatre in Ft. Worth, Texas. She served as a puppetry associate for the Broadway production of War Horse and as puppetry and movement associate for the national tour. She teaches puppetry at Sarah Lawrence College. 

We've set up this campaign for credit card payment - but please also note: Checks may be sent directly to New Georges Theater, 109 W27th St #9a, New York, NY 10001.  Please indicate "Jewel Casket" in the memo line.

 THANK YOU!!!!

story:
Dear Patrons,

Would you consider helping a fledgling theatre company? With the help of generous patrons like yourself, last year we were able to have a successful first season with our production of The Taming of the Shrew. Can we count on you as we prepare for what some consider to be Shakespeare's best and others believe to be the greatest play ever written, Hamlet?

From our inception, we have always believed that we could bring a fresh and welcome addition to the artistic and theatrical community in the Bay Area and the Coastside. With very little overhead and the generosity of Cameron Palmer, who, once again has opened up the Outback for our performance, we can focus our funding where we think it does the most good; with the performers, designers and creating an artistic vision. Last year, through the generosity of donors, we were able to build a stage, pay our actors, rent rehearsal space, obtain our non profit status and stage a Shrew we were all proud of. With growth our vision and needs continue.

  • Paying our actors and crew remains a high priority.

  • Set, costumes and lighting costs are also a major part of our budget.

  • We received some great press last year and we hope to again; marketing and publicity expenses are a large part of our budget and this year through the great work of our new Director of Marketing and Publicity, Hester Schell, we hope to at least double our audience.

 Can we count on you this year to help us reach our goals again?

 Remember, we are a non profit 501 3c organization and all gifts are tax deductible.

 Again, thank you for your support and help to “Let Shakespeare Thrive!”

story:
Hi there, 

Thanks for taking the time to read about our fantastic new project. Prayers for the New World is a theatrical exploration of hope and faith when when all seems lost. We're excited to be premiering this new work in Toronto in the fall of 2013, and we could use your help bringing the show to life on stage. 

First things first. Who are we? Glasswater Theatre is an ensemble of artists dedicated to theatre that explores the hard questions that life asks. We like to dare ourselves with unconventional spaces, stories and performances so that we can challenge our audiences as well. For more about us, visit us at www.glasswater.ca.

Our next project, Prayers for the New World, is no different. We're performing the show in the round at the Berkeley Street Theatre Rehearsal Hall here in Toronto, working with four brilliant actors as we weave two compelling stories together. Spanning 300 years, the show connects characters through time in a powerful and moving way, using text, music and movement to engage our audience. To accomplish all that we hope with this next production, we need your help to get off the ground.

How You Can Help

We've already covered the cost of the venue, and some of our other start-up expenses. As we move into full production over the next four weeks, we need a bit more support for some of our ambitious goals: 

  • The Rehearsal Hall is a beautiful historic building, but is exactly what it's called: a rehearsal hall. We need to bring our own lighting system to the space in order to show off our performers. We have an amazing system of hanging lights planned for the space, but we need help wiring the system. 
  • We also need to provide seating for our audience. Any contributions you put towards the show will help us seat people as comfortably as possible.
  • We always want to pay our artists. In a world where independent theatre often means working for free, we're trying to break the mold and pay our artists for the work they're doing. 

There's a reason that we don't call theatre-goers customers - you're a patron. You are our patrons. Without your support, we couldn't make this happen. Our entire team is already so grateful that you're considering helping us out.

If you have the time, please consider sharing our campaign with others as well. Word of Mouth is the most powerful tool any theatre company could ask for. You can talk about us on Facebook, Twitter, with your mom, your dog (if your dog is rich), or perhaps your friendly neighbourhood theatre critic (tell them that we'll give them free tickets to come review our show). Anything you can do to help us would be much appreciated. You can find all those fancy sharing tools just below the photo above, and visit us on Facebook and Twitter, just below. 

One final time: thank you. We truly couldn't do this without you. 

See you at the theatre, 

Luke LaRocque

story:
What's This All About?:

Wasabassco Burlesque's 8th Anniversary Month arrives this November 2012. Each year our 2 night Anniversary Extravaganza is our chance to give you the most spectacular live burlesque experience imaginable. This year we're extending the celebration throughout the entire month of November and we need your help...

What We Need & What You Get:

An event on the scale of what we have planned requires a lot of advanced prep and up-front expense. We're flying in performers from around the country, booking over 50 other performers and crew to create sexy awesomeness on stage, making props, designing costumes, organizing photoshoots, and so on. We need to start paying for it all.

We are NOT however asking for donations to do our job. Wasabassco is a for profit organization after all. Instead we're using this platform to sell advanced VIP Ticket packages to our November shows. Your money goes directly toward a purchase and we in turn get the funds we need to get to work.

We're offering 3 packages

1) $20 advance purchase Ticket to The first big show in Wasabssco's 8th Anniversary month: November 3 at UNION HALL in Park Slope Brooklyn. It's our longest running show and we're celebrating with an extra long edition at an earlier start time. 9pm doors and guaranteed seating.

2) $50 advance purchase VIP Ticket to Wasabassco's 2-Night 8th Anniversary Extravaganza, taking place on November 9 at CITY WINERY in Manhattan and on November 10 at THE BELL HOUSE in Brooklyn. Admission to both Three-Hour nights comes with guaranteed VIP seating.

3) $200 Golden Ticket with Admission to EVERY ticketed Wasabassco Show for the Month of November, including VIP seating at The 2-Night 8th Anniversary Extravaganza on Nov 9 and 10 at CITY WINERY and THE BELL HOUSE: plus our shows at UNION HALL, THE WAY STATION, THE WASABASSCO HELLFIRE CLUB at the Red Room, a special edition of REVEALED at the Kraine Theater, plus admision to our exclusive Performer and VIP Only Anniversary Show After Party.

The Impact:

With your help we can make Our 8th Anniversary Extravaganza the biggest show we've ever done, and November the most spectacular month of sexy nekkid brilliance ever to hit New York. THANKS!

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you can't swing either of these packages please consider lending us a hand by spreading the word to your friends in the New York area.  

 

*note: In the event of any unforseen or unlikely venue changes or show cancellation, donors will be given admission to alternate equal-value shows and seating arrangements. As this is a fundraisng effort, admission thru these packages is not refundable but may be transferrable by special arrangement.

story:
Our Story

My name is Ann marie Houghtailing and this year I performed my one woman show, Renegade Princess in the Santa Fe Solo Performance Festival, and now I'm headed to New York for my off Broadway debut. I am a single mother, entrepreneur and writer who is finding ways to create a dollar out of thin air, raise good men, take care of my mother, and live my dream. In March of 2011 I went to Santa Fe to write my show and in March 2012 I will be performing at Stage Left Studios in New York. My goal is to take Renegade Princess as far as I possibly can - HBO, are you listening? Fortune favors the bold. This is my bold dream that I'm getting to live out loud.


The Impact

I believe that story telling is as old as the human experience and it is what inspires us and binds us to one another. The ability to create a collective experience that allows people to laugh, celebrate and contemplate the human condition is important work that deserves a platform. Theater has always been a singular experience where a group of people come together and share a story. With your help I will be able to share my story and you will be able to say that you helped take a show to New York and that will become part of your story.


What We Need & What You Get

Not only will I have to pay for travel and expenses for the 2 1/2 weeks that I'm in New York, but I will also have to pay for a Director and Publicist to ensure that my product is in its best and highest form, and that I have the maximum amount of exposure to take my work to the next level. I am also a firm believer in paying people their worth and want to make sure that those who are committed to my success are properly compensated. I will also need to hire a videographer to film my show so that I can use the footage for future promotions and to share with potential influencers. Any financial support is greatly appreciated and please share our campaign with others. The $5000 will cover a large portion of the expenses and I will personally fund anything that exceeds the campaign goal.


Other Ways You Can Help

I believe deeply in community so I am asking that you use the share tools, spread the word and help me take the Renegade Princess across country.

story:
The Cable Car Nymphomaniac is a racy new musical by Tony Asaro and Kirsten Guenther.  Taking a hard and hilarious look at gender roles, it dares to ask "What happens when women want the kind of things women aren't supposed to want?"  Based on the actual events of the 1970 San Francisco cable car sex scandal and set against the backdrop of the sexual revolution, The Cable Car Nymphomaniac is a pro-woman musical ripped from San Francisco headlines.



We need your help to make this show a reality.  Your contribution to this campaign will go toward the costs of production:

Salaries - Artistic, Technical, Front of House: 60%
7 actors • 4 musicians • Director • Music Director • Orchestrator • Choreographer • Designers (Set, Lighting, Costumes, Props) • Playwright and Composer Royalties • Stage Manager • House Manager • Technical Director • Carpenter(s) • Light and Sound Board Operators • Running Crew

Rental Costs : 15%
Performance Space • Rehearsal Space

Materials: 7%
Set Materials • Costume Materials • Prop Materials

Publicity: 15%
Publicist • Photographer • Poster/ Flyer/ Postcard Design and Printing • Bulk Mailing Costs • Paid Listings/Advertisements • Postering Service • Website Design and Maintenance

Other: 3%
Box Office Services • Audio Recording • Video Recording • Script Copying • Ticket and Program Printing



To make this show happen, we need your support.  Your participation means everything!  

  • Contribute to participate in the creation of this show.
  • Contribute to make an investment in this exciting new company that provides locally relevant entertainment.
  • Contribute to ensure that Bay Area stories are getting heard.
  • Contribute because you understand the importance of the arts in an enlightened community.
  • Contribute because the year in coming to an end and you want to make a FULLY TAX-DEDUCTIBLE donation to a non-profit for a 2013 tax write off.
  • Contribute because you want some of the awesome perks listed in the sidebar!  

HELP SPREAD THE WORD! Facebook us.  Tweet us.  Instagram, and Pinterest us.   Definitely send people to foggtheatre.org.  This crowd-funding campaign is not just about us raising money.  This is about your chance to give a voice to the Bay Area.



FOGG Theatre is a brand new non-profit theatre company that commissions, develops, and produces new musical theatre: Bay Area artists telling Bay Area stories.  We tell the stories of our heroes, our history, our communities, our concerns and our ideologies.

The Bay Area is not like anywhere else.  We are a community that is overflowing with stories, and yet these stories rarely get told.  FOGG Theatre is here to change all that!  For more information about FOGG Theatre, please visit our website: foggtheatre.org.

FOGG Theatre is a brand new non-profit theatre company that commissions, develops, and produces new musical theatre: Bay Area artists telling Bay Area stories.  We tell the stories of our heroes, our history, our communities, our concerns and our ideologies.
The Bay Area is not like anywhere else.  We are a community that is overflowing with stories, and yet these stories rarely get told.  FOGG Theatre is here to change all that!  For more information about FOGG Theatre, please visit our website: foggtheatre.org.

story:
What is Short Life of Trouble?

Short Life of Trouble is a new play with songs featuring original text, text by William Shakespeare, transcripts from William Faulkner's public appearances, and the regional music of the South performed live by the ensemble. Inspired by Shakespeare's Hamlet, Southern Gothic literature, and bluegrass and gospel music, it explores the human understanding of mortality, the influence of religious faith, and the tangled complexities of family bonds through the lens of the 1930's American South. With a high theatricality, haunting melodies, and an earthy, visceral approach to language, the play floats freely through time and every characters' innermost thoughts.

This play has been a work in progress since May 2012, taking shape through development workshops in 2013 and the artistic influence of the official cast in 2014.

To learn more about the creation process visit www.shortlifeoftrouble-play.tumblr.com

Co-produced by Lunar Energy Productions and Wandering Bark Theatre Company 

Directed by Eric Powell Holm 

Created/ Adapted by Valerie Redd 

Music by Franklin James Fisher 

Featuring: John Egan, Gregory Isaac, Sheila Joon*, Suzy Kohane*, Michael Markham*, Joseph Mitchell Parks*, Valerie Redd*, Brendan Spieth*, Andy Talen 

* appears courtesy of Actors' Equity Association

Who are we?

Lunar Energy Productions is a New York based theatre company dedicated to transformation- playing with perspective and context to illuminate the unexpected in the familiar, the mythic in the mundane. We challenge ourselves and our audiences to reevaluate their assumptions of the classics, myths, modern ideas, and of the theatre itself.

www.lunarenergyproductions.com

Wandering Bark Theatre Company is a New York based theatre company that produces classical theatre with an unexpected perspective, shining a light on how these works remain relevant and speak to contemporary audiences.

www.wanderingbarktheatrecompany.org


How can you help?

Every donation we receive will go directly to fund production costs.

  • theater rental

  • set, props, lights, sound and costumes
  • marketing expenses
  • artist stipends

Lunar Energy Productions holds non-profit status via Fractured Atlas. 

If you would like to make a tax deductible donation to Short Life of Trouble you may do so at https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/profile?id=2239

All donations made via Fractured Atlas will receive the same reward perks as donations made via indiegogo.

All donations received via Fractured Atlas and indiegogo will be used solely to fund the production of Short Life of Trouble.

Your contribution can make a world of difference as we rely on the generosity of donors like you to help bring these artists' vision to life!


"There's a divinity that shapes our ends,
Rough-hew them how we will."
                -Hamlet, Act V sc. ii


"There must be some universal electricity that holds this ramshackle earth together."
               - William Faulkner, interview transcript, 1957

story:
Who are we?


The Human Animal is a theatre collective which emerged from the University of Warwick in 2012. Our ethos as theatre-makers seeks to put the human being and consciousness at the centre, emphasising artistic collaboration as we produce, direct, devise and perform our own work as an ensemble. 

Our previous projects have harnessed various creative forms. In our inaugural two productions, Lovely Rita and Women War Lustgames (Act I), we interrogated the post-war human and nature of repeated human error. By exploring the lyrical texts of Thomas Brasch, we challenged how a German playwright’s work can be made relevant and engaging for an English-speaking audience. In our next project we delved into the world of online connection as a space for making theatre in Virtual Tourist. Entirely internet-based, the piece served as a commentary highlighting how modern technology has devalued face-to-face communication.

With a continued fascination with technology as a driving force in how we form human connections today, we are pursuing work that is  immersive and in promenade to interrogate perceptions of nature against virtual connection in our developing production of Wastwater.

First official meeting of the Wastwater Team!

The Wastwater  Team

ENSEMBLE

Michael Chidgey
Juliet Miriam Clark
Bryony Davies
Maria Hildebrand
Alex Welsh
Samuel Wightman

PRODUCTION TEAM

Jamie Wright - Producer
India Smith - Set Designer
Emma Digby - Stage Manager


What is Wastwater?


The Human Animal is taking a production of Wastwater by contemporary British playwright Simon Stephens at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe 2014. We will be performing at C nova from July 30th to August 16th.

'The people here feel so lonely that they need a television to remind them that there's a world outside'. 

A mother and son. A pair of lovers. A supplier and her client. On the edges of Heathrow Airport, six lives threaten to blow apart. Upon closer inspection, these seemingly conventional relationships will tilt our understanding of human interaction in a world pervaded by technology. Written by one of the UK's leading playwrights, Simon Stephens' Wastwater is an episodic portrait of the individual on the brink of monumental change. In this promenade production, The Human Animal invite you to explore, touch and trace the world of Wastwater, guiding you through airport security in promise of a flight that will never take off.

The concept of Wastwater emerged through witnessing recent theatre work involving promenade, immersive and site-specific work. From our experiences as audience members of immersive theatre, we value it as a visceral and reflexive form to get individuals to engage with the society they live in and the world around them. Crucially for us, Stephens’ play throws up many ideas for commentary with relevance to the state of society today and how we can find genuine communication in a digital age. We are hoping our production will successfully bridge the gap between contested issues around technology and surveillance, and how these issues are manifested in the audience’s own lives.

The piece will be created by the ensemble, where pairs perform a scene and also direct one of the others together. We believe that by having fluid role distinctions, there is increased artistic ownership over the project from each member of the company and similarly a more cohesive way of working as an ensemble.

The first look at our publicity designs at our installation at the Warwick Student Arts Festival 2014.


Why do we need funding?

The Edinburgh Fringe is an invaluable platform for breaking through to the professional world, however it is very expensive to put on a show at the festival.

As a new student theatre company, we rely 100% on outside funding and bursaries in order to produce our own work. Without this support, we would be unable to take Wastwater to Edinburgh and we would miss out on an opportunity to gain exposure and get our work seen by a wider audience outside of Warwick.


How will we use your funds?


Everything that we raise will go straight back into funding the production, specifically financing the costs for production design and set transportation costs.

Wastwater uses a promenade structure, where the audience will move across three rooms, each housing it's own distinct environment. Once the audience has watched one of Stephens' scenes they will be led through an interactive transitional space; each one representing a different stage of air travel (check-in, security and duty free). Once the audience passes through all three rooms they will then be led back through to find they have been transformed to be completely new spaces.

All the spaces will encourage a high level of interactivity for audiences. The three written scenes take place in very distinct environments: a greenhouse, a hotel room and finally an abandoned warehouse. We want each of these to be suggested through details which play with the notion of authenticity. Rather than being realistic spaces, they are often facilitated by technology and represented through artificial means.

Mood board for the 'greenhouse' space in Scene 1.

 Set Design: Scene 1

Set Design: Scene 2

 Set Design: Scene 3

Risks and Challenges

There are a multitude of challenges which any fledgling theatre company faces when mounting a production. But at the Fringe these can be significantly magnified. Last Summer alone Ed Fringe saw just under 3,000 shows taken up and this year promises to be the biggest Fringe ever. We are confident Wastwater has a number of unique qualities that will stand out amongst others, but we need your help too! These are just a few of the challenges and risks your money could help us avoid.

- The Human Animal as a theatre collective has been set up entirely off our own back. As a group of young people still in full-time education, we lack any real capital to create the financial foundation of a show like Wastwater and ensure it reaches the level of desired quality.

- One of Wastwater’s biggest selling points is our in-depth, immersive set design. Ranging from dozens of intricate pieces like letters, clothing and plants, to tech equipment - importantly a projection system. The ‘immersive’ quality is vital to our interpretation of the piece, but will be very costly.

- Transporting the set will also be a major challenge. Our company is primarily based in the Midlands thus getting all our resources and materials to the Fringe (and then back again) will cost a large amount.


Thanks so much for visiting this page. Anything you can give us will be a huge help ensuring Wastwater is a huge success and allowing our company to continue producing exciting work.
Love,
The Human Animal x

The Animals party, 80's style. (Left to right) Bryony, Sam, Jamie, Michael, Juliet and Alex.

story:
Short Summary

For more than 5,000 years, the Ramayana tale of Lord Rama's life and exploits has spread across the world.  It is very familiar to many parts of the world, for example, India, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Indonesia, Myanmar (formerly Burma), Vietnam, Cambodia, Philippines, Mauritius, Fiji, many countries in the Caribbean and some in South America – such as Guyana.

Briefly stated, Ramayana is an epic love story between Lord Rama of Ayodhya and his wife Sita. It tells stories of devotion, trust, loyalty to the truth, and has been told and retold by saints, poets, scholars, and performers for generation. Though few North Americans realize it, the Indian Festival of Lights or Divali (or Diwali) stems from Ramayana.

This year, the Ramayana Dance Drama is being presented by the International Ramayana Institute of North America (IRINA) for the 11th time. 

The mission of IRINA (a registered not for profit organization based in Illinois) is to promote the Culture, Arts and Knowledge of Ramayana. The biannual event depends solely on volunteer planners and participants and the previous ten performances have spanned across 15 years. This is a testimony of the shared passion and dedication of numerous dancers and musicians. At the event, three countries - India, Indonesia and Thailand - members of IRINA perform side by side to create a magical night for the spectators; each delivering their own interpretation of this ancient story.

However, IRINA  has faced significant challenges. As is common in many immigrant families, the younger generations are not as attached to traditions as previous generations. As the interest of preserving the culture diminishes, so do other aspects that support it. During our last two performances, IRINA has depleted its savings and our founding members are concerned without the support of a much wider public, this great institution will cease to exist. We don’t want the great story of parents bringing their children to have fun learning about unique dances and musical instruments to recede into distant memories. 

What We Need & What You Get

Our campaign is trying to raise $1,750 to cover the cost of renting the stage and other necessary equipment to produce the show. This will free up IRINA's limited resources to be allocated for other expenses such as providing food for musicians and performers at the event, transporting the musical instruments to and from the venue, and other public relations related costs.

We offered many different and exciting perks for every level of donation:

- Photograph of the performers

- Video of performances of the Ramayana Dance Drama

- Ramayana crafts

- Children book about Ramayana (artist and veteran Pixar animator Sanjay Patel lends a lush, whimsical illustration style to this lighthearted book about one of Hindu mythology's best-loved and most enduring tales)

- A collection of US-handmade Ramayana-themed peg dolls

- Ramayana art books. 

The Impact

The success of raising fund means more than just delivering a performance. It will mean a renewed passion in all of the senior artists and scholars involved in this effort since the 1st Ramayana Dance Drama, and also an affirmation that what they believe in, is something worth preserving. 

If we raise more than we need, we will use the extra funds to cover the cost of providing food and beverages to our musicians and dancers during the event as well as provide seed funds for our future conferences and presentations of Ramayana

Other Ways You Can Help

We are forever in debt to you if you could spread the words and make some noise about our campaign! Please know that by sharing this campaign with your friends you are helping us reach and perhaps exceed our goal. 

T H A N K  Y O U

BAHUT DHANYAVAAD (Hindi) - KOB KUN MAK (Thai) - TERIMA KASIH (Indonesian)

story:
The Nitty-Gritty: 

About Dear Armen: An audience-immersive theatre experience inspired by the life of Armen Ohanian, an enigmatic Armenian dancer and poet who survived early 20th-century anti-Armenian pogroms. Integrating traditional Armenian dance, erotic performance, and spoken word, Dear Armen follows young researcher Garineh, as she delves into the life and art of Ohanian in search of a role model and mentor and begins unraveling questions about her own gender, sexuality, ethnicity, family, and the role of the artist in modern life.

About the team: Saboteur Productions was founded in 2013 by long time Canadian collaborators Kamee Abrahamian and Tiffany Golarz. Their first joint venture, the Blood Ballet Cabaret (est. 2010) allowed them to create and produce original theatre work as well as nurture like-minded performers to freely develop their artistry on a more experimental platform. Saboteur Productions is currently focused on developing a body of work that can be described as audience-interactive, site-specific theatre that blends dance, circus, physical theatre and spoken word. Their most recent creation - Dear Armen - is a collaborative work produced with lee williams boudakian, an interdisciplinary artist, activist, writer, and performer based in Vancouver, unceded Coast Salish Territories.

Saboteur Productions has been invited to present Dear Armen for a 6-night run at the Alwan for the Arts centre in NYC this May. This campaign will cover the travel and accommodation costs for the team to be able to make it there. 

The goal here, other than producing Dear Armen in one of the most competitive performing arts scenes in the world, is to grow this work, develop it, build community around it, and hopefully attract the right kind of attention to the show in order to open up more opportunities for bookings in the future. 

We are grateful for your support!

What & Why:

We need $3000 to cover our production costs. This includes our accommodation and our travel to and from NYC. We aren't being fancy about it either - we're taking the bus, and we are renting a studio apartment in Harlem (there are three of us...) so this is just the bare minimum.


Director's Note:

It is important to recognize that Ohanian’s story, which can be compared to the likes of inspirational figures such as Sarah Bernhardt and Frida Kahlo, is quite contemporary even for current times. It has the potential to appeal to a universal audience as well as Armenians. That being said, the desired impact of this project is to engage the prolific dynamism of the Armenian woman and nurture the progression of a pivotal social issue that is prevalent in the frontlines of contemporary cultural discourse in Armenia. My goal is to co-create a piece of interactive theatre that will transfer these strengths, whether they be considered sensual, artistic, maternal, or mystical, to audiences who will walk away feeling energized and moved by Ohanian’s legacy. If these goals are met, I can only hope that those who are inspired will embody this experience in their own lives and pay it forward – to loved ones and strangers alike – therefore taking one step closer to the transformation and evolution of women’s issues and the future of Armenian culture. 

No money? No problem:

If you can't afford to donate, that's alright. Help us spread the word. Every share counts.

story:
Chicago Repertory Ballet NEEDS YOU!

Chicago's newest dance company needs your partnership to produce our first performance! 

Founded on October 13th 2011, Chicago Repertory Ballet brings together seasoned dancers, choreographers and designers into a collaborative process to produce concert dance, to the stage.

We are passionate about bringing dance from a contemporary perspective to our local community, and over time, to the community at large. We believe that the artistic voices of today have much to say, and it is our mission to bring you dance from a new generation in both the abstract and the story format.

YOU CAN BRING THE ARTISTIC VOICE OF THIS GENERATION TO LIFE!

 

OUR NEED

Chicago Repertory Ballet will produce it's first performance at the Ruth Page Center for the Arts on September 21st. and 22nd. There are many costs that we have to meet to produce this performance.

THE BREAKDOWN:

Theater Rental - $1,450

Deposit - $500

Lighting Fees - $500

Guest Choreography Fees - $500

Costumes (Design and Materials) - $2,300

Dancer Fees - $1,800

Dance Studio Rentals - $950

Insurance - $425

Box Office - $200

Headset Rental - $30

Posters/Publicity - $250

Grand total = $8,905.00

 

As you can see, our needs far exceed what we are asking for in this campaign, so if you are able to help us EXCEED our goal, that would make a HUGE impact on our future!

 

What do you get?

Check out the sidebar to see the great perks for your contributions!

 

YOUR CONTRIBUTION IS EVERYTHING TO US!


As we are a brand new company of artists, we have been operating SOLELY on donations from people like you. Man power for grant writing is too small right now, and we are all hands on deck just to produce the artistic and administrative aspects of this project.

Without your help, we literally can not make it to the stage.

 

We are very concerned with fully funding this campaign. As nothing in life is free, neither is this campaign. Sould we not make our campaign goal, Indiegogo will take a heftier percentage of the donation dollars, so PLEASE help CRB reach it's $4,500, and make every donation count!

Other Ways of Helping

If you're not able to make a financial donation, we absolutely validate and respect that. You can support CRB by taking a quick moment to go to our facebook page and click 'like', or follow us on twitter  @chirepballet.

http://www.facebook.com/Chicagorepertoryballet

https://twitter.com/ChiRepBallet

PLEASE SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN WITH FRIENDS COLLEGUES AND LOVED ONES!

Word of mouth endorsement is the best promotion we can get! If aren't able to help support our venture financially, you just may know someone around you who can.

THANK YOU SO MUCH for taking the time to read this campaign, and considering support!
story_txt:
Chicago Repertory Ballet NEEDS YOU!
Chicago's newest dance company needs your partnership to produce our first performance! 
Founded on October 13th 2011, Chicago Repertory Ballet brings together seasoned dancers, choreographers and designers into a collaborative process to produce concert dance, to the stage.
We are passionate about bringing dance from a contemporary perspective to our local community, and over time, to the community at large. We believe that the artistic voices of today have much to say, and it is our mission to bring you dance from a new generation in both the abstract and the story format.
YOU CAN BRING THE ARTISTIC VOICE OF THIS GENERATION TO LIFE!
 
OUR NEED
Chicago Repertory Ballet will produce it's first performance at the Ruth Page Center for the Arts on September 21st. and 22nd. There are many costs that we have to meet to produce this performance.
THE BREAKDOWN:
Theater Rental - $1,450

story:
"Shoreditch Madonna" is a play about visual artists living in the East End of London, England in modern times, but its essence is about the universal desire among all beings for meaningful relationship and meaningful work.

We have a great play, a great space and a talented cast.  Rehearsals are well under way and a great deal of the work has already been done.  Now is the time when we could stand to benefit from your financial contributions.

The Bottom Line

Here is why our production would benefit greatly from your donations:

  • 3 weeks theatre rental = $4500
  • 3 weeks rehearsal space = $900
  • performance rights to the play = $800
  • advertising costs = $600
  • set building materials/lighting = $700
  • flight for Sasha Higgins = $500

Without including miscellaneous costs our budget is already at $9000.  This is with all of the actors, designers and crew members volunteering all of their time.

Yes.  We plan on making some of that money back. 

Here's the math:

If we sold out all 60 seats for all 13 nights of the show at $20 a ticket we could make $15,600.  That's a $6,600 profit.  Divided by 9 people equally that's $750 for a month and a half of work.  Less than minimum wage, but not a bad stipend.  The likelihood, however, and a good standard for independent theatre is to bank on selling 1/3 of your house for the average of the run.  While we aim to reach a much greater audience than that, by many standards an average audience of 20 people a night would be considered a success.  Such a scenario could leave us with a loss of $3,800. 

Your generosity will allow us to cover some of our basic costs without risking a loss on the production.

The illustrious cast includes:

Earl Pastko as the enigmatic and tortured painter Devlin               

Lina Roessler as Martha, who is a self-described ghost of his past

Jimi Shlag, Robbie Beniuk, and Sean Connelly Affleck as Michael, Nick and Hodge - three emerging artists curating a gallery together in an abandoned space

and Sasha Higgins as Christina, a young woman in mourning

A note from the director:

8 years ago I was given a play entitled "Shoreditch Madonna" by my friend Sasha Higgins.    I didn't know what the title meant but I was intrigued...  I was surprised to discover a play richly drawn on the search for meaning that encompasses our lives.  This is a play about visual artists living in the East End of London, England in modern times, but its essence is about the universal desire among all beings for meaningful relationship and meaningful work.  Through an intimate glimpse into the fluctuating private lives of artists the play reveals how our creative impulses are interwoven with the fabric of our deepest sense of identity and our emotions.

For the many years I have been an actor  I have imagined myself directing a play.  I love the theatre and I love working with actors.  I don’t know why I’ve waited so long.

Since I began the process of producing and directing this play, I have been surprised by the generosity of the world.  Again and again, friends and strangers have been willing to help in whatever ways they can… Giving advice about producing independent theatre in Toronto, shooting and editing video, organizing rehearsal schedules, finding space, acting, suggesting actors, painting and building sets, providing props, taking pictures, etc, etc.  Where there is work to be done people step up and provide what they can.  This has deepened my connection to my community at large and to my friends...  Where I had once convinced myself the doors were closed, I am learning to see opportunity and relationship.

Thanks for your support,

Justin Tensen

story:
All Our Happy Days Are Stupid by Sheila Heti

A play by Sheila Heti with songs by Dan Bejar
Directed by Jordan Tannahill
October 24 - November 3 (no performance October 28), 8pm
Video Fag 187 Augusta Ave, Toronto ON

Indie theatre company Suburban Beast is producing the long-anticpated world premiere of novelist Sheila Heti's debut play All Our Happy Days Are Stupid. The show will run from October 24 – November 3, 2013 at Videofag, director Jordan Tannahill's intimate Kensington Market storefront theatre. Featuring songs by acclaimed musician Dan Bejar (Destroyer), Set Designs by Rae Powell, and a cast of Sheila and Jordan's friends, this uproariously unwieldy new play is an irreverent and gut-punching critique of the pursuit of happiness. 

Sheila Heti recently published the novel How Should a Person Be? which was nominated for The Women’s Prize for Fiction (formerly The Orange Prize) and named a Best Book of the Year by The NewYork Times Book Review, The New Yorker, Salon and other places. 

After years of the script being passed over by established theatres, largely on account of it's unusual form and massive cast, Sheila and Jordan decided to gather together a group of their friends for a reading of it in a friend's backyard. As Sheila said in a November 2012 Globe and Mail article, at the backyard reading 'the things that just never worked, somehow they worked." 

We are a bunch of professional artists taking time away from our jobs and joe jobs to take part in this once in a life time collaboration. It is in this spirit of gathering friends together to do the impossible that the piece will have it's birth at Videofag this fall.

We would have it no other way. Join us. Celebrate with us. 

http://www.suburbanbeast.ca/all-our-happy-days-are-stupid

Tickets available here:
http://allourhappydaysarestupid.eventbrite.ca/

Contact organizer please email renna.reddie@gmail.com

story:
THE STORY: The Valley Isle serves as the backdrop for this tale of relationships attempting to navigate rough waters.  When straight-laced Stanley takes his estranged wife, their recent college grad daughter and her milquetoast fiance' to Maui - what should be a celebratory trip quickly turns ugly.  The group finds themselves rooming next to a homosexual couple who have traveled to Hawaii to get married, but soon find their relationship is starting to show cracks as well.  It's only with the help of an overbearing ex-Flamenco dancer, that the couples realize that it's facing the challenges of relationships head-on that will steer them through rough seas and enable them to land on calmer shores.

 

This script has been in development since 2008 and after several workshop situations is finally ready for an audience.  The city of Denver was instrumental in helping it get to where it is and they deserve to have the World Premiere.

story:
The Offstage Podcast and Me

I am an actor and host of the Offstage Podcast, from Toronto Canada. I was inspired to create the podcast by the Downstage Center podcast that was hosted for many years by Howard Sherman. I loved the podcast, but Canadian voices were few and far between. I wanted to create something similar with a focus on Canadian theatre, and thus the Offstage Podcast was born.

Because I live in Toronto, most of the people I have interviewed have been from Toronto, but I’ve always intended the podcast to be about Canadian theatre, and while it is possible to interview people via skype, nothing replaces a face to face conversation.

To that end, I’m going to Montreal in June for the Montreal Fringe Festival, and I’m going to interview people involved in the Festival, from Festival staff, to actors and directors and playwrights involved with the Festival, and even a few of the volunteers.

Going to Montreal will increase the diversity of voices that I've been able to interview, and will extend the reach of the podcast allowing me to tell more stories in Canadian theatre.

Every cent raised will go towards this trip.

What We Need & What You Get

I need $500 to cover accomodation, travel and food while in Montreal. The closer I get to the goal, the longer I can stay in Montreal and the more people I can interview. Even if I don't reach the goal, I will still be going to Montreal and recording as many podcasts as possible, I will only be able to go for a day or two, which means I won't be able to interiview as many people as I want.

I have some perks to offer, from a simple thank you on the website, being a part of a list of sponsors read out on the Montreal Fringe series of podcasts, to direct thanks and a message selected by you read on the podcast.

The Impact

The Offstage Podcast is my attempt to get as many voices as possible talking about their lives in the theatre. As the podcast grows, I intend to travel further and increase the national diversity of the voices I'm able to have as guests on the podcast.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help financially, please help get the word out by tweeting, sharing and generally talking about the campaign. Every bit helps.

story:
Dear Friends,

I have been invited to premiere a brand-new 25 minute dance on the Inside/Out Stage at the 80th Anniversary Season of Jacob's Pillow. This is an honor both thrilling and humbling.

Jacob’s Pillow is the oldest internationally acclaimed summer dance festival belonging to the United States. In 2003, its organization was recognized as a National Historic Landmark and remains the only such site in the field of contemporary dance. In 2010, President Barak Obama presented Jacob’s Pillow the distinction of being the first dance institution of its kind to receive the prestigious National Medal of Arts.

Dubbed “the dance center of the nation” by The New York Times, Jacob’s Pillow draws nearly 80,000 visitors to its magical habitat in the Massachusetts Berkshires annually. Its foundation maintains a clear and effectual mission to foster “dance creation, presentation, education, and preservation; and to engage and deepen public appreciation and support for dance.” My participation in the 2012 Inside/Out series and the public feedback discussion conjoined with our performance offers my dance theater ensemble the opportunity to exchange with a diverse and unfamiliar audience and community. Furtheremore, I create dance to connect. I believe in the power of disclosure; the moment of vulnerability when the stage bares all and the audience can put themselves on the inside. Moreover, my art transpires from the personal. It is the collective “I” panting, soaring and stumbling hard before you, as you sit and watch my performance transcend from the street to the stage.

The funds raised by this campaign will directly facilitate the specific creation and production of my most recent work, entitled Learning to forget and other tragic fortunes.

Key expenses include:

  • Necessary travel and accommodation for our 3-day excursion taking us from the hubbub of New York City to the Berkshire mountains of Western Massachusetts.
  • Security for essential rehearsal time and space rentals.
  • Original scoring and live accompaniment by musical composer Jason Anastasoff.
  • Innovative costume design by Liz Ionescu.

And, last but certainly not least:

Paid compensation to the six professional dancers that will be bringing this new work to life: dancers Courtney Baron, Andrea Jane Dispenziere, James Morrow ChristinaNoel Reaves, Prentice Whitlow and myself included as choreographer and performer. This is the most crucial cause for our campaign. I believe that it is a critically important to reimburse the professional artists not only for their on-stage performance, but also for the time, talent and sweat already dedicated to the in-studio process.

 

THE GOAL: $6,000.00

Budget Breakdown:

Artist Wages: $3,000.00

Rehearsal Space Rentals: $1,550.00

Original Music Composition: $500.00

Original Costume Design: $250.00

Travel & Accomodation Expenses: $700.00

 

THE WORK:

Learning to forget and other tragic fortunes is a confession of memory and its opposing states; presence versus absence, repetition versus rendition, duration versus distortion, endurance versus exhaustion. We move to find answers, or perhaps even to make love, to our confusion. Our bodies tugs on the emotions that curdle and coil up on the inside and stamp vibrant patches onto musings past, staring back blankly and consuming us whole.

My creative process is immersive. I dive headfirst into inspiration, cushioning my fall with literature, conversations and exhibitions of other art mediums, artists and theorists that link up with my incentive. I talk about it, I read about it, I ask more questions, I take responsibility for it... I bathe in it. I spend the first 1 – 3 weeks in the studio alone where I contemplate, research and furiously generate movement material and contextual situations. I improvise with my eyes locked shut and guided by my gut. The result is a soft, faceted athleticism tinged by my technical training background and fueled by emotions aroused here and now. I create my dances for the bodies, personalities and histories of those individuals cast. We work intimately, maintaining a fluid dialogue throughout the process of design and construction. Revelation, doubt, wonder, love, hate flies around the studio and binds the dance together. My collaboration is an exchange of trust.

 

Our performance at the 2012 Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival is scheduled for August 1. We need your help. Your investment in this process —however, big or small— will help sustain and further support the manifestation of our artistic mission and the cooperation of its several contributing artists.

Thank you for your time and your generosity in browsing our fundraising campaign!

Please take a moment to check out the various pillow-inspired prizes that we've put together on the side-bar!

 

Sincerely,

Danielle Russo

 

About DRDC:

Danielle Russo Dance Company (DRDC) is a NYC-based dance theatre ensemble. Since its inception in 2006, choreographer Danielle Russo has been presented throughout the metropolis by various venues and organizations such as the American Dance Guild, Association of Performing Arts Presenters, Atlas Theater, BAAD!, Chez Buschwick, Dance New Amsterdam, dancenOw/NYC, DUMBO Dance Festival, Green Space, HERE Arts Center, H.T. Chen Dance Center, The Flea, The Tank, Triskelion Arts Center, Wave Rising Series, and Williamsburg Art neXus, and elsewhere at the American Dance Festival (Durham, NC), C.N.N. - Ballet de Lorraine (Nancy, France), Danscentrum Jette (Brussels, Belgium), Mercyhurst College (Erie, PA), The Yard (Martha’s Vineyard, MA) and WUK's Im_flieger (Vienna, Austria). In 2007, Russo co-directed and produced the emerging choreographers initiative The New Groundings Dance Project. In 2008 - 2009, she was a contributing choreographer in the Bessie Schoenberg Alumni Workshop at New York University and an artist in residence at dancenOw/NYC Silo. Russo served on faculty at Hollins University in 2010 and the American College Dance Festival Association’s Northeast Conference at Muhlenberg College in 2011. She attended the annual Performática as a guest artist coaching, creating and collaborating with other international movement and multimedia-makers in Puebla and Cholula, Mexico in April 2012. Most recently, she was selected as an Emerging Choreographer for the upcoming Springboard Danse Montréal in June 2012. Acclaimed dance critic Deborah Jowitt has hailed Russo for her “[d]ramatically eloquent athleticism”.(The Village Voice, 2008)

Russo is a recipient of a BFA in Dance and a BA in Anthropology from New York University (Tisch School of the Arts), and a MFA in Dance from Hollins University | American Dance Festival where she attended on fellowship. Additionally, she adjacently trained at the Salzburg Experimental Academy of Dance in Austria while pursuing her undergraduate degrees. 

http://www.daniellerussodancecompany.com

Our performance at the 2012 Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival is scheduled for August 1. We need your help. Your investment in this process —however, big or small— will help sustain and further support the manifestation of our artistic mission and the cooperation of its several contributing artists.
Thank you for your time and your generosity in browsing our fundraising campaign!
Please take a moment to check out the various pillow-inspired prizes that we've put together on the side-bar!
 
Sincerely,
Danielle Russo
 
About DRDC:
Danielle Russo Dance Company (DRDC) is a NYC-based dance theatre ensemble. Since its inception in 2006, choreographer Danielle Russo has been presented throughout the metropolis by various venues and organizations such as the American Dance Guild, Association of Performing Arts Presenters, Atlas Theater, BAAD!, Chez Buschwick, Dance New Amsterdam, dancenOw/NYC, DUMBO Dance Festival, Green Space, HERE Arts Center, H.T. Chen Dance Center, The Flea, The Tank, Triskelion Arts Center, Wave Rising Series, and Williamsburg Art neXus, and elsewhere at the American Dance Festival (Durham, NC), C.N.N. - Ballet de Lorraine (Nancy, France), Danscentrum Jette (Brussels, Belgium), Mercyhurst College (Erie, PA), The Yard (Martha’s Vineyard, MA) and WUK's Im_flieger (Vienna, Austria). In 2007, Russo co-directed and produced the emerging choreographers initiative The New Groundings Dance Project. In 2008 - 2009, she was a contributing choreographer in the Bessie Schoenberg Alumni Workshop at New York University and an artist in residence at dancenOw/NYC Silo. Russo served on faculty at Hollins University in 2010 and the American College Dance Festival Association’s Northeast Conference at Muhlenberg College in 2011. She attended the annual Performática as a guest artist coaching, creating and collaborating with other international movement and multimedia-makers in Puebla and Cholula, Mexico in April 2012. Most recently, she was selected as an Emerging Choreographer for the upcoming Springboard Danse Montréal in June 2012. Acclaimed dance critic Deborah Jowitt has hailed Russo for her “[d]ramatically eloquent athleticism”.(The Village Voice, 2008)
Russo is a recipient of a BFA in Dance and a BA in Anthropology from New York University (Tisch School of the Arts), and a MFA in Dance from Hollins University | American Dance Festival where she attended on fellowship. Additionally, she adjacently trained at the Salzburg Experimental Academy of Dance in Austria while pursuing her undergraduate degrees. 
http://www.daniellerussodancecompany.com

story:
Dixon Place presents Under a Scar-Filled Sky: The Buddy Zinn Mysteries, a collaborative theater / music project bringing together the talents of a diverse group. 


Conceived originally as four flash fictions in Kurt Gottschalk's Little Apples: A Story Cycle, the film noir styled one-act reveals moments in the life of a hard boiled detective, mixing elements of parody and zen parable with an interplay between theater and musical improvisation. The action is set in Buddy’s dingy office although the story itself may take place wholly or in part in Buddy’s mind as the descent into absurdism increasingly blurs the line between enlightenment and drunkenness.

Writer, journalist and musician Kurt Gottschalk's first published piece was a letter to Trouser Press magazine about David Bowie when he was 13. He received a Master’s in journalism from Columbia University and has written for the Village Voice, Time Out, Wire, The Brooklyn Rail and magazines in England, France, Ireland, Italy, Portugal and Russia. He produces and hosts the weekly radio program Miniature Minotaurs on WFMU. Under a Scar-Filled Sky was originally conceived as four short stories within his Little Apples: A Story Cycle, published by Lulu in 2011.

Kurt first met producer Kristen Persinos in high school and since reacquainting in New York they have collaborated on a number of musical projects. It was after Kristen's suggestion that the Buddy Zinn stories from Little Apples could be adapted for the stage that Kurt found himself in the guise of a playwright. Enlisting the talents of an experienced director and musical director, the project began to take shape.

Downtown experimental theater director Mahayana Landowne creates work with dramatic visions that transcend daily life.  Recent productions include : MIXED (Baruch Performing Arts), Impossible Country (Mudbone Collective), Baruch Voices (Baruch), Picasso Project (Luna Stage) to name a few.

Composer and bandleader Charlie Waters has been a key figure in the NYC Downtown jazz scene since relocating from Atlanta in the 1990s. Along with his own Gold Sparkle Band, Waters has played with William Parker's Little Huey Creative Music Orchestra and the trio Acid Birds, to name just a few. 

The company has been invited to show Under a Scar-Filled Sky as part of Dixon Place’s Performance Works-in-Progress series. This is an important first step towards the goal of a full production. Having the amazing support of Dixon Place will help shape the production script and score.

Funds from this campaign will go primarily to rehearsal space, basic set design, props and costuming as well as travel stipends for the cast and crew.  

Please support this exciting project. No donation is too small. And non-monetary support - forwarding and reposting the campaign page link,inviting friends to come to the show - is greatly appreciated.

See you and your on Feb 16th at 10pm at 161A Chrystie Steet, Dixon Place.

Thank you!

story:
VOUS PARLEZ FRANCAIS? → RDV EN BAS DE LA PAGE!

Short Summary - http://carteblanche-sf.com

My name is Charline Formenty, and I'm the artistic director of the San Francisco-based dance/theater company Carte Blanche. I moved from France to California three years ago in the hopes of creating a dance company. When I met the dancer Marie Plouviez, another recent immigrant from France, that dream came true. Together we founded Carte Blanche and created our first show, Ophelia (for more about the show, please visit our website at http://carteblanche-sf.com). Ophelia played at NOHspace in San Francisco for 3 sold out nights and received multiple awards from Bay Area Dance Watch.

Now, Fort Mason Center, one of San Francisco biggest cultural centers, is giving us a grant to produce a site-specific version of our show. This is an incredible opportunity for our company. We’ve taken Ophelia beyond the stage to the grounds of Fort Mason. The show will be an walk-through experience, combining video interaction, dance and theater. Ophelia will bring the audience on a journey through 5 different locations on the campus, both indoors and outdoors, creating a fully immersive experience for the viewer.

Besides being our first show, Ophelia is a project very dear to my heart. It is the story of my immigration to the United States and my journey as a woman in search of her identity. Creating this show with Marie Plouviez (who had also just moved to the country when we started the project) was an intensely personal experience. Yet I believe this show will make sense to anyone as an exploration of the self, dreams, and memories. Ophelia could be any of us.

Performing Ophelia at Fort Mason Center is not only a dream realized, but a huge boost for Carte Blanche. It will give us much more visibility and help us take the show on tour, all while bringing a great show to the community.

 

 

What We Need & What You Get


This dream can only come true with a complete budget. To make this project happen, we will need a total of $23,000. Fort Mason Center is giving us a $6,500 grant and we’ll make some money with ticket sales, but unfortunately that won’t be enough. We’re missing roughly $8,000.

Without your help, we won’t have enough funding to perform.

With your help we will:

- Pay the dancers and the technicians for their hard work
- Build the set and create the costumes
- Add a cutting-edge interactive video performance on a 150 ft long wall, featuring original 3D animations designed specifically for the show
- Create wonderful interactive virtual 3D animation
- Rent the audio/visual equipment
- Produce a great marketing campaign
- Pay for the necessary insurance and taxes


To express our gratitude for your help, we have a bunch of great perks ready for you! For only $25, you can become a part of our set, and we have custom-made limited edition cards, posters and T-shirts for all levels of donors (as well as a number of other great rewards).

If we don’t reach our entire goal, we will have to make some major cuts in the show. We won’t be able to afford a full crew, which would have a huge impact on the overall artistic value of the project. The whole project could potentially be in jeopardy. Without reaching our minimum budget, everything that makes this show so unique might be lost.


The Impact

The performing arts exist because they’re a vital part of the well-being of any community. They have always been a conduit for change, progress, and evolution, and are fundamental expressions of our freedom of speech. My goal with Ophelia is to elevate the way people experience life, and have some impact on the way we all look at the world. With this show, I want to share my unique perspective as a modern day immigrant with the community. My medium is dance, and my tools are dream imagery and poetry, laughter and sorrow, and conflict and harmony.

I’ve already put together a stellar crew for this project. All of us working on Ophelia are passionate artists who believe in this piece and want to achieve the highest possible artistic value. We all are heavily involved in the performing arts, and have enough experience to take on a project of this magnitude. We couldn’t be more excited to have this opportunity.

The history of Fort Mason Center, the talent of the cast and crew, and the foggy backdrop of San Francisco will all combine to create a new kind of immersive theatrical experience. I would love for each one of you to be a part of it.

 

Other ways you can help


No amount is too small - even $10 will help us reach our goal.  We understand that not everyone can help financially, but you can also help us by telling others about the show. Share this campaign, share our website, and share our facebook page! While donations are essential, spreading the word is just as important. Pass it along!

With Love,
Charline Formenty

 

 

 

EN FRANCAIS S’IL VOUS PLAIT!! 

Bonjour à tous,

Je m’appelle Charline Formenty, et je suis la directrice artistique de la compagnie Carte Blanche basée à San Francisco. J’ai fondé la compagnie en collaboration avec Marie Plouviez que j’ai rencontré dans les rues de San Francisco. Oui oui, juste en face de la maison bleue!! Ensemble nous avons créé Ophelia et réunit une équipe de professionnels autour de notre projet.
Nous avons eu l’occasion de montrer notre travail au NOHspace pour 3 représentations et nous avons eu la surprise et grande joie de faire salle comble les 3 soirs!  Quelques mois plus tard, nous avons recus deux awards  et l’opportunité de jouer au Garage puis à Portland dans l’Oregon. Enfin, Fort Mason Center nous a offert une subvention pour créer une version de notre spectacle adaptée à leur lieu.

Fort Mason Center est un des plus gros centres culturels de la ville de San Francisco, c’est donc une enorme opportunité qui s’offre à nous.

Le spectacle sera itinérant et nous emmerons le public pour une belle ballade à travers le Fort. Ca sera également l’occasion de mettre en valeur le patrimoine incroyable de cette ancienne base militaire.
Pour ce faire,  nous allons créer une version du spectacle avec de la danse, du théâtre et l’usage des nouvelles technologies avec de la video interactive!    

Ophelia est un projet qui nous tient particulièrement à coeur à Marie et moi-même car c’est une pièce qui raconte notre immigration aux Etats-Unis et la quête identitaire que ce type d’aventure force en nous. C’est un spectacle qui nous parle à tous, immigrants ou non car il parle d’identité, de rêves, et de mémoires. Ophelia c’est peut-être vous...

Jouer Ophelia à Fort Mason Center, ce n’est pas seulement un rêve, c’est aussi un pas énorme pour la compagnie Carte Blanche et nos carrières aux Etats-Unis.

Ce dont nous avons besoin et ce que vous obtenez


Mais pour réaliser ce rêve, nous avons besoin de votre aide!
Car ce rêve ne se réalisera pas sans avoir un budget cohérant. Pour jouer Ophelia à Fort Mason Center, nous avons besoin de $23,000 [17 500€]. Fort Mason Center nous donne une subvention de $6,500 [5 000€] et nous comptons récupérer de l'argent grace à la vente des tickets. Il nous manque donc $8,000 [6 000€] pour réaliser notre projet.

Et sans votre aide, nous n’y arriverons pas. Grace à vous nous pourrons: 

- Créer les animations 3D interactives
- Payer les danseurs et les techniciens pour leur travail
- Construire le décor et créer les costumes
- Développer la technologie nécéssaire pour les scènes d’interaction video
- Louer l’équipement son et lumière
- Avoir une bonne campagne publicitaire
- Payer pour les assurances et autres taxes

  
Pour vous exprimer notre gratitude pour votre générosité, nous avons prévu quelques cadeaux que nous pourrons votre envoyer à travers l’Atlantique! Koya Takahashi et moi-même allons créer des cartes, posters et t-shirts en édition limité qui seront signés par toute l’équipe avec des petites notes personnalisées bien sûr!
En plus, nous vous proposons aussi d’être là, avec Ophelia, sur scène. Et oui! Le décor d’Ophelia étant fait des lettres qu’elle recoit, qu’elle envoit, qu’elle imagine... nous aurons une lettre qui vous est adressée quelque part dans le décor!

Si nous n’atteignons pas notre but financier, nous ne pourrons malheureusement pas produire le spectacle tel que nous l’aons prévu. Il nous faudra couper plusieurs scènes du spectacle, et ça nous mettra en difficulté pour payer notre équipe et nous-même. De plus, la valeur artistique du spectacle en prendra un sacré coup! Ce qui fait que ce projet est si unique et différent tombera à l’eau.


L’impact

Les arts du spectacle ont toujours existé à travers toutes les civilisations pour la bonne raison qu'elles sont nécessaires au bien-être de la communauté et qu'ils ont été un excellent moyen de faire évoluer notre société. Il est important pour moi de réaliser ce projet parce que je veux partager mon point de vue avec vous et le plus de personnes possible. Pas pour devenir célèbre, pas pour devenir riche, mais pour sensibiliser les gens autour de moi à une perspective différente et avoir un impact sur la façon dont nous regardons le monde. Grâce au rêve et à la poésie, au rire et aux larmes, les arts de la scène existeront toujours car ils apportent aux gens de nouvelles perspectives et des rêves.

L’équipe que nous avons réunit pour ce projet est solide. C’est une équipe composée de gens passionnés par notre projet, qui ont vraiment envie de faire quelque chose avec nous sur le long-terme. Nous sommes tous très enthousiastes à l’idée de travailler sur ce spectacle qui va être si unique et différent de ce que l’on trouve sur la scène San Franciscaine.

Jouer Ophelia à Fort Mason Center sera une experience unique, qui apportera beaucoup à nos carrières respectives et j’aimerai que vous en fassiez parti, même de loin!

Merci,

Charline et Marie
